Text

Persuasion

by

[Jane Austen]89-jane austen

( 1818 )

Chapter 1

[Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter , of [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , in [Somersetshire]2-somersetshire , was [a man who , for [his]90-sir walter own amusement , never took up any book but the Baronetage]219-a man who , for his own amusement , never took up any book but the baronetage ; there [he]90-sir walter found occupation for an idle hour , and consolation in a distressed one ; there [his]90-sir walter faculties were roused into admiration and respect , by contemplating the limited remnant of the earliest patents ; there any unwelcome sensations , arising from domestic affairs changed naturally into pity and contempt as [he]90-sir walter turned over the almost endless creations of the last century ; and there , if every other leaf were powerless , [he]90-sir walter could read [his]90-sir walter own history with an interest which never failed . This was the page at which the favourite volume always opened :

" ELLIOT OF [KELLYNCH HALL]1-kellynch hall . "[221-his family]

" [Walter Elliot]90-sir walter , born March 1 , 1760 , married , July 15 , 1784 , [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , daughter of [James Stevenson]92-james stevenson , Esq . of [South Park]3-south park , in [the county of Gloucester]2199-the county of gloucester , by which [lady]2200-lady ( who died 1800 ) [he]90-sir walter has issue [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , born June 1 , 1785 ; [Anne]93-anne , born August 9 , 1787 ; [a still - born son]2201-a still - born son , November 5 , 1789 ; [Mary]94-mary , born November 20 , 1791 . "[221-his family]

Precisely such had the paragraph originally stood from [the printer]220-the printer 's hands ; but [Sir Walter]90-sir walter had improved it by adding , for the information of [himself]90-sir walter and [[his]90-sir walter family]221-his family , these words , after the date of [Mary]94-mary 's birth-- " Married , December 16 , 1810 , [Charles]95-charles , son and heir of [Charles Musgrove]96-charles , Esq . of [Uppercross]4-uppercross , in [the county of Somerset]2202-the county of somerset , "[90-sir walter] and by inserting most accurately the day of the month on which [he]90-sir walter had lost [[his]90-sir walter wife]222-his wife .

Then followed the history and rise of [the ancient and respectable family]223-the ancient and respectable family , in the usual terms ; how it had been first settled in [Cheshire]5-cheshire ; how mentioned in [Dugdale]97-dugdale , serving the office of high sheriff , representing [a borough]224-a borough in three successive parliaments , exertions of loyalty , and dignity of [baronet]225-baronet , in the first year of [Charles II]98-charles ii , with all [the Marys and Elizabeths]226-the marys and elizabeths [they]227-they had married ; forming altogether [two handsome duodecimo pages]228-two handsome duodecimo pages , and concluding with the arms and motto:--"Principal seat , [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , in [the county of Somerset]2202-the county of somerset , "[90-sir walter] and [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's handwriting again in this finale:--

" [Heir presumptive]2204-heir presumptive , [William Walter Elliot]99-william walter elliot , Esq . , [great grandson of [the second Sir Walter]2206-the second sir walter]2205-great grandson of the second sir walter . "[90-sir walter]

Vanity was the beginning and the end of [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter 's character ; vanity of person and of situation . [He]90-sir walter had been remarkably handsome in [his]90-sir walter youth ; and , at fifty - four , was still [a very fine man]229-a very fine man . [Few women]230-few women could think more of [their]230-few women personal appearance than [he]90-sir walter did , nor could [the valet of [any new made lord]232-any new made lord]231-the valet of any new made lord be more delighted with the place [he]90-sir walter held in [society]233-society . [He]90-sir walter considered the blessing of beauty as inferior only to the blessing of a baronetcy ; and [the Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter , who united these gifts , was the constant object of [his]90-sir walter warmest respect and devotion .

[His]90-sir walter good looks and [his]90-sir walter rank had one fair claim on [his]90-sir walter attachment ; since to [them]234-them [he]90-sir walter must have owed [a wife of very superior character]235-a wife of very superior character to any thing deserved by [his]90-sir walter own . [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot had been [an excellent woman]236-an excellent woman , sensible and amiable ; whose judgement and conduct , if [they]234-them might be pardoned the youthful infatuation which made [her]100-lady elliot [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot , had never required indulgence afterwards.--She had humoured , or softened , or concealed [his]90-sir walter failings , and promoted [his]90-sir walter real respectability for seventeen years ; and though not the very happiest being in [the world]237-the world [herself]100-lady elliot , had found enough in [her]100-lady elliot duties , [[her]100-lady elliot friends]238-her friends , and [[her]100-lady elliot children]239-her children , to attach [her]100-lady elliot to life , and make it no matter of indifference to [her]100-lady elliot when [she]100-lady elliot was called on to quit [them.--Three girls]240-them.--three girls , [the two eldest sixteen and fourteen]241-the two eldest sixteen and fourteen , was an awful legacy for [a mother]242-a mother to bequeath , an awful charge rather , to confide to the authority and guidance of [a conceited , silly father]243-a conceited , silly father . [She]100-lady elliot had , however , [one very intimate friend]244-one very intimate friend , [a sensible , deserving woman , who had been brought , by strong attachment to [herself]100-lady elliot , to settle close by [her]100-lady elliot , in [the village of]246-the village of [Kellynch]6-kellynch]245-a sensible , deserving woman , who had been brought , by strong attachment to herself , to settle close by her , in the village of kellynch ; and on [her]100-lady elliot kindness and advice , [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot mainly relied for the best help and maintenance of the good principles and instruction which [she]100-lady elliot had been anxiously giving [[her]100-lady elliot daughters]247-her daughters .

[This friend]248-this friend , and [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , did not marry , whatever might have been anticipated on that head by [their]249-their acquaintance . Thirteen years had passed away since [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot 's death , and [they]249-their were still near [neighbours]250-neighbours and [intimate friends]251-intimate friends , and [one]252-one remained [a widower]253-a widower , [the other]254-the other [a widow]255-a widow .

That [Lady Russell , of steady age and character , and extremely well provided for]256-lady russell , of steady age and character , and extremely well provided for , should have no thought of a second marriage , needs no apology to [the public]257-the public , which is rather apt to be unreasonably discontented when [a woman]258-a woman does marry again , than when [she]258-a woman does not ; but [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's continuing in singleness requires explanation . Be it known then , that [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , like [a good father]259-a good father , ( having met with one or two private disappointments in very unreasonable applications ) , prided [himself]90-sir walter on remaining single for [[his]90-sir walter dear daughters]260-his dear daughters ' sake . For [one daughter]261-one daughter , [[his]90-sir walter eldest]262-his eldest , [he]90-sir walter would really have given up any thing , which [he]90-sir walter had not been very much tempted to do . [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth had succeeded , at sixteen , to all that was possible , of [[her]91-elizabeth mother]263-her mother 's rights and consequence ; and being very handsome , and very like [himself]90-sir walter , [her]91-elizabeth influence had always been great , and [they]264-they had gone on together most happily . [[His]90-sir walter two other children]265-his two other children were of very inferior value . [Mary]94-mary had acquired a little artificial importance , by becoming [Mrs Charles Musgrove]96-charles ; but [Anne]93-anne , with an elegance of mind and sweetness of character , which must have placed [her]93-anne high with [any people of real understanding]266-any people of real understanding , was nobody with either [father]267-father or [sister]268-sister ; [her]93-anne word had no weight , [her]93-anne convenience was always to give way -- [she]93-anne was only [Anne]93-anne .

To [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , indeed , [she]101-lady russell was [a most dear and highly valued god - daughter]269-a most dear and highly valued god - daughter , favourite , and [friend]270-friend . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell loved [them]271-them all ; but it was only in [Anne]93-anne that [she]101-lady russell could fancy [the mother]272-the mother to revive again .

A few years before , [Anne Elliot]93-anne had been [a very pretty girl]273-a very pretty girl , but [her]93-anne bloom had vanished early ; and as even in its height , [[her]93-anne father]274-her father had found little to admire in [her]93-anne , ( so totally different were [her]93-anne delicate features and mild dark eyes from [his]274-her father own ) , there could be nothing in them , now that [she]93-anne was faded and thin , to excite [his]274-her father esteem . [He]274-her father had never indulged much hope , [he]274-her father had now none , of ever reading [her]93-anne name in any other page of [his]274-her father favourite work . All equality of alliance must rest with [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , for [Mary]94-mary had merely connected [herself]94-mary with [an old country family of respectability and large fortune]275-an old country family of respectability and large fortune , and had therefore given all the honour and received none : [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth would , one day or other , marry suitably .

It sometimes happens that [a woman]258-a woman is handsomer at twenty - nine than [she]258-a woman was ten years before ; and , generally speaking , if there has been neither ill health nor anxiety , it is a time of life at which scarcely any charm is lost . It was so with [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , still the same handsome [Miss Elliot]93-anne that [she]93-anne had begun to be thirteen years ago , and [Sir Walter]90-sir walter might be excused , therefore , in forgetting [her]93-anne age , or , at least , be deemed [only half a fool]277-only half a fool , for thinking [himself]90-sir walter and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth as blooming as ever , amidst the wreck of the good looks of [everybody else]278-everybody else ; for [he]90-sir walter could plainly see how old [all the rest of [[his]90-sir walter family]221-his family]279-all the rest of his family and acquaintance were growing . [Anne]93-anne haggard , [Mary]94-mary coarse , every face in [the neighbourhood]281-the neighbourhood worsting , and the rapid increase of the crow 's foot about [[Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's temples]282-lady russell 's temples had long been a distress to [him]90-sir walter .

[Elizabeth]91-elizabeth did not quite equal [[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father in personal contentment . Thirteen years had seen [[her]91-elizabeth mistress of [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall]284-her mistress of kellynch hall , presiding and directing with a self - possession and decision which could never have given the idea of [her]91-elizabeth being younger than [she]91-elizabeth was . For thirteen years had [she]91-elizabeth been doing the honours , and laying down the domestic law at [home]285-home , and leading the way to the chaise and four , and walking immediately after [Lady Russell]101-lady russell out of [all the drawing - rooms and dining - rooms in [the country]287-the country]286-all the drawing - rooms and dining - rooms in the country . Thirteen winters ' revolving frosts had seen [her]91-elizabeth opening every ball of credit which [a scanty neighbourhood]288-a scanty neighbourhood afforded , and thirteen springs shewn [their]289-their blossoms , as [she]91-elizabeth travelled up to [London]7-london with [[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father , for a few weeks ' annual enjoyment of [the great world]291-the great world . [She]91-elizabeth had the remembrance of all this , [she]91-elizabeth had the consciousness of being nine - and - twenty to give [her]91-elizabeth some regrets and some apprehensions ; [she]91-elizabeth was fully satisfied of being still quite as handsome as ever , but [she]91-elizabeth felt [her]91-elizabeth approach to the years of danger , and would have rejoiced to be certain of being properly solicited by [baronet - blood]292-baronet - blood within the next twelvemonth or two . Then might [she]91-elizabeth again take up the book of books with as much enjoyment as in [her]91-elizabeth early youth , but now [she]91-elizabeth liked it not . Always to be presented with the date of [her]91-elizabeth own birth and see no marriage follow but that of [a youngest sister]293-a youngest sister , made the book an evil ; and more than once , when [[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father had left it open on the table near [her]91-elizabeth , had [she]91-elizabeth closed it , with averted eyes , and pushed it away .

[She]91-elizabeth had had a disappointment , moreover , which that book , and especially the history of [[her]91-elizabeth own family]295-her own family , must ever present the remembrance of . [The heir presumptive]296-the heir presumptive , [the very William Walter Elliot , Esq .]297-the very william walter elliot , esq . , whose rights had been so generously supported by [[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father , had disappointed [her]91-elizabeth .

[She]91-elizabeth had , while [a very young girl]299-a very young girl , as soon as [she]91-elizabeth had known [him]297-the very william walter elliot , esq . to be , in the event of [her]91-elizabeth having [no brother]300-no brother , [the future baronet]301-the future baronet , meant to marry [him]297-the very william walter elliot , esq . , and [[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father had always meant that [she]91-elizabeth should . [He]297-the very william walter elliot , esq . had not been known to [them]303-them as [a boy]304-a boy ; but soon after [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot 's death , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter had sought the acquaintance , and though [his]90-sir walter overtures had not been met with any warmth , [he]90-sir walter had persevered in seeking it , making allowance for the modest drawing - back of youth ; and , in one of [their]303-them spring excursions to [London]7-london , when [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth was in [her]91-elizabeth first bloom , [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot had been forced into the introduction .

[He]102-mr elliot was at that time [a very young man]305-a very young man , just engaged in the study of the law ; and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth found [him]102-mr elliot extremely agreeable , and every plan in [his]102-mr elliot favour was confirmed . [He]102-mr elliot was invited to [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall ; [he]102-mr elliot was talked of and expected all the rest of the year ; but [he]102-mr elliot never came . The following spring [he]102-mr elliot was seen again in [town]306-town , found equally agreeable , again encouraged , invited , and expected , and again [he]102-mr elliot did not come ; and the next tidings were that [he]102-mr elliot was married . Instead of pushing [his]102-mr elliot fortune in the line marked out for [the heir of the house of Elliot]307-the heir of the house of elliot , [he]102-mr elliot had purchased independence by uniting [himself]102-mr elliot to [a rich woman of inferior birth]308-a rich woman of inferior birth .

[Sir Walter]90-sir walter had resented it . As [the head of [the house]310-the house]309-the head of the house , [he]90-sir walter felt that [he]90-sir walter ought to have been consulted , especially after taking [the young man]311-the young man so publicly by the hand ; " For [they]2207-they must have been seen together , "[90-sir walter] [he]90-sir walter observed , " once at [Tattersall 's]8-tattersall 's , and twice in [the lobby of [the House of Commons]2209-the house of commons]2208-the lobby of the house of commons . "[90-sir walter] [His]90-sir walter disapprobation was expressed , but apparently very little regarded . [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot had attempted no apology , and shewn [himself]102-mr elliot as unsolicitous of being longer noticed by [the family]312-the family , as [Sir Walter]90-sir walter considered [him]102-mr elliot unworthy of it : all acquaintance between [them]312-the family had ceased .

This very awkward history of [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot was still , after an interval of several years , felt with anger by [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , who had liked [the man]313-the man for [himself]102-mr elliot , and still more for being [[[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father 's heir , and whose strong family pride could see only in [him]102-mr elliot a proper match for [[Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter 's eldest daughter]316-sir walter elliot 's eldest daughter]315-her father 's heir , and whose strong family pride could see only in him a proper match for sir walter elliot 's eldest daughter . There was not [a baronet from A to Z whom [her]91-elizabeth feelings could have so willingly acknowledged as an equal]317-a baronet from a to z whom her feelings could have so willingly acknowledged as an equal . Yet so miserably had [he]102-mr elliot conducted [himself]102-mr elliot , that though [she]91-elizabeth was at this present time ( the summer of 1814 ) wearing black ribbons for [[his]102-mr elliot wife]222-his wife , [she]91-elizabeth could not admit [him]102-mr elliot to be worth thinking of again . The disgrace of [his]102-mr elliot first marriage might , perhaps , as there was no reason to suppose it perpetuated by [offspring]319-offspring , have been got over , had [he]102-mr elliot not done worse ; but [he]102-mr elliot had , as by the accustomary intervention of [kind friends]320-kind friends , [they]320-kind friends had been informed , spoken most disrespectfully of [them]320-kind friends all , most slightingly and contemptuously of the very blood [he]102-mr elliot belonged to , and the honours which were hereafter to be [his]102-mr elliot own . This could not be pardoned .

Such were [Elizabeth Elliot]91-elizabeth 's sentiments and sensations ; such the cares to alloy , the agitations to vary , the sameness and the elegance , the prosperity and the nothingness of [her]91-elizabeth scene of life ; such the feelings to give interest to a long , uneventful residence in [one country circle]321-one country circle , to fill the vacancies which there were no habits of utility abroad , no talents or accomplishments for [home]285-home , to occupy .

But now , another occupation and solicitude of mind was beginning to be added to these . [[Her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father was growing distressed for money . [She]91-elizabeth knew , that when [he]274-her father now took up [the Baronetage]324-the baronetage , it was to drive the heavy bills of [[his]274-her father tradespeople]325-his tradespeople , and the unwelcome hints of [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , [[his]274-her father agent]326-his agent , from [his]274-her father thoughts . The Kellynch property was good , but not equal to [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's apprehension of [the state]327-the state required in [its possessor]328-its possessor . While [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot lived , there had been method , moderation , and economy , which had just kept [him]102-mr elliot within [his]102-mr elliot income ; but with [her]91-elizabeth had died all such right - mindedness , and from that period [he]102-mr elliot had been constantly exceeding it . It had not been possible for [him]102-mr elliot to spend less ; [he]102-mr elliot had done nothing but what [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter was imperiously called on to do ; but blameless as [he]102-mr elliot was , [he]102-mr elliot was not only growing dreadfully in debt , but was hearing of it so often , that it became vain to attempt concealing it longer , even partially , from [[his]102-mr elliot daughter]329-his daughter . [He]102-mr elliot had given [her]91-elizabeth some hints of it the last spring in [town]306-town ; [he]102-mr elliot had gone so far even as to say , " Can [we]332-their retrench ? Does it occur to [you]91-elizabeth that there is any one article in which [we]332-their can retrench ? "[102-mr elliot] and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , to do [her]91-elizabeth justice , had , in the first ardour of female alarm , set seriously to think what could be done , and had finally proposed these two branches of economy , to cut off some unnecessary charities , and to refrain from new furnishing [the drawing - room]331-the drawing - room ; to which expedients [she]91-elizabeth afterwards added the happy thought of [their]332-their taking no present down to [Anne]93-anne , as had been the usual yearly custom . But these measures , however good in themselves , were insufficient for the real extent of the evil , the whole of which [Sir Walter]90-sir walter found [himself]90-sir walter obliged to confess to [her]91-elizabeth soon afterwards . [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth had nothing to propose of deeper efficacy . [She]91-elizabeth felt [herself]91-elizabeth ill - used and unfortunate , as did [[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father ; and [they]332-their were neither of [them]332-their able to devise any means of lessening [their]332-their expenses without compromising [their]332-their dignity , or relinquishing [their]332-their comforts in a way not to be borne .

There was only a small part of [[his]90-sir walter estate]334-his estate that [Sir Walter]90-sir walter could dispose of ; but had [every acre]335-every acre been alienable , it would have made no difference . [He]90-sir walter had condescended to mortgage as far as [he]90-sir walter had the power , but [he]90-sir walter would never condescend to sell . No ; [he]90-sir walter would never disgrace [his]90-sir walter name so far . [The Kellynch estate]336-the kellynch estate should be transmitted whole and entire , as [he]90-sir walter had received [it]336-the kellynch estate .

[[Their]332-their two confidential friends]337-their two confidential friends , [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , who lived in [the neighbouring market town]338-the neighbouring market town , and [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , were called to advise [them]332-their ; and both [father]267-father and [daughter]340-daughter seemed to expect that something should be struck out by one or the other to remove [their]332-their embarrassments and reduce [their]332-their expenditure , without involving the loss of any indulgence of taste or pride .

Chapter 2

[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , [a civil , cautious lawyer]341-a civil , cautious lawyer , who , whatever might be [his]103-mr shepherd hold or [his]103-mr shepherd views on [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , would rather have the disagreeable prompted by [anybody else]342-anybody else , excused [himself]103-mr shepherd from offering the slightest hint , and only begged leave to recommend an implicit reference to the excellent judgement of [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , from whose known good sense [he]103-mr shepherd fully expected to have just such resolute measures advised as [he]103-mr shepherd meant to see finally adopted .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell was most anxiously zealous on the subject , and gave it much serious consideration . [She]101-lady russell was [a woman rather of sound than of quick abilities , whose difficulties in coming to any decision in this instance were great , from the opposition of two leading principles]343-a woman rather of sound than of quick abilities , whose difficulties in coming to any decision in this instance were great , from the opposition of two leading principles . [She]101-lady russell was of strict integrity [herself]101-lady russell , with a delicate sense of honour ; but [she]101-lady russell was as desirous of saving [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's feelings , as solicitous for the credit of [the family]312-the family , as aristocratic in [her]101-lady russell ideas of what was due to [them]312-the family , as [anybody of sense]345-anybody of sense and honesty could well be . [She]101-lady russell was [a benevolent , charitable , good woman]346-a benevolent , charitable , good woman , and capable of strong attachments , most correct in [her]101-lady russell conduct , strict in [her]101-lady russell notions of decorum , and with manners that were held a standard of good - breeding . [She]101-lady russell had a cultivated mind , and was , generally speaking , rational and consistent ; but [she]101-lady russell had prejudices on the side of ancestry ; [she]101-lady russell had a value for rank and consequence , which blinded [her]101-lady russell a little to the faults of those who possessed [them]312-the family . [Herself]101-lady russell [the widow of only [a knight]348-a knight]347-the widow of only a knight , [she]101-lady russell gave the dignity of [a baronet]349-a baronet all its due ; and [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , independent of [his]90-sir walter claims as [an old acquaintance]350-an old acquaintance , [an attentive neighbour]351-an attentive neighbour , [an obliging landlord]352-an obliging landlord , [the husband of [[her]101-lady russell very dear friend]354-her very dear friend , [the father of [Anne]93-anne]355-the father of anne and [[her]93-anne sisters]356-her sisters]353-the husband of her very dear friend , the father of anne and her sisters , was , as being [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , in [her]101-lady russell apprehension , entitled to a great deal of compassion and consideration under [his]90-sir walter present difficulties .

[They]357-they must retrench ; that did not admit of a doubt . But [she]101-lady russell was very anxious to have it done with the least possible pain to [him]90-sir walter and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth . [She]101-lady russell drew up plans of economy , [she]101-lady russell made exact calculations , and [she]101-lady russell did what [nobody else]358-nobody else thought of doing : [she]101-lady russell consulted [Anne]93-anne , who never seemed considered by [the others]359-the others as having any interest in the question . [She]101-lady russell consulted , and in a degree was influenced by [her]101-lady russell in marking out the scheme of retrenchment which was at last submitted to [Sir Walter]90-sir walter . Every emendation of [Anne]93-anne 's had been on the side of honesty against importance . [She]101-lady russell wanted more vigorous measures , a more complete reformation , a quicker release from debt , a much higher tone of indifference for everything but justice and equity .

" If [we]2210-we can persuade [[your]2211-your father]2212-your father to all this , "[101-lady russell] said [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , looking over [her]101-lady russell paper , " much may be done . If [he]2212-your father will adopt these regulations , in seven years [he]2212-your father will be clear ; and [I]101-lady russell hope [we]2210-we may be able to convince [him]2212-your father and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , that [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall has a respectability in itself which can not be affected by these reductions ; and that the true dignity of [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter will be very far from lessened in the eyes of [sensible people]2213-sensible people , by acting like [a man of principle]2214-a man of principle . What will [he]2212-your father be doing , in fact , but what [very many of [[our]2210-we first families]2216-our first families]2215-very many of our first families have done , or ought to do ? There will be nothing singular in [his]2212-your father case ; and it is singularity which often makes the worst part of [our]2210-we suffering , as it always does of [our]2210-we conduct . [I]101-lady russell have great hope of prevailing . [We]2210-we must be serious and decided ; for after all , [the person who has contracted debts]2217-the person who has contracted debts must pay [them]2218-them ; and though a great deal is due to the feelings of [the gentleman]2219-the gentleman , and [the head of [a house]2221-a house , like [[your]93-anne father]2212-your father]2220-the head of a house , like your father , there is still more due to the character of [an honest man]2223-an honest man . "[101-lady russell]

This was the principle on which [Anne]93-anne wanted [[her]93-anne father]274-her father to be proceeding , [[his]274-her father friends]361-his friends to be urging [him]274-her father . [She]93-anne considered it as an act of indispensable duty to clear away the claims of [creditors]362-creditors with all the expedition which the most comprehensive retrenchments could secure , and saw no dignity in anything short of it . [She]93-anne wanted it to be prescribed , and felt as a duty . [She]93-anne rated [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's influence highly ; and as to the severe degree of self - denial which [her]93-anne own conscience prompted , [she]93-anne believed there might be little more difficulty in persuading [them]363-them to a complete , than to half a reformation . [Her]93-anne knowledge of [[her]93-anne father]274-her father and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth inclined [her]93-anne to think that the sacrifice of one pair of horses would be hardly less painful than of both , and so on , through the whole list of [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's too gentle reductions .

How [Anne]93-anne 's more rigid requisitions might have been taken is of little consequence . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's had no success at all : could not be put up with , were not to be borne . " What ! every comfort of life knocked off ! [Journeys]9-journeys , [London]7-london , [servants]2224-servants , horses , table -- contractions and restrictions every where ! To live no longer with the decencies even of [a private gentleman]2225-a private gentleman ! No , [he]2225-a private gentleman would sooner quit [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall at once , than remain in [it]1-kellynch hall on such disgraceful terms . "[103-mr shepherd]

" Quit [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall . "[103-mr shepherd] The hint was immediately taken up by [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , whose interest was involved in the reality of [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's retrenching , and who was perfectly persuaded that nothing would be done without a change of abode . " Since the idea had been started in the very quarter which ought to dictate , [he]2225-a private gentleman had no scruple , "[103-mr shepherd] [he]103-mr shepherd said , " in confessing [his]2225-a private gentleman judgement to be entirely on that side . It did not appear to [him]2225-a private gentleman that [Sir Walter]90-sir walter could materially alter [his]90-sir walter style of living in [a house]2221-a house which had such a character of hospitality and ancient dignity to support . In any other place [Sir Walter]90-sir walter might judge for [himself]90-sir walter ; and would be looked up to , as regulating the modes of life in whatever way [he]90-sir walter might choose to model [[his]90-sir walter household]2227-his household . "[103-mr shepherd]

[Sir Walter]90-sir walter would quit [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall ; and after a very few days more of doubt and indecision , the great question of whither [he]90-sir walter should go was settled , and the first outline of this important change made out .

There had been three alternatives , [London]7-london , [Bath]10-bath , or [another house in [the country]287-the country]365-another house in the country . All [Anne]93-anne 's wishes had been for the latter . [A small house in [[their]368-their own neighbourhood]369-their own neighbourhood , where [they]368-their might still have [[Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's society]370-lady russell 's society]367-a small house in their own neighbourhood , where they might still have lady russell 's society , still be near [Mary]94-mary , and still have the pleasure of sometimes seeing [the lawns and groves of [Kellynch]6-kellynch]371-the lawns and groves of kellynch , was the object of [her]93-anne ambition . But the usual fate of [Anne]93-anne attended [her]93-anne , in having something very opposite from [her]93-anne inclination fixed on . [She]93-anne disliked [Bath]10-bath , and did not think it agreed with [her]93-anne ; and [Bath]372-bath was to be [[her]93-anne home]373-her home .

[Sir Walter]90-sir walter had at first thought more of [London]7-london ; but [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd felt that [he]103-mr shepherd could not be trusted in [London]7-london , and had been skilful enough to dissuade [him]103-mr shepherd from it , and make [Bath]10-bath preferred . It was a much safer place for [a gentleman]374-a gentleman in [his]374-a gentleman predicament : [he]374-a gentleman might there be important at comparatively little expense . Two material advantages of [Bath]10-bath over [London]7-london had of course been given all [their]375-their weight : [its]10-bath more convenient distance from [Kellynch]6-kellynch , only fifty miles , and [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's spending some part of every winter there ; and to the very great satisfaction of [Lady Russell , whose first views on the projected change]376-lady russell , whose first views on the projected change had been for [Bath]10-bath , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth were induced to believe that [they]375-their should lose neither consequence nor enjoyment by settling [there]377-there .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell felt obliged to oppose [her]101-lady russell dear [Anne]93-anne 's known wishes . It would be too much to expect [Sir Walter]90-sir walter to descend into [a small house in [[his]90-sir walter own neighbourhood]379-his own neighbourhood]378-a small house in his own neighbourhood . [Anne]93-anne [herself]93-anne would have found the mortifications of it more than [she]93-anne foresaw , and to [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's feelings they must have been dreadful . And with regard to [Anne]93-anne 's dislike of [Bath]10-bath , [she]93-anne considered it as a prejudice and mistake arising , first , from the circumstance of [her]93-anne having been three years at [school]380-school [there]377-there , after [[her]93-anne mother]263-her mother 's death ; and secondly , from [her]93-anne happening to be not in perfectly good spirits the only winter which [she]93-anne had afterwards spent [there]377-there with [herself]93-anne .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell was fond of [Bath]10-bath , in short , and disposed to think it must suit [them]384-them all ; and as to [[her]101-lady russell young friend]385-her young friend 's health , by passing all the warm months with [her]101-lady russell at [Kellynch Lodge]11-kellynch lodge , every danger would be avoided ; and it was in fact , a change which must do both health and spirits good . [Anne]93-anne had been too little from [home]285-home , too little seen . [Her]93-anne spirits were not high . A larger society would improve [them]387-them . [She]101-lady russell wanted [her]93-anne to be more known .

The undesirableness of [any other house in [the same neighbourhood]389-the same neighbourhood]388-any other house in the same neighbourhood for [Sir Walter]90-sir walter was certainly much strengthened by one part , and a very material part of the scheme , which had been happily engrafted on the beginning . [He]90-sir walter was not only to quit [[his]90-sir walter home]390-his home , but to see it in the hands of [others]391-others ; a trial of fortitude , which stronger heads than [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's have found too much . [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall was to be let . This , however , was a profound secret , not to be breathed beyond [their]384-them own circle .

[Sir Walter]90-sir walter could not have borne the degradation of being known to design letting [[his]90-sir walter house]392-his house . [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd had once mentioned the word " advertise , "[103-mr shepherd] but never dared approach it again . [Sir Walter]90-sir walter spurned the idea of its being offered in any manner ; forbad the slightest hint being dropped of [his]90-sir walter having such an intention ; and it was only on the supposition of [his]90-sir walter being spontaneously solicited by [some most unexceptionable applicant]393-some most unexceptionable applicant , on [his]90-sir walter own terms , and as a great favour , that [he]90-sir walter would let it at all .

How quick come the reasons for approving what [we]394-we like ! [Lady Russell]101-lady russell had another excellent one at hand , for being extremely glad that [Sir Walter]90-sir walter and [[his]90-sir walter family]221-his family were to remove from [the country]287-the country . [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth had been lately forming an intimacy , which [she]101-lady russell wished to see interrupted . It was with the daughter of [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , who had returned , after an unprosperous marriage , to [[[her]91-elizabeth father]274-her father 's house]398-her father 's house , with the additional burden of [two children]399-two children . [She]91-elizabeth was [a clever young woman , who understood the art of pleasing -- the art of pleasing , at least]400-a clever young woman , who understood the art of pleasing -- the art of pleasing , at least , at [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall ; and who had made [herself]91-elizabeth so acceptable to [Miss Elliot]93-anne , as to have been already staying [there]377-there more than once , in spite of all that [Lady Russell , who thought it a friendship quite out of place , could hint of caution and reserve]402-lady russell , who thought it a friendship quite out of place , could hint of caution and reserve .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell , indeed , had scarcely any influence with [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , and seemed to love [her]91-elizabeth , rather because [she]101-lady russell would love [her]91-elizabeth , than because [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth deserved it . [She]101-lady russell had never received from [her]101-lady russell more than outward attention , nothing beyond the observances of complaisance ; had never succeeded in any point which [she]101-lady russell wanted to carry , against previous inclination . [She]101-lady russell had been repeatedly very earnest in trying to get [Anne]93-anne included in the visit to [London]7-london , sensibly open to all the injustice and all the discredit of the selfish arrangements which shut [her]101-lady russell out , and on many lesser occasions had endeavoured to give [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth the advantage of [her]91-elizabeth own better judgement and experience ; but always in vain : [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth would go [her]91-elizabeth own way ; and never had [she]91-elizabeth pursued it in more decided opposition to [Lady Russell]101-lady russell than in this selection of [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay ; turning from the society of so deserving [a sister]403-a sister , to bestow [her]91-elizabeth affection and confidence on one who ought to have been nothing to [her]91-elizabeth but [the object of distant civility]404-the object of distant civility .

From situation , [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay was , in [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's estimate , a very unequal , and in [her]105-mrs clay character [she]101-lady russell believed [a very dangerous companion]405-a very dangerous companion ; and a removal that would leave [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay behind , and bring a choice of more suitable intimates within [Miss Elliot]93-anne 's reach , was therefore an object of first - rate importance .

Chapter 3

" [I]103-mr shepherd must take leave to observe , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , "[103-mr shepherd] said [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd one morning at [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , as [he]103-mr shepherd laid down the newspaper , " that the present juncture is much in [our]2228-our favour . This peace will be turning all [[our]2228-our rich naval officers]2229-our rich naval officers ashore . [They]2229-our rich naval officers will be all wanting [a home]2230-a home . Could not be a better time , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , for having a choice of [tenants]2231-tenants , [very responsible tenants]2232-very responsible tenants . Many a noble fortune has been made during the war . If [a rich admiral]2233-a rich admiral were to come in [our]2228-our way , [Sir Walter--]106-sir walter-- "[103-mr shepherd]

" [He]2233-a rich admiral would be [a very lucky man]2234-a very lucky man , [Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , "[90-sir walter] replied [Sir Walter]90-sir walter ; " that 's all [I]90-sir walter have to remark . A prize indeed would [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall be to [him]2233-a rich admiral ; rather the greatest prize of all , let [him]2233-a rich admiral have taken ever so many before ; hey , [Shepherd]103-mr shepherd ? "[90-sir walter]

[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd laughed , as [he]103-mr shepherd knew [he]103-mr shepherd must , at this wit , and then added--

" [I]103-mr shepherd presume to observe , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , that , in the way of business , [gentlemen of the navy]2235-gentlemen of the navy are well to deal with . [I]103-mr shepherd have had a little knowledge of [their]2235-gentlemen of the navy methods of doing business ; and [I]103-mr shepherd am free to confess that [they]2235-gentlemen of the navy have very liberal notions , and are as likely to make [desirable tenants]2236-desirable tenants as [any set of people [one]252-one should meet with]2237-any set of people one should meet with . Therefore , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , what [I]103-mr shepherd would take leave to suggest is , that if in consequence of any rumours getting abroad of [your]90-sir walter intention ; which must be contemplated as a possible thing , because [we]2239-our know how difficult it is to keep the actions and designs of [one part of [the world]237-the world]2240-one part of the world from the notice and curiosity of the other ; consequence has its tax ; [I]103-mr shepherd , [John Shepherd]107-john shepherd , might conceal any family - matters that [I]103-mr shepherd chose , for [nobody]2242-nobody would think it worth [their]2242-nobody while to observe [me]103-mr shepherd ; but [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter has eyes upon [him]90-sir walter which it may be very difficult to elude ; and therefore , thus much [I]103-mr shepherd venture upon , that it will not greatly surprise [me]103-mr shepherd if , with all [our]2239-our caution , some rumour of the truth should get abroad ; in the supposition of which , as [I]103-mr shepherd was going to observe , since applications will unquestionably follow , [I]103-mr shepherd should think any from [[our]2239-our wealthy naval commanders]2243-our wealthy naval commanders particularly worth attending to ; and beg leave to add , that two hours will bring [me]103-mr shepherd over at any time , to save [you]90-sir walter the trouble of replying . "[103-mr shepherd]

[Sir Walter]90-sir walter only nodded . But soon afterwards , rising and pacing [the room]406-the room , [he]90-sir walter observed sarcastically--

" There are few among [the gentlemen of [the navy]2245-the navy]2244-the gentlemen of the navy , [I]103-mr shepherd imagine , who would not be surprised to find [themselves]2244-the gentlemen of the navy in [a house of this description]2246-a house of this description . "[103-mr shepherd]

" [They]2244-the gentlemen of the navy would look around [them]2244-the gentlemen of the navy , no doubt , and bless [their]2244-the gentlemen of the navy good fortune , "[105-mrs clay] said [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay , for [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay was present : [[her]105-mrs clay father]274-her father had driven [her]105-mrs clay over , nothing being of so much use to [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay 's health as a drive to [Kellynch]6-kellynch : " but [I]103-mr shepherd quite agree with [[my]103-mr shepherd father]2247-my father in thinking [a sailor]2248-a sailor might be [a very desirable tenant]2249-a very desirable tenant . [I]103-mr shepherd have known a good deal of the profession ; and besides [their]2244-the gentlemen of the navy liberality , [they]2244-the gentlemen of the navy are so neat and careful in all [their]2244-the gentlemen of the navy ways ! These valuable pictures of [yours]90-sir walter , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , if [you]90-sir walter chose to leave them , would be perfectly safe . Everything in and about [the house]310-the house would be taken such excellent care of ! [The gardens]2251-the gardens and shrubberies would be kept in almost as high order as they are now . [You]90-sir walter need not be afraid , [Miss Elliot]93-anne , of [[your]90-sir walter own sweet flower gardens]2252-your own sweet flower gardens being neglected . "[103-mr shepherd]

" As to all that , "[90-sir walter] rejoined [Sir Walter]90-sir walter coolly , " supposing [I]90-sir walter were induced to let [[my]90-sir walter house]2253-my house , [I]90-sir walter have by no means made up [my]90-sir walter mind as to the privileges to be annexed to it . [I]90-sir walter am not particularly disposed to favour [a tenant]2254-a tenant . [The park]2255-the park would be open to [him]2254-a tenant of course , and [few navy officers]2256-few navy officers , or [men of any other description]2257-men of any other description , can have had such a range ; but what restrictions [I]90-sir walter might impose on the use of [the pleasure - grounds]2258-the pleasure - grounds , is another thing . [I]90-sir walter am not fond of the idea of [my]90-sir walter shrubberies being always approachable ; and [I]90-sir walter should recommend [Miss Elliot]93-anne to be on [her]93-anne guard with respect to [[her]93-anne flower garden]2259-her flower garden . [I]90-sir walter am very little disposed to grant [a tenant of Kellynch Hall]2260-a tenant of kellynch hall any extraordinary favour , [I]90-sir walter assure [you]2261-you , be [he]2260-a tenant of kellynch hall [sailor]2262-sailor or [soldier]2263-soldier . "[90-sir walter]

After a short pause , [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd presumed to say--

" In all these cases , there are established usages which make everything plain and easy between [landlord]2264-landlord and [tenant]2265-tenant . [Your]2261-you interest , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , is in pretty safe hands . Depend upon [me]103-mr shepherd for taking care that [no tenant]2266-no tenant has more than [his]2260-a tenant of kellynch hall just rights . [I]103-mr shepherd venture to hint , that [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter can not be half so jealous for [his]90-sir walter own , as [John Shepherd]107-john shepherd will be for [him]90-sir walter . "[103-mr shepherd]

Here [Anne]93-anne spoke--

" [The navy]2245-the navy , [I]93-anne think , who have done so much for [us]2268-us , have at least an equal claim with [any other set of men]2269-any other set of men , for all the comforts and all the privileges which [any home]2270-any home can give . [Sailors]2271-sailors work hard enough for [their]2271-sailors comforts , [we]2268-us must all allow . "[93-anne]

" Very true , very true . What [Miss Anne]93-anne says , is very true , "[103-mr shepherd] was [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd 's rejoinder , and " Oh ! certainly , "[329-his daughter] was [[his]103-mr shepherd daughter]329-his daughter 's ; but [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's remark was , soon afterwards--

" The profession has its utility , but [I]93-anne should be sorry to see [any friend of mine]2272-any friend of mine belonging to it . "[93-anne]

" Indeed ! "[93-anne] was the reply , and with a look of surprise .

" Yes ; it is in two points offensive to [me]93-anne ; [I]93-anne have two strong grounds of objection to it . First , as being the means of bringing [persons of obscure birth]2273-persons of obscure birth into undue distinction , and raising [men]2274-men to honours which [[their]2274-men fathers]2275-their fathers and [grandfathers]2276-grandfathers never dreamt of ; and secondly , as it cuts up [a man]2277-a man 's youth and vigour most horribly ; [a sailor]2248-a sailor grows old sooner than [any other man]2279-any other man . [I]93-anne have observed it all [my]93-anne life . [A man]2277-a man is in greater danger in the navy of being insulted by the rise of [one whose father , [[his]2277-a man father]2282-his father might have disdained to speak to , and of becoming prematurely an object of disgust [himself]2277-a man , than in any other line]2281-one whose father , his father might have disdained to speak to , and of becoming prematurely an object of disgust himself , than in any other line . One day last spring , in [town]306-town , [I]93-anne was in company with [two men]2284-two men , striking instances of what [I]93-anne am talking of ; [Lord St Ives]108-lord st ives , whose father [we]2285-we all know to have been [a country curate , without bread to eat]2286-a country curate , without bread to eat ; [I]93-anne was to give place to [Lord St Ives]108-lord st ives , and [a certain [Admiral Baldwin]109-admiral baldwin , the most deplorable - looking personage [you]2288-they can imagine]2287-a certain admiral baldwin , the most deplorable - looking personage you can imagine ; [his]109-admiral baldwin face the colour of mahogany , rough and rugged to the last degree ; all lines and wrinkles , nine grey hairs of a side , and nothing but a dab of powder at top . ' In the name of [heaven]2289-heaven , who is [that old fellow]2290-that old fellow ? ' said [I]93-anne to [a friend of [mine]93-anne who was standing near]2291-a friend of mine who was standing near , ( [Sir Basil Morley]110-sir basil ) . ' [Old fellow]2292-old fellow ! ' cried [Sir Basil]110-sir basil , ' it is [Admiral Baldwin]109-admiral baldwin . What do [you]110-sir basil take [his]109-admiral baldwin age to be ? ' ' Sixty , ' said [I]93-anne , ' or perhaps sixty - two . ' ' Forty , ' replied [Sir Basil]110-sir basil , ' forty , and no more . ' Picture to [yourselves]2288-they [my]93-anne amazement ; [I]93-anne shall not easily forget [Admiral Baldwin]109-admiral baldwin . [I]93-anne never saw quite so wretched an example of what [a sea - faring life]2293-a sea - faring life can do ; but to a degree , [I]93-anne know it is the same with [them]2288-they all : [they]2288-they are all knocked about , and exposed to every climate , and every weather , till [they]2288-they are not fit to be seen . It is a pity [they]2288-they are not knocked on the head at once , before [they]2288-they reach [Admiral Baldwin]109-admiral baldwin 's age . "[93-anne]

" Nay , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , "[105-mrs clay] cried [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay , " this is being severe indeed . Have a little mercy on [the poor men]2294-the poor men . [We]2295-we are not all born to be handsome . [The sea]2296-the sea is no beautifier , certainly ; [sailors]2271-sailors do grow old betimes ; [I]105-mrs clay have observed it ; [they]2271-sailors soon lose the look of youth . But then , is not it the same with many other professions , perhaps most other ? [Soldiers , in active service]2298-soldiers , in active service , are not at all better off : and even in the quieter professions , there is a toil and a labour of the mind , if not of the body , which seldom leaves [a man]2277-a man 's looks to the natural effect of time . [The lawyer]2300-the lawyer plods , quite care - worn ; [the physician]2301-the physician is up at all hours , and travelling in all weather ; and even [the clergyman--]2302-the clergyman-- "[105-mrs clay] [she]105-mrs clay stopt a moment to consider what might do for the clergyman;--"and even [the clergyman]2303-the clergyman , [you]2304-you know is obliged to go into [infected rooms]2305-infected rooms , and expose [his]2303-the clergyman health and looks to all the injury of a poisonous atmosphere . In fact , as [I]93-anne have long been convinced , though every profession is necessary and honourable in its turn , it is only the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in [the country]287-the country , choosing [their]2294-the poor men own hours , following [their]2294-the poor men own pursuits , and living on [[their]2294-the poor men own property]2307-their own property , without the torment of trying for more ; it is only [their]2294-the poor men lot , [I]93-anne say , to hold the blessings of health and a good appearance to the utmost : [I]93-anne know [no other set of men]2308-no other set of men but what lose something of [their]2294-the poor men personableness when [they]2294-the poor men cease to be quite young . "[93-anne]

It seemed as if [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , in this anxiety to bespeak [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's good will towards [a naval officer as tenant]409-a naval officer as tenant , had been gifted with foresight ; for the very first application for [the house]310-the house was from [an Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft , with whom [he]103-mr shepherd shortly afterwards fell into company in attending the quarter sessions at [Taunton]12-taunton ; and indeed , [he]103-mr shepherd had received a hint of [the Admiral]411-the admiral from [a London correspondent]412-a london correspondent . By the report which [he]103-mr shepherd hastened over to [Kellynch]6-kellynch to make , [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft was [a native of [Somersetshire]2-somersetshire]413-a native of somersetshire , who having acquired a very handsome fortune , was wishing to settle in [[his]111-admiral croft [own country]415-own country]414-his own country , and had come down to [Taunton]12-taunton in order to look at some advertised places in [that immediate neighbourhood]416-that immediate neighbourhood , which , however , had not suited [him]111-admiral croft ; that accidentally hearing--(it was just as [he]103-mr shepherd had foretold , [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd observed , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's concerns could not be kept a secret,)--accidentally hearing of the possibility of [Kellynch Hall]6-kellynch being to let , and understanding [his]103-mr shepherd ( [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd 's ) connection with [the owner]417-the owner , [he]103-mr shepherd had introduced [himself]103-mr shepherd to [him]417-the owner in order to make particular inquiries , and had , in the course of a pretty long conference , expressed as strong an inclination for [the place]418-the place as [a man who knew it only by description]419-a man who knew it only by description could feel ; and given [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd , in [his]103-mr shepherd explicit account of [himself]103-mr shepherd , every proof of [his]103-mr shepherd being [a most responsible , eligible tenant]420-a most responsible , eligible tenant .

" And who is [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft ? "[90-sir walter] was [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's cold suspicious inquiry .

[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd answered for [his]103-mr shepherd being of [[a gentleman]374-a gentleman 's family]422-a gentleman 's family , and mentioned [a place]423-a place ; and [Anne]93-anne , after the little pause which followed , added--

" [He]111-admiral croft is [a rear admiral of the white]2309-a rear admiral of the white . [He]111-admiral croft was in the Trafalgar action , and has been in [the East Indies]13-the east indies since ; [he]111-admiral croft was stationed [there]377-there , [I]93-anne believe , several years . "[93-anne]

" Then [I]90-sir walter take it for granted , "[90-sir walter] observed [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , " that [his]111-admiral croft face is about as orange as the cuffs and capes of [my]90-sir walter livery . "[90-sir walter]

[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd hastened to assure [him]103-mr shepherd , that [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft was [a very hale , hearty , well - looking man]424-a very hale , hearty , well - looking man , a little weather - beaten , to be sure , but not much , and quite the gentleman in all [his]111-admiral croft notions and behaviour ; not likely to make the smallest difficulty about terms , only wanted [a comfortable home]425-a comfortable home , and to get into [it]425-a comfortable home as soon as possible ; knew [he]111-admiral croft must pay for [his]111-admiral croft convenience ; knew what rent [a ready - furnished house of that consequence]426-a ready - furnished house of that consequence might fetch ; should not have been surprised if [Sir Walter]90-sir walter had asked more ; had inquired about [the manor]427-the manor ; would be glad of the deputation , certainly , but made no great point of it ; said [he]111-admiral croft sometimes took out a gun , but never killed ; quite [the gentleman]2219-the gentleman .

[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd was eloquent on the subject ; pointing out all the circumstances of [[the Admiral]411-the admiral 's family]430-the admiral 's family , which made [him]111-admiral croft peculiarly desirable as [a tenant]2254-a tenant . [He]111-admiral croft was [a married man]432-a married man , and without [children]433-children ; the very state to be wished for . [A house]2221-a house was never taken good care of , [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd observed , without [a lady]435-a lady : [he]103-mr shepherd did not know , whether furniture might not be in danger of suffering as much where there was [no lady]436-no lady , as where there were [many children]437-many children . [A lady]435-a lady , without [a family]439-a family , was the very best preserver of furniture in [the world]237-the world . [He]103-mr shepherd had seen [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , too ; [she]112-mrs croft was at [Taunton]12-taunton with [the admiral]411-the admiral , and had been present almost all the time [they]442-they were talking the matter over .

" And [a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady]2311-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady , [she]112-mrs croft seemed to be , "[103-mr shepherd] continued [he]103-mr shepherd ; " asked more questions about [the house]310-the house , and terms , and taxes , than [the Admiral]411-the admiral [himself]411-the admiral , and seemed more conversant with business ; and moreover , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , [I]103-mr shepherd found [she]112-mrs croft was not quite unconnected in [this country]2314-this country , any more than [[her]112-mrs croft husband]2315-her husband ; that is to say , [she]112-mrs croft is sister to [a gentleman who did live amongst [us]2317-us once]2316-a gentleman who did live amongst us once ; [she]112-mrs croft told [me]103-mr shepherd so [herself]112-mrs croft : sister to [the gentleman who lived a few years back at [Monkford]14-monkford]2318-the gentleman who lived a few years back at monkford . "[103-mr shepherd]

But [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay was talking so eagerly with [Miss Elliot]93-anne , that [she]105-mrs clay did not hear the appeal .

" [I]103-mr shepherd have no conception whom [you]113-penelope can mean , [Shepherd]103-mr shepherd ; [I]103-mr shepherd remember [no gentleman resident at [Monkford]14-monkford since the time of [old Governor Trent]114-old governor trent]2322-no gentleman resident at monkford since the time of old governor trent . "[103-mr shepherd]

" Bless [me]103-mr shepherd ! how very odd ! [I]103-mr shepherd shall forget [my]103-mr shepherd own name soon , [I]103-mr shepherd suppose . A name that [I]103-mr shepherd am so very well acquainted with ; knew [the gentleman]2219-the gentleman so well by sight ; seen [him]2219-the gentleman a hundred times ; came to consult [me]103-mr shepherd once , [I]103-mr shepherd remember , about a trespass of [one of [[his]2219-the gentleman neighbours]2325-his neighbours]2324-one of his neighbours ; [[farmer]2326-farmer 's man]2327-farmer 's man breaking into [[his]2219-the gentleman orchard]2328-his orchard ; wall torn down ; apples stolen ; caught in the fact ; and afterwards , contrary to [my]103-mr shepherd judgement , submitted to an amicable compromise . Very odd indeed ! "[103-mr shepherd]

After waiting another moment--

" [You]103-mr shepherd mean [Mr Wentworth]115-mr wentworth , [I]93-anne suppose ? "[93-anne] said [Anne]93-anne .

[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd was all gratitude .

" [Wentworth]115-mr wentworth was the very name ! [Mr Wentworth]115-mr wentworth was [the very man]2329-the very man . " [Wentworth]115-mr wentworth ? Oh ! ay,--Mr [Wentworth]115-mr wentworth , [the curate of [Monkford]14-monkford]2331-the curate of monkford . [You]103-mr shepherd misled [me]103-mr shepherd by the term [gentleman]2332-gentleman . [I]103-mr shepherd thought [you]103-mr shepherd were speaking of [some man of property]2333-some man of property : [Mr Wentworth]115-mr wentworth was [nobody]2242-nobody , [I]103-mr shepherd remember ; quite unconnected ; nothing to do with [the Strafford family]2335-the strafford family . [One]252-one wonders how the names of many of [[our]2337-our nobility]2338-our nobility become so common . "[103-mr shepherd]

As [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd perceived that this connexion of [the Crofts]116-the crofts did [them]116-the crofts no service with [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , [he]103-mr shepherd mentioned it no more ; returning , with all [his]103-mr shepherd zeal , to dwell on the circumstances more indisputably in [their]116-the crofts favour ; [their]116-the crofts age , and number , and fortune ; the high idea [they]116-the crofts had formed of [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , and extreme solicitude for the advantage of renting [it]1-kellynch hall ; making it appear as if [they]116-the crofts ranked nothing beyond the happiness of being [the tenants of [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter]443-the tenants of sir walter elliot : an extraordinary taste , certainly , could [they]116-the crofts have been supposed in the secret of [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's estimate of the dues of [a tenant]2254-a tenant .

It succeeded , however ; and though [Sir Walter]90-sir walter must ever look with an evil eye on anyone intending to inhabit [that house]445-that house , and think [them]116-the crofts infinitely too well off in being permitted to rent [it]445-that house on the highest terms , [he]90-sir walter was talked into allowing [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd to proceed in the treaty , and authorising [him]90-sir walter to wait on [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft , who still remained at [Taunton]12-taunton , and fix a day for [the house]310-the house being seen .

[Sir Walter]90-sir walter was not very wise ; but still [he]90-sir walter had experience enough of [the world]237-the world to feel , that [a more unobjectionable tenant]448-a more unobjectionable tenant , in all essentials , than [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft bid fair to be , could hardly offer . So far went [his]90-sir walter understanding ; and [his]90-sir walter vanity supplied a little additional soothing , in [the Admiral]411-the admiral 's situation in life , which was just high enough , and not too high . " [I]454-an admiral have let [[my]454-an admiral house]2253-my house to [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft , "[454-an admiral] would sound extremely well ; very much better than to [any mere Mr--]450-any mere mr-- ; [a Mr]451-a mr ( save , perhaps , [some half dozen in [the nation]453-the nation]452-some half dozen in the nation , ) always needs a note of explanation . [An admiral]454-an admiral speaks [his]454-an admiral own consequence , and , at the same time , can never make [a baronet]349-a baronet look small . In all [their]456-their dealings and intercourse , [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter must ever have the precedence .

Nothing could be done without a reference to [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth : but [her]91-elizabeth inclination was growing so strong for a removal , that [she]91-elizabeth was happy to have it fixed and expedited by [a tenant at hand]457-a tenant at hand ; and not a word to suspend decision was uttered by [her]91-elizabeth .

[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd was completely empowered to act ; and no sooner had such an end been reached , than [Anne]93-anne , who had been [a most attentive listener to the whole]458-a most attentive listener to the whole , left [the room]406-the room , to seek the comfort of cool air for [her]93-anne flushed cheeks ; and as [she]93-anne walked along [a favourite grove]460-a favourite grove , said , with a gentle sigh , " A few months more , and [he]90-sir walter , perhaps , may be walking [here]2340-here . "[93-anne]

Chapter 4

[He]90-sir walter was not [Mr Wentworth]115-mr wentworth , [the former curate of [Monkford]14-monkford]461-the former curate of monkford , however suspicious appearances may be , but [a Captain [Frederick Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , [his]115-mr wentworth brother , who being made commander in consequence of the action off [St Domingo]15-st domingo , and not immediately employed , had come into [Somersetshire]2-somersetshire]117-captain wentworth , in the summer of 1806 ; and having [no parent]462-no parent living , found a home for half a year at [Monkford]14-monkford . [He]90-sir walter was , at that time , [a remarkably fine young man , with a great deal of intelligence , spirit , and brilliancy]463-a remarkably fine young man , with a great deal of intelligence , spirit , and brilliancy ; and [Anne]93-anne [an extremely pretty girl , with gentleness , modesty , taste , and feeling]464-an extremely pretty girl , with gentleness , modesty , taste , and feeling . Half the sum of attraction , on either side , might have been enough , for [he]90-sir walter had nothing to do , and [she]93-anne had hardly [anybody to love]465-anybody to love ; but the encounter of such lavish recommendations could not fail . [They]466-they were gradually acquainted , and when acquainted , rapidly and deeply in love . It would be difficult to say which had seen highest perfection in the other , or which had been the happiest : [she]93-anne , in receiving [his]90-sir walter declarations and proposals , or [he]90-sir walter in having them accepted .

A short period of exquisite felicity followed , and but a short one . Troubles soon arose . [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , on being applied to , without actually withholding [his]90-sir walter consent , or saying it should never be , gave it all the negative of great astonishment , great coldness , great silence , and a professed resolution of doing nothing for [[his]90-sir walter daughter]329-his daughter . [He]90-sir walter thought it a very degrading alliance ; and [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , though with more tempered and pardonable pride , received it as a most unfortunate one .

[Anne Elliot]93-anne , with all [her]93-anne claims of birth , beauty , and mind , to throw [herself]93-anne away at nineteen ; involve [herself]93-anne at nineteen in an engagement with [a young man]468-a young man , who had nothing but [himself]468-a young man to recommend [him]468-a young man , and [no hopes of attaining affluence , but in the chances of a most uncertain profession]469-no hopes of attaining affluence , but in the chances of a most uncertain profession , and no connexions to secure even [his]468-a young man farther rise in the profession , would be , indeed , a throwing away , which [she]93-anne grieved to think of ! [Anne Elliot]93-anne , so young ; known to so few , to be snatched off by [a stranger without alliance or fortune]470-a stranger without alliance or fortune ; or rather sunk by [him]468-a young man into [a state of most wearing , anxious , youth - killing dependence]471-a state of most wearing , anxious , youth - killing dependence ! It must not be , if by any fair interference of friendship , any representations from one who had almost [a mother]242-a mother 's love , and [mother]473-mother 's rights , it would be prevented .

[Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth had no fortune . [He]117-captain wentworth had been lucky in [his]117-captain wentworth profession ; but spending freely , what had come freely , had realized nothing . But [he]117-captain wentworth was confident that [he]117-captain wentworth should soon be rich : full of life and ardour , [he]117-captain wentworth knew that [he]117-captain wentworth should soon have [a ship]474-a ship , and soon be on a station that would lead to everything [he]117-captain wentworth wanted . [He]117-captain wentworth had always been lucky ; [he]117-captain wentworth knew [he]117-captain wentworth should be so still . Such confidence , powerful in its own warmth , and bewitching in the wit which often expressed it , must have been enough for [Anne]93-anne ; but [Lady Russell]101-lady russell saw it very differently . [His]117-captain wentworth sanguine temper , and fearlessness of mind , operated very differently on [her]101-lady russell . [She]101-lady russell saw in it but an aggravation of the evil . It only added a dangerous character to [himself]117-captain wentworth . [He]117-captain wentworth was brilliant , [he]117-captain wentworth was headstrong . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell had little taste for wit , and of anything approaching to imprudence a horror . [She]101-lady russell deprecated the connexion in every light .

Such opposition , as these feelings produced , was more than [Anne]93-anne could combat . Young and gentle as [she]93-anne was , it might yet have been possible to withstand [[her]93-anne father]274-her father 's ill - will , though unsoftened by one kind word or look on the part of [[her]93-anne sister]476-her sister ; but [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , whom [she]93-anne had always loved and relied on , could not , with such steadiness of opinion , and such tenderness of manner , be continually advising [her]93-anne in vain . [She]93-anne was persuaded to believe the engagement a wrong thing : indiscreet , improper , hardly capable of success , and not deserving it . But it was not a merely selfish caution , under which [she]93-anne acted , in putting an end to it . Had [she]93-anne not imagined [herself]93-anne consulting [his]117-captain wentworth good , even more than [her]93-anne own , [she]93-anne could hardly have given [him]117-captain wentworth up . The belief of being prudent , and self - denying , principally for [his]117-captain wentworth advantage , was [her]93-anne chief consolation , under the misery of a parting , a final parting ; and every consolation was required , for [she]93-anne had to encounter all the additional pain of opinions , on [his]117-captain wentworth side , totally unconvinced and unbending , and of [his]117-captain wentworth feeling [himself]117-captain wentworth ill used by so forced a relinquishment . [He]117-captain wentworth had left [the country]287-the country in consequence .

A few months had seen the beginning and the end of [their]478-their acquaintance ; but not with a few months ended [Anne]93-anne 's share of suffering from it . [Her]93-anne attachment and regrets had , for a long time , clouded every enjoyment of youth , and an early loss of bloom and spirits had been their lasting effect .

More than seven years were gone since this little history of sorrowful interest had reached its close ; and time had softened down much , perhaps nearly all of peculiar attachment to [him]117-captain wentworth , but [she]93-anne had been too dependent on time alone ; no aid had been given in change of place ( except in one visit to [Bath]10-bath soon after the rupture ) , or in any novelty or enlargement of society . [No one]479-no one had ever come within the Kellynch circle , who could bear a comparison with [Frederick Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , as [he]117-captain wentworth stood in [her]93-anne memory . No second attachment , the only thoroughly natural , happy , and sufficient cure , at [her]93-anne time of life , had been possible to the nice tone of [her]93-anne mind , the fastidiousness of [her]93-anne taste , in the small limits of the society around [them]478-their . [She]93-anne had been solicited , when about two - and - twenty , to change [her]93-anne name , by [the young man]311-the young man , who not long afterwards found a more willing mind in [[her]93-anne younger sister]481-her younger sister ; and [Lady Russell]101-lady russell had lamented [her]101-lady russell refusal ; for [Charles Musgrove]96-charles was [the eldest son of [a man , whose landed property and general importance were second in [that country]484-that country , only to [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's , and of good character and appearance]483-a man , whose landed property and general importance were second in that country , only to sir walter 's , and of good character and appearance]482-the eldest son of a man , whose landed property and general importance were second in that country , only to sir walter 's , and of good character and appearance ; and however [Lady Russell]101-lady russell might have asked yet for something more , while [Anne]93-anne was nineteen , [she]101-lady russell would have rejoiced to see [her]93-anne at twenty - two so respectably removed from the partialities and injustice of [[[her]93-anne father]274-her father 's house]398-her father 's house , and settled so permanently near [herself]93-anne . But in this case , [Anne]93-anne had left nothing for advice to do ; and though [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , as satisfied as ever with [her]101-lady russell own discretion , never wished the past undone , [she]101-lady russell began now to have the anxiety which borders on hopelessness for [Anne]93-anne 's being tempted , by [some man of talents and independence]487-some man of talents and independence , to enter a state for which [she]101-lady russell held [her]93-anne to be peculiarly fitted by [her]93-anne warm affections and domestic habits .

[They]488-their knew not [each other]489-each other 's opinion , either its constancy or its change , on the one leading point of [Anne]93-anne 's conduct , for the subject was never alluded to ; but [Anne]93-anne , at seven - and - twenty , thought very differently from what [she]93-anne had been made to think at nineteen . [She]93-anne did not blame [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , [she]93-anne did not blame [herself]93-anne for having been guided by [her]101-lady russell ; but [she]93-anne felt that were [any young person]490-any young person , in similar circumstances , to apply to [her]93-anne for counsel , [they]490-any young person would never receive any of such certain immediate wretchedness , such uncertain future good . [She]93-anne was persuaded that under every disadvantage of disapprobation at [home]285-home , and every anxiety attending [his]492-his profession , all [their]488-their probable fears , delays , and disappointments , [she]93-anne should yet have been [a happier woman]493-a happier woman in maintaining the engagement , than [she]93-anne had been in the sacrifice of it ; and this , [she]93-anne fully believed , had the usual share , had even more than the usual share of all such solicitudes and suspense been theirs , without reference to the actual results of [their]488-their case , which , as it happened , would have bestowed earlier prosperity than could be reasonably calculated on . All [his]492-his sanguine expectations , all [his]492-his confidence had been justified . [His]492-his genius and ardour had seemed to foresee and to command [his]492-his prosperous path . [He]492-his had , very soon after [their]488-their engagement ceased , got employ : and all that [he]492-his had told [her]93-anne would follow , had taken place . [He]492-his had distinguished [himself]492-his , and early gained the other step in rank , and must now , by successive captures , have made a handsome fortune . [She]93-anne had only navy lists and newspapers for [her]93-anne authority , but [she]93-anne could not doubt [his]492-his being rich ; and , in favour of [his]492-his constancy , [she]93-anne had no reason to believe [him]492-his married .

How eloquent could [Anne Elliot]93-anne have been ! how eloquent , at least , were [her]93-anne wishes on the side of early warm attachment , and a cheerful confidence in futurity , against that over - anxious caution which seems to insult exertion and distrust [Providence]118-providence ! [She]93-anne had been forced into prudence in [her]93-anne youth , [she]93-anne learned romance as [she]93-anne grew older : the natural sequel of an unnatural beginning .

With all these circumstances , recollections and feelings , [she]93-anne could not hear that [[Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's sister]494-captain wentworth 's sister was likely to live at [Kellynch]6-kellynch without a revival of former pain ; and many a stroll , and many a sigh , were necessary to dispel the agitation of the idea . [She]93-anne often told [herself]93-anne it was folly , before [she]93-anne could harden [her]93-anne nerves sufficiently to feel the continual discussion of [the Crofts]116-the crofts and [their]116-the crofts business no evil . [She]93-anne was assisted , however , by that perfect indifference and apparent unconsciousness , among [the only three of [[her]93-anne own friends]496-her own friends]495-the only three of her own friends in the secret of the past , which seemed almost to deny any recollection of it . [She]93-anne could do justice to the superiority of [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's motives in this , over those of [[her]93-anne father]274-her father and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth ; [she]93-anne could honour all the better feelings of [her]93-anne calmness ; but the general air of oblivion among [them]495-the only three of her own friends was highly important from whatever it sprung ; and in the event of [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft 's really taking [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , [she]93-anne rejoiced anew over the conviction which had always been most grateful to [her]93-anne , of the past being known to [those three only among [her]93-anne connexions]498-those three only among her connexions , by whom no syllable , [she]93-anne believed , would ever be whispered , and in the trust that among [his]111-admiral croft , [the brother only with whom [he]111-admiral croft had been residing]499-the brother only with whom he had been residing , had received any information of [their]500-their short - lived engagement . [That brother]501-that brother had been long removed from [the country]287-the country and being [a sensible man]503-a sensible man , and , moreover , [a single man]504-a single man at the time , [she]93-anne had a fond dependence on [no human creature]505-no human creature 's having heard of it from [him]501-that brother .

[The sister]506-the sister , [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , had then been out of [England]17-england , accompanying [[her]112-mrs croft husband]2315-her husband on [a foreign station]508-a foreign station , and [[her]112-mrs croft own sister]509-her own sister , [Mary]94-mary , had been at [school]380-school while it all occurred ; and never admitted by the pride of some , and the delicacy of [others , to the smallest knowledge of it afterwards]511-others , to the smallest knowledge of it afterwards .

With these supports , [she]93-anne hoped that the acquaintance between [herself]93-anne and [the Crofts]116-the crofts , which , with [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , still resident in [Kellynch]6-kellynch , and [Mary]94-mary fixed only three miles off , must be anticipated , need not involve any particular awkwardness .

Chapter 5
