On the morning appointed for [Admiral]111-admiral croft and [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft 's seeing [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , [Anne]93-anne found it most natural to take [her]93-anne almost daily walk to [[Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's]512-lady russell 's , and keep out of the way till all was over ; when [she]93-anne found it most natural to be sorry that [she]93-anne had missed the opportunity of seeing [them]513-them .

This meeting of [the two parties]514-the two parties proved highly satisfactory , and decided the whole business at once . [Each lady]515-each lady was previously well disposed for an agreement , and saw nothing , therefore , but good manners in the other ; and with regard to [the gentlemen]516-the gentlemen , there was such an hearty good humour , such an open , trusting liberality on [the Admiral]411-the admiral 's side , as could not but influence [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , who had besides been flattered into [his]90-sir walter very best and most polished behaviour by [Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd 's assurances of [his]90-sir walter being known , by report , to [the Admiral]411-the admiral , as a model of good breeding .

[The house]310-the house and [grounds]520-grounds , and furniture , were approved , [the Crofts]116-the crofts were approved , terms , time , every thing , and every body , was right ; and [[Mr Shepherd]103-mr shepherd 's clerks]521-mr shepherd 's clerks were set to work , without there having been a single preliminary difference to modify of all that " This indenture sheweth . "[90-sir walter]

[Sir Walter]90-sir walter , without hesitation , declared [the Admiral]411-the admiral to be [the best - looking sailor [he]90-sir walter had ever met with]523-the best - looking sailor he had ever met with , and went so far as to say , that if [[his]90-sir walter own man]524-his own man might have had the arranging of [his]90-sir walter hair , [he]90-sir walter should not be ashamed of being seen with [him]524-his own man any where ; and [the Admiral]411-the admiral , with sympathetic cordiality , observed to [[his]411-the admiral wife]222-his wife as [they]527-they drove back through [the park]2255-the park , " [I]411-the admiral thought [we]527-they should soon come to a deal , [[my]411-the admiral dear]2319-my dear , in spite of what [they]527-they told [us]527-they at [Taunton]12-taunton . [The Baronet]2342-the baronet will never set [the Thames]18-the thames on fire , but there seems to be no harm in [him]2342-the baronet . "--reciprocal[411-the admiral] compliments , which would have been esteemed about equal .

[The Crofts]116-the crofts were to have possession at [Michaelmas]127-michaelmas ; and as [Sir Walter]90-sir walter proposed removing to [Bath]10-bath in the course of the preceding month , there was no time to be lost in making every dependent arrangement .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell , convinced that [Anne]93-anne would not be allowed to be of any use , or any importance , in the choice of [the house which [they]527-they were going to secure]529-the house which they were going to secure , was very unwilling to have [her]93-anne hurried away so soon , and wanted to make it possible for [her]93-anne to stay behind till [she]101-lady russell might convey [her]93-anne to [Bath]10-bath [herself]93-anne after Christmas ; but having engagements of [her]93-anne own which must take [her]93-anne from [Kellynch]6-kellynch for several weeks , [she]93-anne was unable to give the full invitation [she]93-anne wished , and [Anne]93-anne though dreading the possible heats of September in all the white glare of [Bath]10-bath , and grieving to forego all the influence so sweet and so sad of the autumnal months in [the country]287-the country , did not think that , everything considered , [she]93-anne wished to remain . It would be most right , and most wise , and , therefore must involve least suffering to go with [the others]359-the others .

Something occurred , however , to give [her]93-anne a different duty . [Mary]94-mary , often a little unwell , and always thinking a great deal of [her]94-mary own complaints , and always in the habit of claiming [Anne]93-anne when anything was the matter , was indisposed ; and foreseeing that [she]93-anne should not have a day 's health all the autumn , entreated , or rather required [her]93-anne , for it was hardly entreaty , to come to [Uppercross Cottage]20-uppercross cottage , and bear [her]93-anne company as long as [she]93-anne should want [her]93-anne , instead of going to [Bath]10-bath .

" [I]94-mary can not possibly do without [Anne]93-anne , "[94-mary] was [Mary]94-mary 's reasoning ; and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth 's reply was , " Then [I]91-elizabeth am sure [Anne]93-anne had better stay , for [nobody]2242-nobody will want [her]93-anne in [Bath]10-bath . "[91-elizabeth]

To be claimed as a good , though in an improper style , is at least better than being rejected as no good at all ; and [Anne]93-anne , glad to be thought of some use , glad to have anything marked out as a duty , and certainly not sorry to have the scene of it in [the country]287-the country , and [[her]93-anne own dear country]533-her own dear country , readily agreed to stay .

This invitation of [Mary]94-mary 's removed all [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's difficulties , and it was consequently soon settled that [Anne]93-anne should not go to [Bath]10-bath till [Lady Russell]101-lady russell took [her]93-anne , and that all the intervening time should be divided between [Uppercross Cottage]20-uppercross cottage and [Kellynch Lodge]11-kellynch lodge .

So far all was perfectly right ; but [Lady Russell]101-lady russell was almost startled by the wrong of one part of the Kellynch Hall plan , when it burst on [her]101-lady russell , which was , [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay 's being engaged to go to [Bath]10-bath with [Sir Walter]90-sir walter and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , as [a most important and valuable assistant to the latter in all the business before [her]101-lady russell]534-a most important and valuable assistant to the latter in all the business before her . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell was extremely sorry that such a measure should have been resorted to at all , wondered , grieved , and feared ; and the affront it contained to [Anne]93-anne , in [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay 's being of so much use , while [Anne]93-anne could be of none , was a very sore aggravation .

[Anne]93-anne [herself]93-anne was become hardened to such affronts ; but [she]93-anne felt the imprudence of the arrangement quite as keenly as [Lady Russell]101-lady russell . With a great deal of quiet observation , and a knowledge , which [she]93-anne often wished less , of [[her]93-anne father]274-her father 's character , [she]93-anne was sensible that results the most serious to [[his]274-her father family]221-his family from the intimacy were more than possible . [She]93-anne did not imagine that [[her]93-anne father]274-her father had at present an idea of the kind . [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay had freckles , and a projecting tooth , and a clumsy wrist , which [he]274-her father was continually making severe remarks upon , in [her]105-mrs clay absence ; but [she]105-mrs clay was young , and certainly altogether well - looking , and possessed , in an acute mind and assiduous pleasing manners , infinitely more dangerous attractions than any merely personal might have been . [Anne]93-anne was so impressed by the degree of [their]538-their danger , that [she]93-anne could not excuse [herself]93-anne from trying to make it perceptible to [[her]93-anne sister]476-her sister . [She]93-anne had little hope of success ; but [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , who in the event of such a reverse would be so much more to be pitied than [herself]91-elizabeth , should never , [she]91-elizabeth thought , have reason to reproach [her]91-elizabeth for giving no warning .

[She]91-elizabeth spoke , and seemed only to offend . [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth could not conceive how such an absurd suspicion should occur to [her]91-elizabeth , and indignantly answered for [each party]540-each party 's perfectly knowing [their]538-their situation .

" [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay , "[91-elizabeth] said [she]91-elizabeth , warmly , " never forgets who [she]105-mrs clay is ; and as [I]91-elizabeth am rather better acquainted with [her]105-mrs clay sentiments than [you]2344-you can be , [I]91-elizabeth can assure [you]2344-you , that upon the subject of marriage [they]538-their are particularly nice , and that [she]105-mrs clay reprobates all inequality of condition and rank more strongly than [most people]2345-most people . And as to [[my]91-elizabeth father]2247-my father , [I]91-elizabeth really should not have thought that [he]2247-my father , who has kept [himself]2247-my father single so long for [our]2347-our sakes , need be suspected now . If [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay were [a very beautiful woman]2348-a very beautiful woman , [I]91-elizabeth grant [you]2344-you , it might be wrong to have [her]105-mrs clay so much with [me]91-elizabeth ; not that anything in [the world]237-the world , [I]91-elizabeth am sure , would induce [[my]91-elizabeth father]2247-my father to make a degrading match , but [he]2247-my father might be rendered unhappy . But poor [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay who , with all [her]105-mrs clay merits , can never have been reckoned tolerably pretty , [I]91-elizabeth really think poor [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay may be staying [here]2340-here in perfect safety . [One]252-one would imagine [you]2344-you had never heard [[my]91-elizabeth father]2247-my father speak of [her]105-mrs clay personal misfortunes , though [I]91-elizabeth know [you]2344-you must fifty times . That tooth of [her]105-mrs clay 's and those freckles . Freckles do not disgust [me]91-elizabeth so very much as they do [him]2247-my father . [I]91-elizabeth have known a face not materially disfigured by a few , but [he]2247-my father abominates [them]2354-them . [You]2344-you must have heard [him]2247-my father notice [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay 's freckles . "[91-elizabeth]

" There is hardly any personal defect , "[93-anne] replied [Anne]93-anne , " which an agreeable manner might not gradually reconcile [one]252-one to . "[93-anne]

" [I]91-elizabeth think very differently , "[91-elizabeth] answered [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , shortly ; " an agreeable manner may set off handsome features , but can never alter plain ones . However , at any rate , as [I]91-elizabeth have a great deal more at stake on this point than [anybody else]342-anybody else can have , [I]91-elizabeth think it rather unnecessary in [you]2344-you to be advising [me]91-elizabeth . "[91-elizabeth]

[Anne]93-anne had done ; glad that it was over , and not absolutely hopeless of doing good . [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , though resenting the suspicion , might yet be made observant by it .

The last office of [the four carriage - horses]541-the four carriage - horses was to draw [Sir Walter]90-sir walter , [Miss Elliot]93-anne , and [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay to [Bath]10-bath . [The party]542-the party drove off in very good spirits ; [Sir Walter]90-sir walter prepared with condescending bows for [all [the afflicted tenantry]544-the afflicted tenantry and cottagers who might have had a hint to show [themselves]543-all the afflicted tenantry and cottagers who might have had a hint to show themselves]543-all the afflicted tenantry and cottagers who might have had a hint to show themselves , and [Anne]93-anne walked up at the same time , in a sort of desolate tranquillity , to [the Lodge]545-the lodge , where [she]93-anne was to spend the first week .

[[Her]93-anne friend]546-her friend was not in better spirits than [herself]93-anne . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell felt this break - up of [the family]312-the family exceedingly . [Their]312-the family respectability was as dear to [her]101-lady russell as [her]101-lady russell own , and a daily intercourse had become precious by habit . It was painful to look upon [[their]312-the family deserted grounds]548-their deserted grounds , and still worse to anticipate the new hands [they]312-the family were to fall into ; and to escape the solitariness and the melancholy of so altered [a village]549-a village , and be out of the way when [Admiral]111-admiral croft and [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft first arrived , [she]101-lady russell had determined to make [her]101-lady russell own absence from [home]285-home begin when [she]101-lady russell must give up [Anne]93-anne . Accordingly [their]312-the family removal was made together , and [Anne]93-anne was set down at [Uppercross Cottage]20-uppercross cottage , in the first stage of [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's journey .

[Uppercross]4-uppercross was [a moderate - sized village]551-a moderate - sized village , which a few years back had been completely in the old English style , containing [only [two houses]553-two houses superior in appearance to those of [the yeomen]554-the yeomen and [labourers]555-labourers]552-only two houses superior in appearance to those of the yeomen and labourers ; [the mansion of [the squire]557-the squire , with [its]556-the mansion of the squire , with its high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in its own neat garden high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and [the compact , tight parsonage]558-the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in [its]558-the compact , tight parsonage own neat garden]556-the mansion of the squire , with its high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in its own neat garden , with a vine and a pear - tree trained round [its]558-the compact , tight parsonage casements ; but upon the marriage of [the young ' squire]559-the young ' squire , [it]558-the compact , tight parsonage had received the improvement of [a farm - house]560-a farm - house elevated into [a cottage]561-a cottage , for [[his]557-the squire residence]562-his residence , and [Uppercross Cottage]20-uppercross cottage , with [its]20-uppercross cottage veranda , French windows , and other prettiness , was quite as likely to catch [the traveller]563-the traveller 's eye as the more consistent and considerable aspect and premises of [the Great House]564-the great house , about a quarter of a mile farther on .

Here [Anne]93-anne had often been staying . [She]93-anne knew the ways of [Uppercross]4-uppercross as well as those of [Kellynch]6-kellynch . [The two families]565-the two families were so continually meeting , so much in the habit of running in and out of [each other 's house]566-each other 's house at all hours , that it was rather a surprise to [her]93-anne to find [Mary]94-mary alone ; but being alone , [her]94-mary being unwell and out of spirits was almost a matter of course . Though better endowed than [the elder sister]567-the elder sister , [Mary]94-mary had not [Anne]93-anne 's understanding nor temper . While well , and happy , and properly attended to , [she]94-mary had great good humour and excellent spirits ; but any indisposition sunk [her]94-mary completely . [She]94-mary had no resources for solitude ; and inheriting a considerable share of the Elliot self - importance , was very prone to add to every other distress that of fancying [herself]94-mary neglected and ill - used . In person , [she]94-mary was inferior to [both sisters]568-both sisters , and had , even in [her]94-mary bloom , only reached the dignity of being " [a fine girl]2357-a fine girl . "[94-mary] [She]94-mary was now lying on the faded sofa of [the pretty little drawing - room]569-the pretty little drawing - room , the once elegant furniture of which had been gradually growing shabby , under the influence of four summers and [two children]399-two children ; and , on [Anne]93-anne 's appearing , greeted [her]94-mary with--

" So , [you]94-mary are come at last ! [I]94-mary began to think [I]94-mary should never see [you]94-mary . [I]94-mary am so ill [I]94-mary can hardly speak . [I]94-mary have not seen a creature the whole morning ! "[94-mary]

" [I]93-anne am sorry to find [you]94-mary unwell , "[93-anne] replied [Anne]93-anne . " [You]94-mary sent [me]93-anne such a good account of [yourself]94-mary on Thursday ! "[93-anne]

" Yes , [I]94-mary made the best of it ; [I]94-mary always do : but [I]94-mary was very far from well at the time ; and [I]94-mary do not think [I]94-mary ever was so ill in [my]94-mary life as [I]94-mary have been all this morning : very unfit to be left alone , [I]94-mary am sure . Suppose [I]94-mary were to be seized of a sudden in some dreadful way , and not able to ring the bell ! So , [Lady Russell]101-lady russell would not get out . [I]94-mary do not think [she]101-lady russell has been in [this house]2358-this house three times this summer . "[94-mary]

[Anne]93-anne said what was proper , and enquired after [[her]93-anne husband]2315-her husband . " Oh ! [Charles]96-charles is out shooting . [I]93-anne have not seen [him]2315-her husband since seven o'clock . [He]2315-her husband would go , though [I]93-anne told [him]2315-her husband how ill [I]93-anne was . [He]2315-her husband said [he]2315-her husband should not stay out long ; but [he]2315-her husband has never come back , and now it is almost one . [I]93-anne assure [you]2315-her husband , [I]93-anne have not seen [a soul]2359-a soul this whole long morning . "[93-anne]

" [You]93-anne have had [[your]93-anne little boys]2360-your little boys with [you]93-anne ? "[94-mary]

" Yes , as long as [I]93-anne could bear [their]2360-your little boys noise ; but [they]2360-your little boys are so unmanageable that [they]2360-your little boys do [me]93-anne more harm than good . [Little Charles]119-little charles does not mind a word [I]93-anne say , and [Walter]90-sir walter is growing quite as bad . "[93-anne]

" Well , [you]2315-her husband will soon be better now , "[93-anne] replied [Anne]93-anne , cheerfully . " [You]2315-her husband know [I]93-anne always cure [you]2315-her husband when [I]93-anne come . How are [[your]2315-her husband neighbours]2361-your neighbours at [the Great House]564-the great house ? "[93-anne]

" [I]93-anne can give [you]2315-her husband no account of [them]2361-your neighbours . [I]93-anne have not seen one of [them]2361-your neighbours to - day , except [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove , who just stopped and spoke through the window , but without getting off [his]120-mrs musgrove horse ; and though [I]93-anne told [him]120-mrs musgrove how ill [I]93-anne was , not one of [them]2361-your neighbours have been near [me]93-anne . It did not happen to suit [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , [I]93-anne suppose , and [they]2361-your neighbours never put [themselves]2361-your neighbours out of [their]2361-your neighbours way . "[93-anne]

" [You]2315-her husband will see [them]2361-your neighbours yet , perhaps , before the morning is gone . It is early . "[93-anne]

" [I]93-anne never want [them]2361-your neighbours , [I]93-anne assure [you]2315-her husband . [They]2361-your neighbours talk and laugh a great deal too much for [me]93-anne . Oh ! [Anne]93-anne , [I]93-anne am so very unwell ! It was quite unkind of [you]2315-her husband not to come on Thursday . "[93-anne]

" [[My]93-anne dear]2319-my dear [Mary]94-mary , recollect what a comfortable account [you]2315-her husband sent [me]93-anne of [yourself]2315-her husband ! [You]2315-her husband wrote in the cheerfullest manner , and said [you]2315-her husband were perfectly well , and in no hurry for [me]93-anne ; and that being the case , [you]2315-her husband must be aware that [my]93-anne wish would be to remain with [Lady Russell]101-lady russell to the last : and besides what [I]93-anne felt on [her]101-lady russell account , [I]93-anne have really been so busy , have had so much to do , that [I]93-anne could not very conveniently have left [Kellynch]6-kellynch sooner . "[93-anne]

" Dear [me]93-anne ! what can [you]93-anne possibly have to do ? "[93-anne]

" A great many things , [I]93-anne assure [you]2315-her husband . More than [I]93-anne can recollect in a moment ; but [I]93-anne can tell [you]2315-her husband some . [I]93-anne have been making a duplicate of the catalogue of [[my]93-anne father]2247-my father 's books and pictures . [I]93-anne have been several times in [the garden]2365-the garden with [Mackenzie]122-mackenzie , trying to understand , and make [him]122-mackenzie understand , which of [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth 's plants are for [Lady Russell]101-lady russell . [I]93-anne have had all [my]93-anne own little concerns to arrange , books and music to divide , and all [my]93-anne trunks to repack , from not having understood in time what was intended as to the waggons : and one thing [I]93-anne have had to do , [Mary]94-mary , of a more trying nature : going to [almost every house in [the parish]2367-the parish]2366-almost every house in the parish , as a sort of take - leave . [I]93-anne was told that [they]2366-almost every house in the parish wished it . But all these things took up a great deal of time . "[93-anne]

" Oh ! well ! "[93-anne] and after a moment 's pause , " but [you]94-mary have never asked [me]93-anne one word about [our]2368-our dinner at [the Pooles]21-the pooles yesterday . "[93-anne]

" Did [you]94-mary go then ? [I]93-anne have made no enquiries , because [I]93-anne concluded [you]94-mary must have been obliged to give up the party . "[93-anne]

" Oh yes ! [I]93-anne went . [I]93-anne was very well yesterday ; nothing at all the matter with [me]93-anne till this morning . It would have been strange if [I]93-anne had not gone . "[93-anne]

" [I]93-anne am very glad [you]94-mary were well enough , and [I]93-anne hope [you]94-mary had a pleasant party . "[93-anne]

" Nothing remarkable . [One]252-one always knows beforehand what the dinner will be , and who will be [there]377-there ; and it is so very uncomfortable not having [a carriage]2371-a carriage of [one]252-one 's own . [Mr]2373-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove took [me]93-anne , and [we]2374-we were so crowded ! [They]2374-we are both so very large , and take up so much room ; and [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove always sits forward . So , there was [I]93-anne , crowded into the back seat with [Henrietta]123-henrietta and [Louisa]124-louisa ; and [I]93-anne think it very likely that [my]93-anne illness to - day may be owing to it . "[93-anne]

A little further perseverance in patience and forced cheerfulness on [Anne]93-anne 's side produced nearly a cure on [Mary]94-mary 's . [She]93-anne could soon sit upright on the sofa , and began to hope [she]93-anne might be able to leave it by dinner - time . Then , forgetting to think of it , [she]93-anne was at the other end of [the room]406-the room , beautifying a nosegay ; then , [she]93-anne ate [her]93-anne cold meat ; and then [she]93-anne was well enough to propose a little walk .

" Where shall [we]573-they go ? "[93-anne] said [she]93-anne , when [they]573-they were ready . " [I]93-anne suppose [you]2375-you will not like to call at [the Great House]564-the great house before [they]573-they have been to see [you]2375-you ? "[93-anne]

" [I]93-anne have not the smallest objection on that account , "[93-anne] replied [Anne]93-anne . " [I]93-anne should never think of standing on such ceremony with [people]2377-people [I]93-anne know so well as [Mrs]2378-mrs and [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves . "[93-anne]

" Oh ! but [they]573-they ought to call upon [you]93-anne as soon as possible . [They]573-they ought to feel what is due to [you]93-anne as [[my]93-anne sister]2379-my sister . However , [we]577-their may as well go and sit with [them]573-they a little while , and when [we]577-their have that over , [we]577-their can enjoy [our]577-their walk . "[93-anne]

[Anne]93-anne had always thought such a style of intercourse highly imprudent ; but [she]93-anne had ceased to endeavour to check it , from believing that , though there were on each side [continual subjects of offence]574-continual subjects of offence , [neither family]575-neither family could now do without it . To [the Great House]564-the great house accordingly [they]577-their went , to sit the full half hour in [the old - fashioned square parlour , with a small carpet and shining floor , to which [the present daughters of the house]579-the present daughters of the house]578-the old - fashioned square parlour , with a small carpet and shining floor , to which the present daughters of the house were gradually giving the proper air of confusion by a grand piano - forte and a harp , flower - stands and little tables placed in every direction . Oh ! could the originals of the portraits against the wainscot , could [the gentlemen in brown velvet]580-the gentlemen in brown velvet and [the ladies in blue satin]581-the ladies in blue satin have seen what was going on , have been conscious of such an overthrow of all order and neatness ! The portraits [themselves]577-their seemed to be staring in astonishment .

[The Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , like [[their]577-their houses]582-their houses , were in a state of alteration , perhaps of improvement . [The father]583-the father and [mother]473-mother were in the old English style , and [the young people]585-the young people in the new . [Mr]586-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove were [a very good sort of people]587-a very good sort of people ; friendly and hospitable , not much educated , and not at all elegant . [[Their]577-their children]588-their children had more modern minds and manners . There was [a numerous family]589-a numerous family ; but [the only two grown up]590-the only two grown up , excepting [Charles]119-little charles , were [Henrietta]123-henrietta and [Louisa]124-louisa , [young ladies of nineteen and twenty]591-young ladies of nineteen and twenty , who had brought from school at [Exeter]22-exeter all the usual stock of accomplishments , and were now like thousands of [other young ladies , living to be fashionable , happy , and merry]592-other young ladies , living to be fashionable , happy , and merry . [Their]577-their dress had every advantage , [their]577-their faces were rather pretty , [their]577-their spirits extremely good , [their]577-their manner unembarrassed and pleasant ; [they]577-their were of consequence at [home]285-home , and favourites abroad . [Anne]93-anne always contemplated [them]577-their as [some of the happiest creatures of [her]93-anne acquaintance]594-some of the happiest creatures of her acquaintance ; but still , saved as [we]595-we all are , by some comfortable feeling of superiority from wishing for the possibility of exchange , [she]93-anne would not have given up [her]93-anne own more elegant and cultivated mind for all [their]577-their enjoyments ; and envied [them]577-their nothing but that seemingly perfect good understanding and agreement together , that good - humoured mutual affection , of which [she]93-anne had known so little [herself]93-anne with either of [[her]93-anne sisters]356-her sisters .

[They]577-their were received with great cordiality . Nothing seemed amiss on the side of [the Great House family]597-the great house family , which was generally , as [Anne]93-anne very well knew , the least to blame . The half hour was chatted away pleasantly enough ; and [she]93-anne was not at all surprised , at the end of it , to have [their]577-their walking party joined by both [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , at [Mary]94-mary 's particular invitation .

Chapter 6

[Anne]93-anne had not wanted this visit to [Uppercross]4-uppercross , to learn that a removal from one set of [people]2377-people to another , though at a distance of only three miles , will often include a total change of conversation , opinion , and idea . [She]93-anne had never been staying [there]377-there before , without being struck by it , or without wishing that [other Elliots]600-other elliots could have [her]93-anne advantage in seeing how unknown , or unconsidered there , were the affairs which at [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall were treated as of such general publicity and pervading interest ; yet , with all this experience , [she]93-anne believed [she]93-anne must now submit to feel that another lesson , in the art of knowing [our]601-we own nothingness beyond [our]601-we own circle , was become necessary for [her]93-anne ; for certainly , coming as [she]93-anne did , with a heart full of the subject which had been completely occupying [both houses]602-both houses in [Kellynch]6-kellynch for many weeks , [she]93-anne had expected rather more curiosity and sympathy than [she]93-anne found in the separate but very similar remark of [Mr and Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove : " So , [Miss Anne]93-anne , [Sir Walter]90-sir walter and [[your]93-anne sister]2380-your sister are gone ; and what part of [Bath]372-bath do [you]93-anne think [they]603-the young ladies will settle in ? "[120-mrs musgrove] and this , without much waiting for an answer ; or in [the young ladies]603-the young ladies ' addition of , " [I]603-the young ladies hope [we]601-we shall be in [Bath]10-bath in the winter ; but remember , [papa]2382-papa , if [we]601-we do go , [we]601-we must be in a good situation : none of [[your]2382-papa Queen]2383-your queen Squares for [us]601-we ! "[603-the young ladies] or in the anxious supplement from [Mary]94-mary , of--"Upon [my]603-the young ladies word , [I]603-the young ladies shall be pretty well off , when [you]2382-papa are all gone away to be happy at [Bath]10-bath ! "[603-the young ladies]

[She]94-mary could only resolve to avoid such self - delusion in future , and think with heightened gratitude of the extraordinary blessing of having [one such truly sympathising friend]604-one such truly sympathising friend as [Lady Russell]101-lady russell .

[The Mr Musgroves]125-the mr musgroves had [their]125-the mr musgroves own game to guard , and to destroy , [their]125-the mr musgroves own horses , dogs , and newspapers to engage [them]125-the mr musgroves , and [the females]605-the females were fully occupied in all the other common subjects of housekeeping , [neighbours]250-neighbours , dress , dancing , and music . [She]94-mary acknowledged it to be very fitting , that every little social commonwealth should dictate its own matters of discourse ; and hoped , ere long , to become [a not unworthy member of the one [she]94-mary was now transplanted into]607-a not unworthy member of the one she was now transplanted into . With the prospect of spending at least two months at [Uppercross]4-uppercross , it was highly incumbent on [her]94-mary to clothe [her]94-mary imagination , [her]94-mary memory , and all [her]94-mary ideas in as much of [Uppercross]4-uppercross as possible .

[She]94-mary had no dread of these two months . [Mary]94-mary was not so repulsive and unsisterly as [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , nor so inaccessible to all influence of [hers]94-mary ; neither was there anything among the other component parts of [the cottage]608-the cottage inimical to comfort . [She]94-mary was always on friendly terms with [[her]94-mary brother - in - law]609-her brother - in - law ; and in [the children]610-the children , who loved [her]94-mary nearly as well , and respected [her]94-mary a great deal more than [[their]610-the children mother]611-their mother , [she]94-mary had an object of interest , amusement , and wholesome exertion .

[Charles Musgrove]96-charles was civil and agreeable ; in sense and temper [he]612-his was undoubtedly superior to [[his]612-his wife]222-his wife , but not of powers , or conversation , or grace , to make the past , as [they]614-they were connected together , at all a dangerous contemplation ; though , at the same time , [Anne]93-anne could believe , with [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , that a more equal match might have greatly improved [him]612-his ; and that [a woman of real understanding]615-a woman of real understanding might have given more consequence to [his]612-his character , and more usefulness , rationality , and elegance to [his]612-his habits and pursuits . As it was , [he]612-his did nothing with much zeal , but sport ; and [his]612-his time was otherwise trifled away , without benefit from books or anything else . [He]612-his had very good spirits , which never seemed much affected by [[his]612-his wife]222-his wife 's occasional lowness , bore with [her]222-his wife unreasonableness sometimes to [Anne]93-anne 's admiration , and upon the whole , though there was very often a little disagreement ( in which [she]222-his wife had sometimes more share than [she]222-his wife wished , being appealed to by [both parties]617-both parties ) , [they]614-they might pass for [a happy couple]618-a happy couple . [They]614-they were always perfectly agreed in the want of more money , and a strong inclination for a handsome present from [[his]612-his father]2282-his father ; but here , as on most topics , [he]612-his had the superiority , for while [Mary]94-mary thought it a great shame that such a present was not made , [he]612-his always contended for [[his]612-his father]2282-his father 's having many other uses for [his]612-his money , and a right to spend it as [he]612-his liked .

As to the management of [[their]614-they children]588-their children , [his]612-his theory was much better than [[his]612-his wife]222-his wife 's , and [his]612-his practice not so bad . " [I]612-his could manage them very well , if it were not for [Mary]94-mary 's interference , "[612-his] was what [Anne]93-anne often heard [him]612-his say , and had a good deal of faith in ; but when listening in turn to [Mary]94-mary 's reproach of " [Charles]96-charles spoils [the children]610-the children so that [I]93-anne can not get [them]610-the children into any order , "[93-anne] [she]93-anne never had the smallest temptation to say , " Very true . "[93-anne]

One of the least agreeable circumstances of [her]93-anne residence there was [her]93-anne being treated with too much confidence by [all parties]623-all parties , and being too much in the secret of the complaints of [each house]624-each house . Known to have some influence with [[her]93-anne sister]476-her sister , [she]93-anne was continually requested , or at least receiving hints to exert it , beyond what was practicable . " [I]96-charles wish [you]93-anne could persuade [Mary]94-mary not to be always fancying [herself]94-mary ill , "[96-charles] was [Charles]96-charles 's language ; and , in an unhappy mood , thus spoke [Mary]94-mary : " [I]94-mary do believe if [Charles]96-charles were to see [me]94-mary dying , [he]2385-he would not think there was anything the matter with [me]94-mary . [I]94-mary am sure , [Anne]93-anne , if [you]93-anne would , [you]93-anne might persuade [him]2385-he that [I]94-mary really am very ill -- a great deal worse than [I]94-mary ever own . "[94-mary]

[Mary]94-mary 's declaration was , " [I]94-mary hate sending [the children]610-the children to [the Great House]564-the great house , though [[their]610-the children grandmamma]2388-their grandmamma is always wanting to see [them]610-the children , for [she]2388-their grandmamma humours and indulges [them]610-the children to such a degree , and gives [them]610-the children so much trash and sweet things , that [they]610-the children are sure to come back sick and cross for the rest of the day . "[94-mary] And [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles took the first opportunity of being alone with [Anne]93-anne , to say , " Oh ! [Miss Anne]93-anne , [I]96-charles can not help wishing [Mrs Charles]96-charles had a little of [your]93-anne method with [those children]2389-those children . [They]2389-those children are quite different creatures with [you]93-anne ! But to be sure , in general [they]2389-those children are so spoilt ! It is a pity [you]93-anne can not put [[your]93-anne sister]2380-your sister in the way of managing [them]2389-those children . [They]2389-those children are [as fine healthy children as ever]2391-as fine healthy children as ever were seen , [poor little dears]2392-poor little dears ! without partiality ; but [Mrs Charles]96-charles knows no more how [they]2389-those children should be treated-- ! Bless [me]96-charles ! how troublesome [they]2389-those children are sometimes . [I]96-charles assure [you]93-anne , [Miss Anne]93-anne , it prevents [my]96-charles wishing to see [them]2389-those children at [[our]2393-our house]2394-our house so often as [I]96-charles otherwise should . [I]96-charles believe [Mrs Charles]96-charles is not quite pleased with [my]96-charles not inviting [them]2389-those children oftener ; but [you]93-anne know it is very bad to have [children]433-children with one that [one]252-one is obligated to be checking every moment ; "[96-charles] do n't do this , " and "[94-mary] do n't do that ; " or that [one]252-one can only keep in tolerable order by more cake than is good for [them]2389-those children . "[94-mary]

[She]626-she had this communication , moreover , from [Mary]94-mary . " [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles thinks all [[her]96-charles servants]2398-her servants so steady , that it would be high treason to call it in question ; but [I]94-mary am sure , without exaggeration , that [[her]96-charles upper house - maid]2399-her upper house - maid and [laundry - maid]2400-laundry - maid , instead of being in [their]2398-her servants business , are gadding about [the village]2401-the village , all day long . [I]94-mary meet [them]2389-those children wherever [I]94-mary go ; and [I]94-mary declare , [I]94-mary never go twice into [[my]94-mary nursery]2402-my nursery without seeing something of [them]2389-those children . If [Jemima]126-jemima were not [the trustiest , steadiest creature in [the world]237-the world]2403-the trustiest , steadiest creature in the world , it would be enough to spoil [her]126-jemima ; for [she]126-jemima tells [me]94-mary , [they]2389-those children are always tempting [her]126-jemima to take a walk with [them]2389-those children . "[94-mary] And on [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles 's side , it was , " [I]94-mary make a rule of never interfering in any of [[my]94-mary daughter - in - law]2405-my daughter - in - law 's concerns , for [I]94-mary know it would not do ; but [I]94-mary shall tell [you]2406-you , [Miss Anne]93-anne , because [you]2406-you may be able to set things to rights , that [I]94-mary have no very good opinion of [[Mrs Charles]96-charles 's nursery - maid]2407-mrs charles 's nursery - maid : [I]94-mary hear strange stories of [her]2407-mrs charles 's nursery - maid ; [she]2407-mrs charles 's nursery - maid is always upon the gad ; and from [my]94-mary own knowledge , [I]94-mary can declare , [she]2407-mrs charles 's nursery - maid is [such a fine - dressing lady , that [she]2407-mrs charles 's nursery - maid is enough to ruin [any servants [she]2407-mrs charles 's nursery - maid comes near]2409-any servants she comes near]2408-such a fine - dressing lady , that she is enough to ruin any servants she comes near . [Mrs Charles]96-charles quite swears by [her]2407-mrs charles 's nursery - maid , [I]94-mary know ; but [I]94-mary just give [you]2410-you this hint , that [you]2410-you may be upon the watch ; because , if [you]2410-you see anything amiss , [you]2410-you need not be afraid of mentioning it . "[94-mary]

Again , it was [Mary]94-mary 's complaint , that [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles was very apt not to give [her]94-mary the precedence that was [her]94-mary due , when [they]627-i dined at [the Great House]564-the great house with [other families]629-other families ; and [she]94-mary did not see any reason why [she]94-mary was to be considered so much at [home]285-home as to lose [her]94-mary place . And one day when [Anne]93-anne was walking with only [the Musgroves]125-the mr musgroves , one of [them]627-i after talking of rank , [people of rank , and jealousy of rank]631-people of rank , and jealousy of rank , said , " [I]627-i have no scruple of observing to [you]2410-you , how nonsensical [some persons]2411-some persons are about [their]2411-some persons place , because all [the world]237-the world knows how easy and indifferent [you]2410-you are about it ; but [I]627-i wish [anybody]2413-anybody could give [Mary]94-mary a hint that it would be a great deal better if [she]94-mary were not so very tenacious , especially if [she]94-mary would not be always putting [herself]94-mary forward to take place of [mamma]2414-mamma . [Nobody]2242-nobody doubts [her]94-mary right to have precedence of [mamma]2414-mamma , but it would be more becoming in [her]94-mary not to be always insisting on it . It is not that [mamma]2417-mamma cares about it the least in [the world]237-the world , but [I]627-i know it is taken notice of by [many persons]2419-many persons . "[627-i]

How was [Anne]93-anne to set all these matters to rights ? [She]93-anne could do little more than listen patiently , soften every grievance , and excuse each to [the other]254-the other ; give [them]633-their all hints of the forbearance necessary between [such near neighbours]634-such near neighbours , and make those hints broadest which were meant for [[her]93-anne sister]476-her sister 's benefit .

In all other respects , [her]93-anne visit began and proceeded very well . [Her]93-anne own spirits improved by change of place and subject , by being removed three miles from [Kellynch]6-kellynch ; [Mary]94-mary 's ailments lessened by having [a constant companion]636-a constant companion , and [their]633-their daily intercourse with [the other family]637-the other family , since there was neither superior affection , confidence , nor employment in [the cottage]608-the cottage , to be interrupted by it , was rather an advantage . It was certainly carried nearly as far as possible , for [they]633-their met every morning , and hardly ever spent an evening asunder ; but [she]93-anne believed [they]633-their should not have done so well without the sight of [Mr]639-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles 's respectable forms in the usual places , or without the talking , laughing , and singing of [[their]633-their daughters]640-their daughters .

[She]93-anne played a great deal better than either of [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , but having no voice , no knowledge of the harp , and [no fond parents]641-no fond parents , to sit by and fancy [themselves]633-their delighted , [her]93-anne performance was little thought of , only out of civility , or to refresh [the others]359-the others , as [she]93-anne was well aware . [She]93-anne knew that when [she]93-anne played [she]93-anne was giving pleasure only to [herself]93-anne ; but this was no new sensation . Excepting one short period of [her]93-anne life , [she]93-anne had never , since the age of fourteen , never since the loss of [[her]93-anne dear mother]643-her dear mother , known the happiness of being listened to , or encouraged by any just appreciation or real taste . In music [she]93-anne had been always used to feel alone in [the world]237-the world ; and [Mr]645-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles 's fond partiality for [[their]633-their own daughters]646-their own daughters ' performance , and total indifference to [any other person]647-any other person 's , gave [her]93-anne much more pleasure for [their]633-their sakes , than mortification for [her]93-anne own .

The party at [the Great House]564-the great house was sometimes increased by [other company]649-other company . [The neighbourhood]281-the neighbourhood was not large , but [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves were visited by [everybody]651-everybody , and had more dinner - parties , and [more callers]652-more callers , [more visitors]653-more visitors by invitation and by chance , than [any other family]654-any other family . [They]633-their were more completely popular .

[The girls]655-the girls were wild for dancing ; and the evenings ended , occasionally , in an unpremeditated little ball . There was [a family of cousins within a walk of [Uppercross]4-uppercross]656-a family of cousins within a walk of uppercross , in less affluent circumstances , who depended on [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves for all [their]656-a family of cousins within a walk of uppercross pleasures : [they]656-a family of cousins within a walk of uppercross would come at any time , and help play at anything , or dance anywhere ; and [Anne]93-anne , very much preferring the office of [musician]657-musician to [a more active post]658-a more active post , played country dances to [them]656-a family of cousins within a walk of uppercross by the hour together ; a kindness which always recommended [her]93-anne musical powers to the notice of Mr and [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles more than anything else , and often drew this compliment;--"Well done , [Miss Anne]93-anne ! very well done indeed ! [Lord]2420-lord bless [me]93-anne ! how those little fingers of yours fly about ! "[93-anne]

So passed the first three weeks . [Michaelmas]127-michaelmas came ; and now [Anne]93-anne 's heart must be in [Kellynch]6-kellynch again . [A beloved home]659-a beloved home made over to [others]391-others ; all the precious rooms and furniture , groves , and prospects , beginning to own other eyes and other limbs ! [She]93-anne could not think of much else on the 29th of September ; and [she]93-anne had this sympathetic touch in the evening from [Mary]94-mary , who , [on having occasion to note down the day of the month]661-on having occasion to note down the day of the month , exclaimed , " Dear [me]94-mary , is not this the day [the Crofts]2421-the crofts were to come to [Kellynch]6-kellynch ? [I]94-mary am glad [I]94-mary did not think of it before . How low it makes [me]94-mary ! "[94-mary]

[The Crofts]116-the crofts took possession with true naval alertness , and were to be visited . [Mary]94-mary deplored the necessity for [herself]94-mary . " [Nobody]2242-nobody knew how much [she]93-anne should suffer . [She]93-anne should put it off as long as [she]93-anne could ; "[94-mary] but was not easy till [she]93-anne had talked [Charles]96-charles into driving [her]93-anne over on an early day , and was in a very animated , comfortable state of imaginary agitation , when [she]93-anne came back . [Anne]93-anne had very sincerely rejoiced in there being no means of [her]93-anne going . [She]93-anne wished , however to see [the Crofts]116-the crofts , and was glad to be within when the visit was returned . [They]116-the crofts came : [the master of [the house]310-the house]662-the master of the house was not at [home]285-home , but [the two sisters]665-the two sisters were together ; and as it chanced that [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft fell to the share of [Anne]93-anne , while [the Admiral]411-the admiral sat by [Mary]94-mary , and made [himself]411-the admiral very agreeable by [his]411-the admiral good - humoured notice of [[her]94-mary little boys]667-her little boys , [she]94-mary was well able to watch for a likeness , and if it failed [her]94-mary in the features , to catch it in the voice , or in the turn of sentiment and expression .

[Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , though neither tall nor fat , had a squareness , uprightness , and vigour of form , which gave importance to [her]112-mrs croft person . [She]112-mrs croft had bright dark eyes , good teeth , and altogether an agreeable face ; though [her]112-mrs croft reddened and weather - beaten complexion , the consequence of [her]112-mrs croft having been almost as much at [sea]668-sea as [[her]112-mrs croft husband]2315-her husband , made [her]112-mrs croft seem to have lived some years longer in [the world]237-the world than [her]112-mrs croft real eight - and - thirty . [Her]112-mrs croft manners were open , easy , and decided , like one who had no distrust of [herself]112-mrs croft , and no doubts of what to do ; without any approach to coarseness , however , or any want of good humour . [Anne]93-anne gave [her]93-anne credit , indeed , for feelings of great consideration towards [herself]93-anne , in all that related to [Kellynch]6-kellynch , and it pleased [her]93-anne : especially , as [she]93-anne had satisfied [herself]93-anne in the very first half minute , in the instant even of introduction , that there was not the smallest symptom of any knowledge or suspicion on [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft 's side , to give a bias of any sort . [She]93-anne was quite easy on that head , and consequently full of strength and courage , till for a moment electrified by [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft 's suddenly saying,--

" It was [you]93-anne , and not [[your]93-anne sister]2380-your sister , [I]93-anne find , that [[my]93-anne brother]2424-my brother had the pleasure of being acquainted with , when [he]2424-my brother was in [this country]2314-this country . "[93-anne]

[Anne]93-anne hoped [she]93-anne had outlived the age of blushing ; but the age of emotion [she]93-anne certainly had not .

" Perhaps [you]93-anne may not have heard that [he]2424-my brother is married ? "[112-mrs croft] added [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft .

[She]93-anne could now answer as [she]93-anne ought ; and was happy to feel , when [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft 's next words explained it to be [Mr Wentworth]115-mr wentworth of whom [she]93-anne spoke , that [she]93-anne had said nothing which might not do for [either brother]671-either brother . [She]93-anne immediately felt how reasonable it was , that [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft should be thinking and speaking of [Edward]128-edward , and not of [Frederick]117-captain wentworth ; and with shame at [her]93-anne own forgetfulness applied [herself]93-anne to the knowledge of [[their]672-their former neighbour]673-their former neighbour 's present state with proper interest .

The rest was all tranquillity ; till , just as [they]672-their were moving , [she]93-anne heard [the Admiral]411-the admiral say to [Mary--]129-mary--

" [We]672-their are expecting [a brother of [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft 's here]2426-a brother of mrs croft 's here soon ; [I]411-the admiral dare say [you]129-mary-- know [him]2426-a brother of mrs croft 's here by name . "[411-the admiral]

[He]411-the admiral was cut short by the eager attacks of [the little boys]675-the little boys , clinging to [him]411-the admiral like [an old friend]676-an old friend , and declaring [he]411-the admiral should not go ; and being too much engrossed by proposals of carrying [them]675-the little boys away in [his]411-the admiral coat pockets , & c. , to have another moment for finishing or recollecting what [he]411-the admiral had begun , [Anne]93-anne was left to persuade [herself]93-anne , as well as [she]93-anne could , that [the same brother]677-the same brother must still be in question . [She]93-anne could not , however , reach such a degree of certainty , as not to be anxious to hear whether anything had been said on the subject at [the other house]678-the other house , where [the Crofts]116-the crofts had previously been calling .

[The folks of [the Great House]564-the great house]679-the folks of the great house were to spend the evening of this day at [the Cottage]608-the cottage ; and it being now too late in the year for such visits to be made on foot , [the coach]682-the coach was beginning to be listened for , when [the youngest Miss Musgrove]124-louisa walked in . That [she]124-louisa was coming to apologize , and that [they]679-the folks of the great house should have to spend the evening by [themselves]679-the folks of the great house , was the first black idea ; and [Mary]94-mary was quite ready to be affronted , when [Louisa]124-louisa made all right by saying , that [she]124-louisa only came on foot , to leave more room for the harp , which was bringing in [the carriage]683-the carriage .

" And [I]124-louisa will tell [you]2427-you [our]679-the folks of the great house reason , "[124-louisa] [she]124-louisa added , " and all about it . [I]124-louisa am come on to give [you]2427-you notice , that [papa]2382-papa and [mamma]2414-mamma are out of spirits this evening , especially [mamma]2414-mamma ; [she]2414-mamma is thinking so much of poor [Richard]117-captain wentworth ! And [we]679-the folks of the great house agreed it would be best to have the harp , for it seems to amuse [her]2414-mamma more than the piano - forte . [I]124-louisa will tell [you]2427-you why [she]2414-mamma is out of spirits . When [the Crofts]116-the crofts called this morning , ( [they]116-the crofts called here afterwards , did not [they]116-the crofts ? ) , [they]116-the crofts happened to say , that [[her]2414-mamma brother]2431-her brother , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , is just returned to [England]17-england , or paid off , or something , and is coming to see [them]116-the crofts almost directly ; and most unluckily it came into [mamma]2432-mamma 's head , when [they]116-the crofts were gone , that [Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , or something very like it , was the name of [poor [Richard]117-captain wentworth 's captain]2433-poor richard 's captain at one time ; [I]124-louisa do not know when or where , but a great while before [he]2433-poor richard 's captain died , [poor fellow]2434-poor fellow ! And upon looking over [his]2433-poor richard 's captain letters and things , [she]2414-mamma found it was so , and is perfectly sure that this must be [the very man]2329-the very man , and [her]2414-mamma head is quite full of it , and of poor [Richard]117-captain wentworth ! So [we]2436-we must be as merry as [we]2436-we can , that [she]2414-mamma may not be dwelling upon such gloomy things . "[124-louisa]

The real circumstances of this pathetic piece of family history were , that [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves had had the ill fortune of [a very troublesome , hopeless son]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son ; and the good fortune to lose [him]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son before [he]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son reached [his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son twentieth year ; that [he]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son had been sent to [sea]668-sea because [he]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son was stupid and unmanageable on [shore]686-shore ; that [he]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son had been very little cared for at any time by [[his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son family]221-his family , though quite as much as [he]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son deserved ; seldom heard of , and scarcely at all regretted , when the intelligence of [his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son death abroad had worked its way to [Uppercross]4-uppercross , two years before .

[He]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son had , in fact , though [[his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son sisters]688-his sisters were now doing all [they]688-his sisters could for [him]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son , by calling [him]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son " poor [Richard]117-captain wentworth , "[688-his sisters] been nothing better than [a thick - headed , unfeeling , unprofitable [Dick Musgrove]130-dick , who had never done anything to entitle [himself]130-dick to more than the abbreviation of [his]130-dick name , living or dead]130-dick .

[He]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son had been several years at [sea]668-sea , and had , in the course of those removals to which [all midshipmen]690-all midshipmen are liable , and especially such midshipmen as [every captain]691-every captain wishes to get rid of , been six months on board [[Captain Frederick Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's frigate]692-captain frederick wentworth 's frigate , [the Laconia]23-the laconia ; and from [the Laconia]23-the laconia [he]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son had , under the influence of [[his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son captain]693-his captain , written the only two letters which [[his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son father]2282-his father and [mother]473-mother had ever received from [him]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son during the whole of [his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son absence ; that is to say , the only two disinterested letters ; all the rest had been mere applications for money .

In each letter [he]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son had spoken well of [[his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son captain]693-his captain ; but yet , so little were [they]697-they in the habit of attending to such matters , so unobservant and incurious were [they]697-they as to the names of [men]2274-men or [ships]699-ships , that it had made scarcely any impression at the time ; and that [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles should have been suddenly struck , this very day , with a recollection of the name of [Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , as connected with [[her]96-charles son]700-her son , seemed one of those extraordinary bursts of mind which do sometimes occur .

[She]96-charles had gone to [her]96-charles letters , and found it all as [she]96-charles supposed ; and the re - perusal of these letters , after so long an interval , [[her]96-charles poor son]701-her poor son gone for ever , and all the strength of [his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son faults forgotten , had affected [her]96-charles spirits exceedingly , and thrown [her]96-charles into greater grief for [him]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son than [she]96-charles had known on first hearing of [his]684-a very troublesome , hopeless son death . [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove was , in a lesser degree , affected likewise ; and when [they]697-they reached [the cottage]608-the cottage , [they]697-they were evidently in want , first , of being listened to anew on this subject , and afterwards , of all the relief which [cheerful companions]703-cheerful companions could give [them]697-they .

To hear [them]697-they talking so much of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , repeating [his]117-captain wentworth name so often , puzzling over past years , and at last ascertaining that it might , that it probably would , turn out to be [the very same Captain Wentworth whom [they]697-they recollected meeting , once or twice , after [their]697-they coming back from [Clifton]24-clifton]131-captain wentworth -- [a very fine young man]704-a very fine young man -- but [they]697-they could not say whether it was seven or eight years ago , was a new sort of trial to [Anne]93-anne 's nerves . [She]96-charles found , however , that it was one to which [she]96-charles must inure [herself]96-charles . Since [he]117-captain wentworth actually was expected in [the country]287-the country , [she]96-charles must teach [herself]96-charles to be insensible on such points . And not only did it appear that [he]117-captain wentworth was expected , and speedily , but [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , in [their]697-they warm gratitude for the kindness [he]117-captain wentworth had shewn poor [Dick]130-dick , and very high respect for [his]117-captain wentworth character , stamped as it was by [poor Dick]130-dick 's having been six months under [his]117-captain wentworth care , and mentioning [him]117-captain wentworth in strong , though not perfectly well - spelt praise , as " [a fine dashing felow]2437-a fine dashing felow , only two perticular about [the schoolmaster]2438-the schoolmaster , "[697-they] were bent on introducing [themselves]697-they , and seeking [his]117-captain wentworth acquaintance , as soon as [they]697-they could hear of [his]117-captain wentworth arrival .

The resolution of doing so helped to form the comfort of [their]697-they evening .

Chapter 7

A very few days more , and [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth was known to be at [Kellynch]6-kellynch , and [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove had called on [him]117-captain wentworth , and come back warm in [his]117-captain wentworth praise , and [he]117-captain wentworth was engaged with [the Crofts]116-the crofts to dine at [Uppercross]4-uppercross , by the end of another week . It had been a great disappointment to [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove to find that no earlier day could be fixed , so impatient was [he]120-mrs musgrove to shew [his]120-mrs musgrove gratitude , by seeing [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth under [his]117-captain wentworth own roof , and welcoming [him]117-captain wentworth to all that was strongest and best in [[his]117-captain wentworth cellars]706-his cellars . But a week must pass ; only a week , in [Anne]93-anne 's reckoning , and then , [she]93-anne supposed , [they]697-they must meet ; and soon [she]93-anne began to wish that [she]93-anne could feel secure even for a week .

[Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth made a very early return to [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove 's civility , and [she]93-anne was all but calling [there]377-there in the same half hour . [She]93-anne and [Mary]94-mary were actually setting forward for [the Great House]564-the great house , where , as [she]93-anne afterwards learnt , [they]697-they must inevitably have found [him]131-captain wentworth , when [they]697-they were stopped by [the eldest boy]709-the eldest boy 's being at that moment brought [home]285-home in consequence of a bad fall . [The child]711-the child 's situation put the visit entirely aside ; but [she]93-anne could not hear of [her]93-anne escape with indifference , even in the midst of the serious anxiety which [they]697-they afterwards felt on [his]131-captain wentworth account .

[His]131-captain wentworth collar - bone was found to be dislocated , and such injury received in the back , as roused the most alarming ideas . It was an afternoon of distress , and [Anne]93-anne had every thing to do at once ; [the apothecary]712-the apothecary to send for , [the father]583-the father to have pursued and informed , [the mother]272-the mother to support and keep from hysterics , [the servants]715-the servants to control , [the youngest child]716-the youngest child to banish , and the poor suffering one to attend and soothe ; besides sending , as soon as [she]93-anne recollected it , proper notice to [the other house]678-the other house , which brought [her]93-anne an accession rather of [frightened , enquiring companions]718-frightened , enquiring companions , than of [very useful assistants]719-very useful assistants .

[[Her]93-anne brother]2431-her brother 's return was the first comfort ; [he]2431-her brother could take best care of [[his]2431-her brother wife]222-his wife ; and the second blessing was the arrival of [the apothecary]712-the apothecary . Till [he]131-captain wentworth came and had examined [the child]711-the child , [their]724-they apprehensions were the worse for being vague ; [they]724-they suspected great injury , but knew not where ; but now the collar - bone was soon replaced , and though [Mr Robinson]132-mr robinson felt and felt , and rubbed , and looked grave , and spoke low words both to [the father]583-the father and [the aunt]726-the aunt , still [they]724-they were all to hope the best , and to be able to part and eat [their]724-they dinner in tolerable ease of mind ; and then it was , just before [they]724-they parted , that [the two young aunts]727-the two young aunts were able so far to digress from [[their]727-the two young aunts nephew]728-their nephew 's state , as to give the information of [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth 's visit ; staying five minutes behind [[their]724-they father]729-their father and [mother]473-mother , to endeavour to express how perfectly delighted [they]724-they were with [him]131-captain wentworth , how much handsomer , how infinitely more agreeable [they]724-they thought [him]131-captain wentworth than [any individual among [their]724-they male acquaintance]731-any individual among their male acquaintance , who had been at all a favourite before . How glad [they]724-they had been to hear [papa]2382-papa invite [him]131-captain wentworth to stay dinner , how sorry when [he]131-captain wentworth said it was quite out of [his]131-captain wentworth power , and how glad again when [he]131-captain wentworth had promised in reply to [papa]2382-papa and [mamma]2414-mamma 's farther pressing invitations to come and dine with [them]724-they on the morrow -- actually on the morrow ; and [he]131-captain wentworth had promised it in so pleasant a manner , as if [he]131-captain wentworth felt all the motive of [their]724-they attention just as [he]131-captain wentworth ought . And in short , [he]131-captain wentworth had looked and said everything with such exquisite grace , that [they]724-they could assure [them]724-they all , [their]724-they heads were both turned by [him]131-captain wentworth ; and off [they]724-they ran , quite as full of glee as of love , and apparently more full of [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth than of [little Charles]96-charles .

The same story and the same raptures were repeated , when [the two girls]735-the two girls came with [[their]735-the two girls father]729-their father , through the gloom of the evening , to make enquiries ; and [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove , no longer under the first uneasiness about [[his]120-mrs musgrove heir]737-his heir , could add [his]120-mrs musgrove confirmation and praise , and hope there would be now no occasion for putting [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth off , and only be sorry to think that the cottage party , probably , would not like to leave [the little boy]738-the little boy , to give [him]738-the little boy the meeting . " Oh no ; as to leaving [the little boy]738-the little boy , "[267-father] both [father]267-father and [mother]473-mother were in much too strong and recent alarm to bear the thought ; and [Anne]93-anne , in the joy of the escape , could not help adding [her]93-anne warm protestations to [theirs]724-they .

[Charles Musgrove]96-charles , indeed , afterwards , [shewed]741-shewed more of inclination ; " [the child]711-the child was going on so well , and [he]711-the child wished so much to be introduced to [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth , that , perhaps , [he]711-the child might join [them]724-they in the evening ; [he]711-the child would not dine from [home]285-home , but [he]711-the child might walk in for half an hour . "[120-mrs musgrove] But in this [he]120-mrs musgrove was eagerly opposed by [[his]120-mrs musgrove wife]222-his wife , with " Oh ! no , indeed , [Charles]96-charles , [I]120-mrs musgrove can not bear to have [you]96-charles go away . Only think if anything should happen ? "[120-mrs musgrove]

[The child]711-the child had a good night , and was going on well the next day . It must be a work of time to ascertain that no injury had been done to the spine ; but [Mr Robinson]132-mr robinson found nothing to increase alarm , and [Charles Musgrove]96-charles began , consequently , to feel no necessity for longer confinement . [The child]711-the child was to be kept in bed and amused as quietly as possible ; but what was there for [a father]745-a father to do ? This was quite a female case , and it would be highly absurd in [him]120-mrs musgrove , who could be of no use at [home]285-home , to shut [himself]120-mrs musgrove up . [[His]711-the child father]2282-his father very much wished [him]711-the child to meet [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth , and there being no sufficient reason against it , [he]711-the child ought to go ; and it ended in [his]120-mrs musgrove making a bold , public declaration , when [he]120-mrs musgrove came in from [shooting]748-shooting , of [his]120-mrs musgrove meaning to dress directly , and dine at [the other house]678-the other house .

" Nothing can be going on better than [the child]711-the child , "[120-mrs musgrove] said [he]120-mrs musgrove ; " so [I]120-mrs musgrove told [[my]120-mrs musgrove father]2247-my father , just now , that [I]120-mrs musgrove would come , and [he]2247-my father thought [me]120-mrs musgrove quite right . [[Your]711-the child sister]2380-your sister being with [you]711-the child , [[my]120-mrs musgrove love]2445-my love , [I]120-mrs musgrove have no scruple at all . [You]711-the child would not like to leave [him]711-the child [yourself]711-the child , but [you]711-the child see [I]120-mrs musgrove can be of no use . [Anne]93-anne will send for [me]120-mrs musgrove if anything is the matter . "[120-mrs musgrove]

[Husbands]750-husbands and [wives]751-wives generally understand when opposition will be vain . [Mary]94-mary knew , from [Charles]96-charles 's manner of speaking , that [he]752-i was quite determined on going , and that it would be of no use to teaze [him]752-i . [She]94-mary said nothing , therefore , till [he]752-i was out of [the room]406-the room , but as soon as there was only [Anne]93-anne to hear--

" So [you]711-the child and [I]752-i are to be left to shift by [ourselves]2446-ourselves , with [this poor sick child]2447-this poor sick child ; and not a creature coming near [us]2446-ourselves all the evening ! [I]752-i knew how it would be . This is always [my]752-i luck . If there is anything disagreeable going on [men]2274-men are always sure to get out of it , and [Charles]96-charles is as bad as any of [them]2274-men . Very unfeeling ! [I]752-i must say it is very unfeeling of [him]752-i to be running away from [[his]752-i poor little boy]2449-his poor little boy . Talks of [his]752-i being going on so well ! How does [he]752-i know that [he]752-i is going on well , or that there may not be a sudden change half an hour hence ? [I]752-i did not think [Charles]96-charles would have been so unfeeling . So here [he]752-i is to go away and enjoy [himself]752-i , and because [I]752-i am [the poor mother]2450-the poor mother , [I]752-i am not to be allowed to stir ; and yet , [I]752-i am sure , [I]752-i am more unfit than [anybody else]342-anybody else to be about [the child]711-the child . [My]752-i being [the mother]272-the mother is the very reason why [my]752-i feelings should not be tried . [I]752-i am not at all equal to it . [You]2454-you saw how hysterical [I]752-i was yesterday . "[752-i]

" But that was only the effect of the suddenness of [your]2454-you alarm -- of the shock . [You]2454-you will not be hysterical again . [I]752-i dare say [we]2455-we shall have nothing to distress [us]2455-we . [I]752-i perfectly understand [Mr Robinson]132-mr robinson 's directions , and have no fears ; and indeed , [Mary]94-mary , [I]752-i can not wonder at [[your]94-mary husband]2456-your husband . [Nursing]133-nursing does not belong to [a man]2277-a man ; it is not [[his]2277-a man province]2458-his province . [A sick child]2459-a sick child is always [the mother]272-the mother 's property : [her]272-the mother own feelings generally make it so . "[752-i]

" [I]752-i hope [I]752-i am as fond of [[my]752-i child]2461-my child as [any mother]2462-any mother , but [I]752-i do not know that [I]752-i am of any more use in [the sick - room]2463-the sick - room than [Charles]96-charles , for [I]752-i can not be always scolding and teazing [the poor child]2464-the poor child when it is ill ; and [you]94-mary saw , this morning , that if [I]752-i told [him]2464-the poor child to keep quiet , [he]2464-the poor child was sure to begin kicking about . [I]752-i have not nerves for the sort of thing . "[752-i]

" But , could [you]94-mary be comfortable [yourself]94-mary , to be spending the whole evening away from [the poor boy]2465-the poor boy ? "[752-i]

" Yes ; [you]94-mary see [[his]2464-the poor child papa]2466-his papa can , and why should not [I]752-i ? [Jemima]126-jemima is so careful ; and [she]126-jemima could send [us]2467-us word every hour how [he]2464-the poor child was . [I]752-i really think [Charles]96-charles might as well have told [[his]2464-the poor child father]2282-his father [we]2467-us would all come . [I]752-i am not more alarmed about [little Charles]96-charles now than [he]2464-the poor child is . [I]752-i was dreadfully alarmed yesterday , but the case is very different to - day . "[752-i]

" Well , if [you]94-mary do not think it too late to give notice for [yourself]94-mary , suppose [you]94-mary were to go , as well as [[your]94-mary husband]2456-your husband . Leave [little Charles]96-charles to [my]752-i care . [Mr and Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove can not think it wrong while [I]752-i remain with [him]2464-the poor child . "[752-i]

" Are [you]94-mary serious ? "[94-mary] cried [Mary]94-mary , [her]94-mary eyes brightening . " Dear [me]94-mary ! that 's a very good thought , very good , indeed . To be sure , [I]94-mary may just as well go as not , for [I]94-mary am of no use at [home]285-home -- am [I]94-mary ? and it only harasses [me]94-mary . [You]94-mary , who have not [a mother]242-a mother 's feelings , are a great deal [the properest person]2472-the properest person . [You]94-mary can make [little Charles]96-charles do anything ; [he]2464-the poor child always minds [you]94-mary at a word . It will be a great deal better than leaving [him]2464-the poor child only with [Jemima]126-jemima . Oh ! [I]94-mary shall certainly go ; [I]94-mary am sure [I]94-mary ought if [I]94-mary can , quite as much as [Charles]96-charles , for [they]2473-they want [me]94-mary excessively to be acquainted with [Captain Wentworth]131-captain wentworth , and [I]94-mary know [you]94-mary do not mind being left alone . An excellent thought of [yours]94-mary , indeed , [Anne]93-anne . [I]94-mary will go and tell [Charles]96-charles , and get ready directly . [You]94-mary can send for [us]2474-us , [you]94-mary know , at a moment 's notice , if anything is the matter ; but [I]94-mary dare say there will be nothing to alarm [you]94-mary . [I]94-mary should not go , [you]94-mary may be sure , if [I]94-mary did not feel quite at ease about [[my]94-mary dear child]2475-my dear child . "[94-mary]

The next moment [she]754-i was tapping at [[her]754-i husband]2315-her husband 's dressing - room door , and as [Anne]93-anne followed [her]754-i up [stairs]756-stairs , [she]754-i was in time for the whole conversation , which began with [Mary]94-mary 's saying , in a tone of great exultation--

" [I]754-i mean to go with [you]96-charles , [Charles]96-charles , for [I]754-i am of no more use at [home]285-home than [you]96-charles are . If [I]754-i were to shut [myself]754-i up for ever with [the child]711-the child , [I]754-i should not be able to persuade [him]711-the child to do anything [he]711-the child did not like . [Anne]93-anne will stay ; [Anne]93-anne undertakes to stay at [home]285-home and take care of [him]711-the child . It is [Anne]93-anne 's own proposal , and so [I]754-i shall go with [you]96-charles , which will be a great deal better , for [I]754-i have not dined at [the other house]678-the other house since Tuesday . "[754-i]

" This is very kind of [Anne]93-anne , "[2315-her husband] was [[her]757-her husband]2315-her husband 's answer , " and [I]2315-her husband should be very glad to have [you]93-anne go ; but it seems rather hard that [she]93-anne should be left at [home]285-home by [herself]93-anne , to nurse [[our]759-them sick child]2481-our sick child . "[2315-her husband]

[Anne]93-anne was now at hand to take up [her]93-anne own cause , and the sincerity of [her]93-anne manner being soon sufficient to convince [him]2315-her husband , where conviction was at least very agreeable , [he]2315-her husband had no farther scruples as to [her]93-anne being left to dine alone , though [he]2315-her husband still wanted [her]93-anne to join [them]759-them in the evening , when [the child]711-the child might be at rest for the night , and kindly urged [her]93-anne to let [him]2315-her husband come and fetch [her]93-anne , but [she]93-anne was quite unpersuadable ; and this being the case , [she]93-anne had ere long the pleasure of seeing [them]759-them set off together in high spirits . [They]759-them were gone , [she]93-anne hoped , to be happy , however oddly constructed such happiness might seem ; as for [herself]93-anne , [she]93-anne was left with as many sensations of comfort , as were , perhaps , ever likely to be [hers]93-anne . [She]93-anne knew [herself]93-anne to be of the first utility to [the child]711-the child ; and what was it to [her]93-anne if [Frederick Wentworth]117-captain wentworth were only half a mile distant , making [himself]117-captain wentworth agreeable to [others]391-others ?

[She]93-anne would have liked to know how [he]117-captain wentworth felt as to a meeting . Perhaps indifferent , if indifference could exist under such circumstances . [He]117-captain wentworth must be either indifferent or unwilling . Had [he]117-captain wentworth wished ever to see [her]93-anne again , [he]117-captain wentworth need not have waited till this time ; [he]117-captain wentworth would have done what [she]93-anne could not but believe that in [his]117-captain wentworth place [she]93-anne should have done long ago , when events had been early giving [him]117-captain wentworth the independence which alone had been wanting .

[[Her]93-anne brother]2431-her brother and [sister]268-sister came back delighted with [their]765-they new acquaintance , and [their]765-they visit in general . There had been music , singing , talking , laughing , all that was most agreeable ; charming manners in [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , no shyness or reserve ; [they]765-they seemed all to know [each other]489-each other perfectly , and [he]117-captain wentworth was coming the very next morning to shoot with [Charles]96-charles . [He]117-captain wentworth was to come to breakfast , but not at [the Cottage]608-the cottage , though that had been proposed at first ; but then [he]117-captain wentworth had been pressed to come to [the Great House]564-the great house instead , and [he]117-captain wentworth seemed afraid of being in [Mrs Charles Musgrove]96-charles 's way , on account of [the child]711-the child , and therefore , somehow , [they]765-they hardly knew how , it ended in [Charles]96-charles 's being to meet [him]117-captain wentworth to breakfast at [[his]117-captain wentworth father]2282-his father 's .

[Anne]93-anne understood it . [He]117-captain wentworth wished to avoid seeing [her]93-anne . [He]117-captain wentworth had inquired after [her]93-anne , [she]93-anne found , slightly , as might suit [a former slight acquaintance]771-a former slight acquaintance , seeming to acknowledge such as [she]93-anne had acknowledged , actuated , perhaps , by the same view of escaping introduction when [they]765-they were to meet .

The morning hours of [the Cottage]608-the cottage were always later than those of [the other house]678-the other house , and on the morrow the difference was so great that [Mary]94-mary and [Anne]93-anne were not more than beginning breakfast when [Charles]96-charles came in to say that [they]765-they were just setting off , that [he]117-captain wentworth was come for [his]117-captain wentworth dogs , that [[his]117-captain wentworth sisters]688-his sisters were following with [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth ; [[his]117-captain wentworth sisters]688-his sisters meaning to visit [Mary]94-mary and [the child]711-the child , and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth proposing also to wait on [her]711-the child for a few minutes if not inconvenient ; and though [Charles]96-charles had answered for [the child]711-the child 's being in no such state as could make it inconvenient , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth would not be satisfied without [his]117-captain wentworth running on to give notice .
