[Mary]94-mary , very much gratified by this attention , was delighted to receive [him]117-captain wentworth , while a thousand feelings rushed on [Anne]93-anne , of which this was the most consoling , that it would soon be over . And it was soon over . In two minutes after [Charles]96-charles 's preparation , [the others]359-the others appeared ; [they]359-the others were in [the drawing - room]331-the drawing - room . [Her]94-mary eye half met [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's , a bow , a curtsey passed ; [she]94-mary heard [his]117-captain wentworth voice ; [he]117-captain wentworth talked to [Mary]94-mary , said all that was right , said something to [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , enough to mark an easy footing ; [the room]406-the room seemed full , full of [persons and voices]781-persons and voices , but a few minutes ended it . [Charles]96-charles shewed [himself]96-charles at the window , all was ready , [[their]359-the others visitor]782-their visitor had bowed and was gone , [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves were gone too , suddenly resolving to walk to [the end of [the village]2401-the village]783-the end of the village with [the sportsmen]785-the sportsmen : [the room]406-the room was cleared , and [Anne]93-anne might finish [her]93-anne breakfast as [she]93-anne could .

" It is over ! it is over ! "[93-anne] [she]93-anne repeated to [herself]93-anne again and again , in nervous gratitude . " The worst is over ! "[93-anne]

[Mary]94-mary talked , but [she]94-mary could not attend . [She]94-mary had seen [him]787-him . [They]788-they had met . [They]788-they had been once more in [the same room]789-the same room .

Soon , however , [she]94-mary began to reason with [herself]94-mary , and try to be feeling less . Eight years , almost eight years had passed , since all had been given up . How absurd to be resuming the agitation which such an interval had banished into distance and indistinctness ! What might not eight years do ? Events of every description , changes , alienations , removals -- all , all must be comprised in it , and oblivion of the past-- how natural , how certain too ! It included nearly a third part of [her]94-mary own life .

Alas ! with all [her]94-mary reasoning , [she]94-mary found , that to retentive feelings eight years may be little more than nothing .

Now , how were [his]787-him sentiments to be read ? Was this like wishing to avoid [her]94-mary ? And the next moment [she]94-mary was hating [herself]94-mary for the folly which asked the question .

On one other question which perhaps [her]94-mary utmost wisdom might not have prevented , [she]94-mary was soon spared all suspense ; for , after [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves had returned and finished [their]788-they visit at [the Cottage]608-the cottage [she]94-mary had this spontaneous information from [Mary:--]134-mary:--

" [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth is not very gallant by [you]94-mary , [Anne]93-anne , though [he]117-captain wentworth was so attentive to [me]94-mary . [Henrietta]123-henrietta asked [him]117-captain wentworth what [he]117-captain wentworth thought of [you]94-mary , when [they]788-they went away , and [he]117-captain wentworth said , ' [You]94-mary were so altered [he]117-captain wentworth should not have known [you]94-mary again . ' "[94-mary]

[Mary]94-mary had no feelings to make [her]94-mary respect [[her]94-mary sister]476-her sister 's in a common way , but [she]94-mary was perfectly unsuspicious of being inflicting any peculiar wound .

" Altered beyond [his]792-he knowledge . "[93-anne] [Anne]93-anne fully submitted , in silent , deep mortification . Doubtless it was so , and [she]93-anne could take no revenge , for [he]792-he was not altered , or not for the worse . [She]93-anne had already acknowledged it to [herself]93-anne , and [she]93-anne could not think differently , let [him]792-he think of [her]93-anne as [he]792-he would . No : the years which had destroyed [her]93-anne youth and bloom had only given [him]792-he a more glowing , manly , open look , in no respect lessening [his]792-he personal advantages . [She]93-anne had seen the same [Frederick Wentworth]117-captain wentworth .

" So altered that [he]792-he should not have known [her]93-anne again ! "[117-captain wentworth] These were words which could not but dwell with [her]93-anne . Yet [she]93-anne soon began to rejoice that [she]93-anne had heard them . [They]793-they were of sobering tendency ; they allayed agitation ; [they]793-they composed , and consequently must make [her]93-anne happier .

[Frederick Wentworth]117-captain wentworth had used such words , or something like them , but without an idea that they would be carried round to [her]93-anne . [He]792-he had thought [her]93-anne wretchedly altered , and in the first moment of appeal , had spoken as [he]792-he felt . [He]792-he had not forgiven [Anne Elliot]93-anne . [She]93-anne had used [him]792-he ill , deserted and disappointed [him]792-he ; and worse , [she]93-anne had shewn a feebleness of character in doing so , which [his]792-he own decided , confident temper could not endure . [She]93-anne had given [him]792-he up to oblige [others]391-others . It had been the effect of over - persuasion . It had been weakness and timidity .

[He]792-he had been most warmly attached to [her]93-anne , and had never seen [a woman since whom [he]792-he thought [her]93-anne equal]795-a woman since whom he thought her equal ; but , except from some natural sensation of curiosity , [he]792-he had no desire of meeting [her]93-anne again . [Her]93-anne power with [him]792-he was gone for ever .

It was now [his]792-he object to marry . [He]792-he was rich , and being turned on [shore]686-shore , fully intended to settle as soon as [he]792-he could be properly tempted ; actually looking round , ready to fall in love with all the speed which a clear head and a quick taste could allow . [He]792-he had a heart for either of [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , if [they]797-they could catch it ; a heart , in short , for [any pleasing young woman who came in [his]792-he way]798-any pleasing young woman who came in his way , excepting [Anne Elliot]93-anne . This was [his]792-he only secret exception , when [he]792-he said to [[his]792-he sister]799-his sister , in answer to [her]799-his sister suppositions:--

" Yes , here [I]792-he am , [Sophia]135-sophy , quite ready to make a foolish match . [Anybody between fifteen and thirty]2482-anybody between fifteen and thirty may have [me]792-he for asking . A little beauty , and a few smiles , and a few compliments to [the navy]2245-the navy , and [I]792-he am [a lost man]2484-a lost man . Should not this be enough for [a sailor]2248-a sailor , who has had no society among [women]2486-women to make [him]2248-a sailor nice ? "[792-he]

[He]792-he said it , [she]799-his sister knew , to be contradicted . [His]792-he bright proud eye spoke the conviction that [he]792-he was nice ; and [Anne Elliot]93-anne was not out of [his]792-he thoughts , when [he]792-he more seriously described [the woman [he]792-he should wish to meet with]800-the woman he should wish to meet with . " A strong mind , with sweetness of manner , "[792-he] made the first and the last of the description .

" That is [the woman [I]792-he want]2487-the woman i want , "[792-he] said [he]792-he . " Something a little inferior [I]792-he shall of course put up with , but it must not be much . If [I]792-he am [a fool]2488-a fool , [I]792-he shall be [a fool]2488-a fool indeed , for [I]792-he have thought on the subject more than [most men]2490-most men . "[792-he]

Chapter 8

From this time [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth and [Anne Elliot]93-anne were repeatedly in the same circle . [They]801-they were soon dining in company together at [[Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove 's]802-mr musgrove 's , for [the little boy]738-the little boy 's state could no longer supply [[his]738-the little boy aunt]804-his aunt with a pretence for absenting [herself]804-his aunt ; and this was but the beginning of other dinings and other meetings .

Whether former feelings were to be renewed must be brought to the proof ; former times must undoubtedly be brought to the recollection of each ; they could not but be reverted to ; the year of [their]801-they engagement could not but be named by [him]792-he , in the little narratives or descriptions which conversation called forth . [His]792-he profession qualified [him]792-he , [his]792-he disposition lead [him]792-he , to talk ; and " That was in the year six ; "[792-he] " That happened before [I]792-he went to [sea]668-sea in the year six , "[792-he] occurred in the course of the first evening [they]801-they spent together : and though [his]792-he voice did not falter , and though [she]93-anne had no reason to suppose [his]792-he eye wandering towards [her]93-anne while [he]792-he spoke , [Anne]93-anne felt the utter impossibility , from [her]93-anne knowledge of [his]792-he mind , that [he]792-he could be unvisited by remembrance any more than [herself]93-anne . There must be the same immediate association of thought , though [she]93-anne was very far from conceiving it to be of equal pain .

[They]801-they had no conversation together , no intercourse but what the commonest civility required . Once so much to [each other]489-each other ! Now nothing ! There had been a time , when of [all the large party now filling [the drawing - room at [Uppercross]4-uppercross]807-the drawing - room at uppercross]806-all the large party now filling the drawing - room at uppercross , [they]801-they would have found it most difficult to cease to speak to [one another]808-one another . With the exception , perhaps , of [Admiral]111-admiral croft and [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , who seemed particularly attached and happy , ( [Anne]93-anne could allow no other exceptions even among [the married couples]809-the married couples ) , there could have been no two hearts so open , no tastes so similar , no feelings so in unison , no countenances so beloved . Now [they]801-they were as [strangers]810-strangers ; nay , worse than [strangers]810-strangers , for [they]801-they could never become acquainted . It was a perpetual estrangement .

When [he]792-he talked , [she]93-anne heard the same voice , and discerned the same mind . There was a very general ignorance of all naval matters throughout [the party]542-the party ; and [he]792-he was very much questioned , and especially by [the two Miss Musgroves , who seemed hardly to have any eyes]813-the two miss musgroves , who seemed hardly to have any eyes but for [him]792-he , as to the manner of living on board , daily regulations , food , hours , & c. , and [their]813-the two miss musgroves , who seemed hardly to have any eyes surprise at [his]792-he accounts , at learning the degree of accommodation and arrangement which was practicable , drew from [him]792-he some pleasant ridicule , which reminded [Anne]93-anne of the early days when [she]93-anne too had been ignorant , and [she]93-anne too had been accused of supposing [sailors]2271-sailors to be living on board without anything to eat , or [any cook to dress it if there were]815-any cook to dress it if there were , or [any servant to wait]816-any servant to wait , or any knife and fork to use .

From thus listening and thinking , [she]93-anne was roused by a whisper of [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove 's who , overcome by fond regrets , could not help saying--

" Ah ! [Miss Anne]93-anne , if it had pleased [Heaven]136-heaven to spare [[my]359-the others poor son]2492-my poor son , [I]359-the others dare say [he]2492-my poor son would have been just such another by this time . "[359-the others]

[Anne]93-anne suppressed a smile , and listened kindly , while [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove relieved [her]93-anne heart a little more ; and for a few minutes , therefore , could not keep pace with the conversation of [the others]359-the others .

When [she]93-anne could let [her]93-anne attention take its natural course again , [she]93-anne found [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves just fetching the Navy List ( [[their]818-their own navy]819-their own navy list , the first that had ever been at [Uppercross]4-uppercross ) , and sitting down together to pore over it , with the professed view of finding out [the ships that [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth had commanded]820-the ships that captain wentworth had commanded .

" [Your]93-anne first was [the Asp]25-the asp , [I]655-the girls remember ; [we]2493-we will look for [the Asp]2494-the asp . "[655-the girls]

" [You]93-anne will not find [her]2494-the asp there . Quite worn out and broken up . [I]93-anne was [the last man who commanded [her]2494-the asp]2495-the last man who commanded her . Hardly fit for service then . [Reported]2496-reported fit for [home]285-home service for a year or two , and so [I]93-anne was sent off to [the West Indies]26-the west indies . "[93-anne]

[The girls]655-the girls looked all amazement .

" [The Admiralty]27-the admiralty , "[117-captain wentworth] [he]117-captain wentworth continued , " entertain [themselves]27-the admiralty now and then , with sending [a few hundred men]2498-a few hundred men to [sea]668-sea , in [a ship not fit to be employed]2500-a ship not fit to be employed . But [they]27-the admiralty have a great many to provide for ; and among the thousands that may just as well go to the bottom as not , it is impossible for [them]27-the admiralty to distinguish [the very set who may be least missed]2501-the very set who may be least missed . "[117-captain wentworth]

" Phoo ! phoo ! "[411-the admiral] cried [the Admiral]411-the admiral , " what stuff [these young fellows]2502-these young fellows talk ! Never was [a better sloop than [the Asp]25-the asp in [her]2494-the asp day]2503-a better sloop than the asp in her day . For [an old built sloop]2504-an old built sloop , [you]411-the admiral would not see [her]2494-the asp equal . [Lucky fellow]2505-lucky fellow to get [her]2494-the asp ! [He]2505-lucky fellow knows there must have been [twenty better men than [himself]2505-lucky fellow]2506-twenty better men than himself applying for [her]2494-the asp at the same time . [Lucky fellow]2505-lucky fellow to get anything so soon , with no more interest than [his]2505-lucky fellow . "[411-the admiral]

" [I]117-captain wentworth felt [my]117-captain wentworth luck , [Admiral]2508-admiral , [I]117-captain wentworth assure [you]2508-admiral ; "[117-captain wentworth] replied [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , seriously . " [I]117-captain wentworth was as well satisfied with [my]117-captain wentworth appointment as [you]2508-admiral can desire . It was a great object with [me]117-captain wentworth at that time to be at [sea]668-sea ; a very great object , [I]117-captain wentworth wanted to be doing something . "[117-captain wentworth]

" To be sure [you]2508-admiral did . What should [a young fellow like [you]2508-admiral]2510-a young fellow like you do ashore for half a year together ? If [a man]2277-a man had not [a wife]2512-a wife , [he]2277-a man soon wants to be afloat again . "[411-the admiral]

" But , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , "[124-louisa] cried [Louisa]124-louisa , " how vexed [you]117-captain wentworth must have been when [you]117-captain wentworth came to [the Asp]25-the asp , to see what an old thing [they]2513-they had given [you]117-captain wentworth . "[124-louisa]

" [I]823-i knew pretty well what [she]2512-a wife was before that day ; "[823-i] said [he]823-i , smiling . " [I]93-anne had no more discoveries to make than [you]2508-admiral would have as to the fashion and strength of any old pelisse , which [you]2508-admiral had seen lent about among half [your]2508-admiral acquaintance ever since [you]2508-admiral could remember , and which at last , on some very wet day , is lent to [yourself]2508-admiral . Ah ! [she]2512-a wife was [a dear old Asp to [me]93-anne]2514-a dear old asp to me . [She]2512-a wife did all that [I]93-anne wanted . [I]93-anne knew [she]2512-a wife would . [I]93-anne knew that [we]2515-our should either go to the bottom together , or that [she]2512-a wife would be the making of [me]93-anne ; and [I]93-anne never had two days of foul weather all the time [I]93-anne was at [sea]668-sea in [her]2512-a wife ; and after taking privateers enough to be very entertaining , [I]93-anne had the good luck in [my]93-anne passage [home]285-home the next autumn , to fall in with [the very French frigate [I]93-anne wanted]2518-the very french frigate i wanted . [I]93-anne brought [her]2512-a wife into [Plymouth]28-plymouth ; and here another instance of luck . [We]2515-our had not been six hours in [the Sound]29-the sound , when a gale came on , which lasted four days and nights , and which would have done for [poor old Asp]2519-poor old asp in half the time ; [our]2515-our touch with [the Great Nation]138-the great nation not having much improved [our]2515-our condition . Four - and - twenty hours later , and [I]93-anne should only have been a gallant [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , in a small paragraph at [one corner of the newspapers]2520-one corner of the newspapers ; and being lost in only [a sloop]2521-a sloop , [nobody]2242-nobody would have thought about [me]93-anne . "[93-anne] [Anne]93-anne 's shudderings were to [herself]93-anne alone ; but [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves could be as open as [they]824-they were sincere , in [their]824-they exclamations of pity and horror .

" And so then , [I]120-mrs musgrove suppose , "[120-mrs musgrove] said [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove , in a low voice , as if thinking aloud , " so then [he]825-he went away to [the Laconia]23-the laconia , and there [he]825-he met with [[our]2515-our poor boy]2523-our poor boy . [Charles]96-charles , [[my]120-mrs musgrove dear]2319-my dear , "[120-mrs musgrove] ( beckoning [him]825-he to [her]121-the miss musgroves ) , " do ask [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth where it was [he]117-captain wentworth first met with [[your]96-charles poor brother]2525-your poor brother . [I]120-mrs musgrove always forgot . "[120-mrs musgrove]

" It was at [Gibraltar]30-gibraltar , [mother]473-mother , [I]120-mrs musgrove know . [Dick]130-dick had been left ill at [Gibraltar]30-gibraltar , with a recommendation from [[his]130-dick former captain]2527-his former captain to [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . "[120-mrs musgrove]

" Oh ! but , [Charles]96-charles , tell [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , [he]117-captain wentworth need not be afraid of mentioning poor [Dick]130-dick before [me]120-mrs musgrove , for it would be rather a pleasure to hear [him]117-captain wentworth talked of by [such a good friend]2528-such a good friend . "[120-mrs musgrove]

[Charles]96-charles , being somewhat more mindful of the probabilities of the case , only nodded in reply , and walked away .

[The girls]655-the girls were now hunting for [the Laconia]23-the laconia ; and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth could not deny [himself]117-captain wentworth the pleasure of taking the precious volume into [his]117-captain wentworth own hands to save [them]655-the girls the trouble , and once more read aloud the little statement of [her]827-i name and rate , and [present non - commissioned class]828-present non - commissioned class , observing over it that [she]827-i too had been one of [the best friends man]829-the best friends man ever had .

" Ah ! those were pleasant days when [I]827-i had [the Laconia]23-the laconia ! How fast [I]827-i made money in [her]827-i . [A friend of [mine]827-i]2529-a friend of mine and [I]827-i had such a lovely cruise together off [the Western Islands]32-the western islands . [Poor Harville]139-poor harville , [sister]268-sister ! [You]268-sister know how much [he]139-poor harville wanted money : worse than [myself]827-i . [He]139-poor harville had [a wife]2512-a wife . [Excellent fellow]2532-excellent fellow . [I]827-i shall never forget [his]139-poor harville happiness . [He]139-poor harville felt it all , so much for [her]2512-a wife sake . [I]827-i wished for [him]139-poor harville again the next summer , when [I]827-i had still the same luck in [the Mediterranean]33-the mediterranean . "[827-i]

" And [I]96-charles am sure , [Sir]2533-sir , "[96-charles] said [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles , " it was a lucky day for [us]2534-us , when [you]117-captain wentworth were put [captain]2535-captain into [that ship]2536-that ship . [We]2534-us shall never forget what [you]117-captain wentworth did . "[96-charles]

[Her]96-charles feelings made [her]96-charles speak low ; and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , hearing only in part , and probably not having [Dick Musgrove]130-dick at all near [his]117-captain wentworth thoughts , looked rather in suspense , and as if waiting for more .

" [[My]830-one of the girls brother]2424-my brother , "[830-one of the girls] whispered [one of [the girls]655-the girls]830-one of the girls ; " [mamma]2414-mamma is thinking of poor [Richard]117-captain wentworth . "[830-one of the girls]

" [Poor dear fellow]2539-poor dear fellow ! "[96-charles] continued [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles ; " [he]117-captain wentworth was grown so steady , and such [an excellent correspondent]2540-an excellent correspondent , while [he]117-captain wentworth was under [your]96-charles care ! Ah ! it would have been a happy thing , if [he]117-captain wentworth had never left [you]96-charles . [I]96-charles assure [you]96-charles , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , [we]2541-we are very sorry [he]117-captain wentworth ever left [you]96-charles . "[96-charles]

There was a momentary expression in [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's face at this speech , a certain glance of [his]117-captain wentworth bright eye , and curl of [his]117-captain wentworth handsome mouth , which convinced [Anne]93-anne , that instead of sharing in [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles 's kind wishes , as to [[her]96-charles son]700-her son , [he]117-captain wentworth had probably been at some pains to get rid of [him]700-her son ; but it was too transient an indulgence of self - amusement to be detected by [any who understood [him]117-captain wentworth less than [herself]96-charles]833-any who understood him less than herself ; in another moment [he]117-captain wentworth was perfectly collected and serious , and almost instantly afterwards coming up to the sofa , on which [she]96-charles and [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles were sitting , took a place by [the latter]834-the latter , and entered into conversation with [her]96-charles , in a low voice , about [[her]96-charles son]700-her son , doing it with so much sympathy and natural grace , as [shewed]836-shewed the kindest consideration for all that was real and unabsurd in [the parent]837-the parent 's feelings .

[They]838-they were actually on the same sofa , for [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles had most readily made room for [him]117-captain wentworth ; [they]838-they were divided only by [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles . It was no insignificant barrier , indeed . [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles was of a comfortable , substantial size , infinitely more fitted by nature to express good cheer and good humour , than tenderness and sentiment ; and while the agitations of [Anne]93-anne 's slender form , and pensive face , may be considered as very completely screened , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth should be allowed some credit for the self - command with which [he]117-captain wentworth attended to [her]96-charles large fat sighings over the destiny of [a son]839-a son , whom alive [nobody had cared for]840-nobody had cared for .

Personal size and mental sorrow have certainly no necessary proportions . [A large bulky figure]841-a large bulky figure has as good a right to be in deep affliction , as the most graceful set of limbs in [the world]237-the world . But , fair or not fair , there are unbecoming conjunctions , which reason will patronize in vain -- which taste can not tolerate -- which ridicule will seize .

[The Admiral]411-the admiral , after taking two or three refreshing turns about [the room]406-the room with [his]411-the admiral hands behind [him]411-the admiral , being called to order by [[his]411-the admiral wife]222-his wife , now came up to [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , and without any observation of what [he]411-the admiral might be interrupting , thinking only of [his]411-the admiral own thoughts , began with--

" If [you]117-captain wentworth had been a week later at [Lisbon]34-lisbon , last spring , [Frederick]117-captain wentworth , [you]117-captain wentworth would have been asked to give a passage to [Lady Mary Grierson]94-mary and [[her]94-mary daughters]247-her daughters . "[411-the admiral]

" Should [I]411-the admiral ? [I]411-the admiral am glad [I]411-the admiral was not a week later then . "[411-the admiral]

[The Admiral]411-the admiral abused [him]411-the admiral for [his]411-the admiral want of gallantry . [He]411-the admiral defended [himself]411-the admiral ; though professing that [he]411-the admiral would never willingly admit [any ladies on board [a ship of [his]411-the admiral]848-a ship of his]847-any ladies on board a ship of his , excepting for a ball , or a visit , which a few hours might comprehend .

" But , if [I]411-the admiral know [myself]411-the admiral , "[411-the admiral] said [he]411-the admiral , " this is from no want of gallantry towards [them]2543-them . It is rather from feeling how impossible it is , with all one 's efforts , and [all one]2544-all one 's sacrifices , to make the accommodations on board such as [women]2486-women ought to have . There can be no want of gallantry , [Admiral]2508-admiral , in rating the claims of [women]2486-women to every personal comfort high , and this is what [I]411-the admiral do . [I]411-the admiral hate to hear of [women on board]2548-women on board , or to see [them]2548-women on board on board ; and [no ship under [my]411-the admiral command]2549-no ship under my command shall ever convey [a family of ladies]2550-a family of ladies anywhere , if [I]411-the admiral can help it . "[411-the admiral]

This brought [[his]411-the admiral sister]799-his sister upon [him]411-the admiral .

" Oh ! [Frederick]117-captain wentworth ! But [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his can not believe it of you.--All idle refinement!--Women may be as comfortable on board , as in [the best house in [England]17-england]2551-the best house in england . [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his believe [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his have lived as much on board as [most women]2552-most women , and [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his know nothing superior to the accommodations of [a man - of - war]2553-a man - of - war . [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his declare [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his have not a comfort or an indulgence about [me]847-any ladies on board a ship of his , even at [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , "[847-any ladies on board a ship of his] ( with a kind bow to [Anne]93-anne ) , " beyond what [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his always had in most of [the ships [I]847-any ladies on board a ship of his have lived in]2554-the ships i have lived in ; and [they]2554-the ships i have lived in have been five altogether . "[847-any ladies on board a ship of his]

" Nothing to the purpose , "[2431-her brother] replied [[her]93-anne brother]2431-her brother . " [You]847-any ladies on board a ship of his were living with [[your]847-any ladies on board a ship of his husband]2456-your husband , and were [the only woman on board]2556-the only woman on board . "[2431-her brother]

" But [you]847-any ladies on board a ship of his , [yourself]847-any ladies on board a ship of his , brought [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville , [[her]140-mrs harville sister]476-her sister , [[her]140-mrs harville cousin]2558-her cousin , and [three children]2559-three children , round from [Portsmouth]35-portsmouth to [Plymouth]28-plymouth . " All merged in [my]2431-her brother friendship , [Sophia]135-sophy . But do not imagine that [I]2431-her brother did not feel it an evil in itself . "[2431-her brother]

" Depend upon it , [they]2563-they were all perfectly comfortable . "[847-any ladies on board a ship of his]

" [I]2431-her brother might not like [them]2563-they the better for that perhaps . [Such a number of [women]2486-women and [children]433-children]2564-such a number of women and children have no right to be comfortable on board . "[2431-her brother]

" [[My]847-any ladies on board a ship of his dear]2319-my dear [Frederick]117-captain wentworth , [you]117-captain wentworth are talking quite idly . [We]2568-we none of [us]2568-we expect to be in smooth water all [our]2568-we days . "[847-any ladies on board a ship of his]

" Ah ! [[my]411-the admiral dear]2319-my dear , "[411-the admiral] said [the Admiral]411-the admiral , " when [he]411-the admiral had got [a wife]2512-a wife , [he]411-the admiral will sing a different tune . " Ay , that [we]2568-we shall . "[847-any ladies on board a ship of his]

" Now [I]117-captain wentworth have done , "[117-captain wentworth] cried [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . "[117-captain wentworth]

[He]117-captain wentworth got up and moved away .

" What [a great traveller]2583-a great traveller [you]117-captain wentworth must have been , [ma'am]2584-ma'am ! "[96-charles] said [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles to [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft .

" Pretty well , [ma'am]2584-ma'am in the fifteen years of [my]96-charles marriage ; though [many women]2586-many women have done more . [I]96-charles have crossed [the Atlantic]36-the atlantic four times , and have been once to [the East Indies]13-the east indies , and back again , and only once ; besides being in different places about [home]285-home : [Cork]37-cork , and [Lisbon]34-lisbon , and [Gibraltar]30-gibraltar . But [I]96-charles never went beyond [the Streights]38-the streights , and never was in [the West Indies]26-the west indies . [We]2588-we do not call [Bermuda]39-bermuda or [Bahama]40-bahama , [you]2589-you know , [the West Indies]26-the west indies . "[96-charles]

[Mrs Musgrove]96-charles had not a word to say in dissent ; [she]96-charles could not accuse [herself]96-charles of having ever called [them]852-them anything in the whole course of [her]96-charles life .

" And [I]112-mrs croft do assure [you]2589-you , [ma'am]2584-ma'am , "[112-mrs croft] pursued [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , " that nothing can exceed the accommodations of [a man - of - war]2553-a man - of - war ; [I]112-mrs croft speak , [you]2589-you know , of the higher rates . When [you]2589-you come to [a frigate]2592-a frigate , of course , [you]2589-you are more confined ; though [any reasonable woman]2593-any reasonable woman may be perfectly happy in one of them ; and [I]112-mrs croft can safely say , that the happiest part of [my]112-mrs croft life has been spent on board [a ship]474-a ship . While [we]2595-we were together , [you]2589-you know , there was nothing to be feared . Thank [God]141-god ! [I]112-mrs croft have always been blessed with excellent health , and [no climate]2596-no climate disagrees with [me]112-mrs croft . A little disordered always the first twenty - four hours of going to [sea]668-sea , but never knew what sickness was afterwards . The only time [I]112-mrs croft ever really suffered in body or mind , the only time that [I]112-mrs croft ever fancied [myself]112-mrs croft unwell , or had any ideas of danger , was the winter that [I]112-mrs croft passed by [myself]112-mrs croft at [Deal]41-deal , when [the Admiral]411-the admiral ( [Captain Croft]142-captain croft then ) was in [the North Seas]42-the north seas . [I]112-mrs croft lived in perpetual fright at that time , and had all manner of imaginary complaints from not knowing what to do with [myself]112-mrs croft , or when [I]112-mrs croft should hear from [him]411-the admiral next ; but as long as [we]2599-we could be together , nothing ever ailed [me]112-mrs croft , and [I]112-mrs croft never met with the smallest inconvenience . "[112-mrs croft]

" Aye , to be sure . Yes , indeed , oh yes ! [I]96-charles am quite of [your]96-charles opinion , [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , "[96-charles] was [Mrs Musgrove]96-charles 's hearty answer . " There is nothing so bad as a separation . [I]96-charles am quite of [your]96-charles opinion . [I]96-charles know what it is , for [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove always attends the assizes , and [I]96-charles am so glad when [they]2600-they are over , and [he]120-mrs musgrove is safe back again . "[96-charles]

The evening ended with dancing . On its being proposed , [Anne]93-anne offered [her]93-anne services , as usual ; and though [her]93-anne eyes would sometimes fill with tears as [she]93-anne sat at the instrument , [she]93-anne was extremely glad to be employed , and desired nothing in return but to be unobserved .

It was a merry , joyous party , and [no one]479-no one seemed in higher spirits than [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . [She]93-anne felt that [he]117-captain wentworth had every thing to elevate [him]117-captain wentworth which general attention and deference , and especially the attention of [all the young women]854-all the young women , could do . [The Miss Hayters]143-the hayters , [the females of [the family of cousins already mentioned]856-the family of cousins already mentioned]855-the females of the family of cousins already mentioned , were apparently admitted to the honour of being in love with [him]117-captain wentworth ; and as for [Henrietta]123-henrietta and [Louisa]124-louisa , [they]857-they both seemed so entirely occupied by [him]117-captain wentworth , that nothing but the continued appearance of the most perfect good - will between [themselves]857-they could have made it credible that [they]857-they were not decided rivals . If [he]117-captain wentworth were a little spoilt by such universal , such eager admiration , who could wonder ?

These were some of the thoughts which occupied [Anne]93-anne , while [her]93-anne fingers were mechanically at work , proceeding for half an hour together , equally without error , and without consciousness . Once [she]93-anne felt that [he]117-captain wentworth was looking at [herself]93-anne , observing [her]93-anne altered features , perhaps , trying to trace in [them]858-them the ruins of the face which had once charmed [him]117-captain wentworth ; and once [she]93-anne knew that [he]117-captain wentworth must have spoken of [her]93-anne ; [she]93-anne was hardly aware of it , till [she]93-anne heard the answer ; but then [she]93-anne was sure of [his]117-captain wentworth having asked [[his]117-captain wentworth partner]859-his partner whether [Miss Elliot]93-anne never danced ? The answer was , " Oh , no ; never ; [she]93-anne has quite given up dancing . [She]93-anne had rather play . [She]93-anne is never tired of playing . "[117-captain wentworth] Once , too , [he]117-captain wentworth spoke to [her]93-anne . [She]93-anne had left the instrument on the dancing being over , and [he]117-captain wentworth had sat down to try to make out an air which [he]117-captain wentworth wished to give [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves an idea of . Unintentionally [she]93-anne returned to [that part of [the room]406-the room]860-that part of the room ; [he]117-captain wentworth saw [her]93-anne , and , instantly rising , said , with studied politeness--

" [I]93-anne beg [your]93-anne pardon , [madam]2601-madam , this is [your]93-anne seat ; "[93-anne] and though [she]93-anne immediately drew back with a decided negative , [he]117-captain wentworth was not to be induced to sit down again .

[Anne]93-anne did not wish for more of such looks and speeches . [His]117-captain wentworth cold politeness , [his]117-captain wentworth ceremonious grace , were worse than anything .

Chapter 9

[Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth was come to [Kellynch]6-kellynch as to [a home]2230-a home , to stay as long as [he]117-captain wentworth liked , being as thoroughly the object of [the Admiral]411-the admiral 's fraternal kindness as of [[his]117-captain wentworth wife]222-his wife 's . [He]117-captain wentworth had intended , on first arriving , to proceed very soon into [Shropshire]43-shropshire , and visit [the brother]865-the brother settled in [that country]484-that country , but the attractions of [Uppercross]144-uppercross induced [him]117-captain wentworth to put this off . There was so much of friendliness , and of flattery , and of everything most bewitching in [his]117-captain wentworth reception [there]377-there ; [the old]868-the old were so hospitable , [the young]869-the young so agreeable , that [he]117-captain wentworth could not but resolve to remain where [he]117-captain wentworth was , and take all the charms and perfections of [[Edward]128-edward 's wife]870-edward 's wife upon credit a little longer .

It was soon [Uppercross]871-uppercross with [him]117-captain wentworth almost every day . [The Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves could hardly be more ready to invite than [he]117-captain wentworth to come , particularly in the morning , when [he]117-captain wentworth had [no companion]872-no companion at [home]285-home , for [the Admiral]411-the admiral and [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft were generally out of doors together , interesting [themselves]875-their in [their]875-their new possessions , [their]875-their grass , and [their]875-their sheep , and dawdling about in a way not endurable to [a third person]876-a third person , or driving out in a gig , lately added to [their]875-their establishment .

Hitherto there had been but one opinion of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth among [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves and [[their]875-their dependencies]877-their dependencies . It was unvarying , warm admiration everywhere ; but this intimate footing was not more than established , when [a certain [Charles Hayter]95-charles]878-a certain charles hayter returned among [them]875-their , to be a good deal disturbed by it , and to think [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth very much in the way .

[Charles Hayter]95-charles was [the eldest of [all the cousins]880-all the cousins]879-the eldest of all the cousins , and [a very amiable , pleasing young man]881-a very amiable , pleasing young man , between whom and [Henrietta]123-henrietta there had been a considerable appearance of attachment previous to [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's introduction . [He]117-captain wentworth was in [orders]882-orders ; and having a curacy in [the neighbourhood]281-the neighbourhood , where residence was not required , lived at [[[his]117-captain wentworth father]2282-his father 's house]885-his father 's house , only two miles from [Uppercross]4-uppercross . A short absence from [home]285-home had left [[his]117-captain wentworth fair one]887-his fair one unguarded by [his]117-captain wentworth attentions at this critical period , and when [he]117-captain wentworth came back [he]117-captain wentworth had the pain of finding very altered manners , and of seeing [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth .

[Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove and [Mrs Hayter]145-mrs hayter were [sisters]888-sisters . [They]888-sisters had each had money , but [their]888-sisters marriages had made a material difference in [their]888-sisters degree of consequence . [Mr Hayter]146-mr hayter had some property of [his]146-mr hayter own , but it was insignificant compared with [[Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove 's]802-mr musgrove 's ; and while [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves were in [the first class of society in [the country]287-the country]890-the first class of society in the country , [the young Hayters]892-the young hayters would , from [[their]892-the young hayters parents]893-their parents ' inferior , retired , and unpolished way of living , and [their]892-the young hayters own defective education , have been hardly in any class at all , but for [their]892-the young hayters connexion with [Uppercross]4-uppercross , [this eldest son of course excepted]894-this eldest son of course excepted , who had chosen to be [a scholar]895-a scholar and [a gentleman]374-a gentleman , and who was very superior in cultivation and manners to [all the rest]897-all the rest .

[The two families]565-the two families had always been on excellent terms , there being no pride on one side , and no envy on the other , and only such a consciousness of superiority in [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , as made [them]892-the young hayters pleased to improve [[their]892-the young hayters cousins]899-their cousins . [Charles]95-charles 's attentions to [Henrietta]123-henrietta had been observed by [[her]123-henrietta father]274-her father and [mother]473-mother without any disapprobation . " It would not be a great match for [her]123-henrietta ; but if [Henrietta]123-henrietta liked [him,"--]95-charles[123-henrietta] and [Henrietta]123-henrietta did seem to like [him]95-charles .

[Henrietta]123-henrietta fully thought so [herself]123-henrietta , before [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth came ; but from that time [Cousin Charles]147-cousin charles had been very much forgotten .

Which of [the two sisters]665-the two sisters was preferred by [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth was as yet quite doubtful , as far as [Anne]93-anne 's observation reached . [Henrietta]123-henrietta was perhaps the prettiest , [Louisa]124-louisa had the higher spirits ; and [she]124-louisa knew not now , whether the more gentle or the more lively character were most likely to attract [him]95-charles .

Mr and [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove , either from seeing little , or from an entire confidence in the discretion of both [[their]665-the two sisters daughters]640-their daughters , and of all [the young men who came near them]904-the young men who came near them , seemed to leave everything to take its chance . There was not the smallest appearance of solicitude or remark about [them]665-the two sisters in [the Mansion - house]905-the mansion - house ; but it was different at [the Cottage]608-the cottage : [the young couple there]907-the young couple there were more disposed to speculate and wonder ; and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth had not been above four or five times in [the [Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves ' company]908-the miss musgroves ' company , and [Charles Hayter]95-charles had but just reappeared , when [Anne]93-anne had to listen to the opinions of [[her]93-anne brother]2431-her brother and sister , as to which was [the one liked best]910-the one liked best . [Charles]95-charles gave it for [Louisa]124-louisa , [Mary]94-mary for [Henrietta]123-henrietta , but quite agreeing that to have [him]95-charles marry either could be extremely delightful .

[Charles]95-charles " had never seen [a pleasanter man]2602-a pleasanter man in [his]95-charles life ; and from what [he]95-charles had once heard [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth [himself]117-captain wentworth say , was very sure that [he]117-captain wentworth had not made less than twenty thousand pounds by the war . Here was a fortune at once ; besides which , there would be the chance of what might be done in any future war ; and [he]95-charles was sure [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth was as likely [a man to distinguish [himself]117-captain wentworth as [any officer in the navy]2604-any officer in the navy]2603-a man to distinguish himself as any officer in the navy . Oh ! it would be a capital match for [either of [[his]117-captain wentworth sisters]688-his sisters]2605-either of his sisters . "[95-charles]

" Upon [my]94-mary word it would , "[94-mary] replied [Mary]94-mary . " Dear [me]94-mary ! If [he]117-captain wentworth should rise to any very great honours ! If [he]117-captain wentworth should ever be made [a baronet]349-a baronet ! ' [Lady Wentworth]148-lady wentworth ' sounds very well . That would be a noble thing , indeed , for [Henrietta]123-henrietta ! [She]123-henrietta would take place of [me]94-mary then , and [Henrietta]123-henrietta would not dislike that . [Sir Frederick]149-sir frederick and [Lady Wentworth]148-lady wentworth ! It would be but a new creation , however , and [I]94-mary never think much of [your]143-the hayters new creations . "[94-mary]

It suited [Mary]94-mary best to think [Henrietta]123-henrietta the one preferred on the very account of [Charles Hayter]95-charles , whose pretensions [she]94-mary wished to see put an end to . [She]94-mary looked down very decidedly upon [the Hayters]143-the hayters , and thought it would be quite a misfortune to have the existing connection between [the families]911-the families renewed -- very sad for [herself]94-mary and [[her]94-mary children]239-her children .

" [You]143-the hayters know , "[94-mary] said [she]94-mary , " [I]94-mary can not think [him]95-charles at all a fit match for [Henrietta]123-henrietta ; and considering the alliances which [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves have made , [she]123-henrietta has no right to throw [herself]123-henrietta away . [I]94-mary do not think [any young woman]2608-any young woman has a right to make a choice that may be disagreeable and inconvenient to [the principal part of [[her]2608-any young woman family]2573-her family]2609-the principal part of her family , and be giving bad connections to [those who have not been used to]2611-those who have not been used to [them]2609-the principal part of her family . And , pray , who is [Charles Hayter]95-charles ? Nothing but [a country curate]2612-a country curate . A most improper match for [Miss Musgrove of Uppercross]144-uppercross . "[94-mary]

[[Her]94-mary husband]2315-her husband , however , would not agree with [her]94-mary here ; for besides having a regard for [[his]2315-her husband cousin]914-his cousin , [Charles Hayter]95-charles was [an eldest son]915-an eldest son , and [he]95-charles saw things as [an eldest son]915-an eldest son [himself]95-charles .

" Now [you]94-mary are talking nonsense , [Mary]94-mary , "[2315-her husband] was therefore [his]2315-her husband answer . " It would not be a great match for [Henrietta]123-henrietta , but [Charles]95-charles has a very fair chance , through [the Spicers]150-the spicers , of getting something from [the Bishop]2613-the bishop in the course of a year or two ; and [you]94-mary will please to remember , that [he]95-charles is [the eldest son]2614-the eldest son ; whenever [[my]2315-her husband uncle]2615-my uncle dies , [he]95-charles steps into very pretty property . [The estate at [Winthrop]44-winthrop]2616-the estate at winthrop is not less than two hundred and fifty acres , besides [the farm near [Taunton]12-taunton]2617-the farm near taunton , which is [some of the best land in [the country]287-the country]2618-some of the best land in the country . [I]2315-her husband grant [you]94-mary , that any of [them]2620-them but [Charles]95-charles would be a very shocking match for [Henrietta]123-henrietta , and indeed it could not be ; [he]95-charles is the only one that could be possible ; but [he]95-charles is a very good - natured , good sort of [a fellow]2621-a fellow ; and whenever [Winthrop]44-winthrop comes into [his]95-charles hands , [he]95-charles will make a different sort of place of it , and live in a very different sort of way ; and with [that property]2622-that property , [he]95-charles will never be [a contemptible man]2623-a contemptible man -- good , freehold property . No , no ; [Henrietta]123-henrietta might do worse than marry [Charles Hayter]95-charles ; and if [she]123-henrietta has [him]95-charles , and [Louisa]124-louisa can get [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , [I]2315-her husband shall be very well satisfied . "[2315-her husband]

" [Charles]95-charles may say what [he]95-charles pleases , "[94-mary] cried [Mary]94-mary to [Anne]93-anne , as soon as [he]917-he was out of [the room]406-the room , " but it would be shocking to have [Henrietta]123-henrietta marry [Charles Hayter]95-charles ; a very bad thing for [her]123-henrietta , and still worse for [me]94-mary ; and therefore it is very much to be wished that [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth may soon put [him]95-charles quite out of [her]123-henrietta head , and [I]94-mary have very little doubt that [he]95-charles has . [She]123-henrietta took hardly any notice of [Charles Hayter]95-charles yesterday . [I]94-mary wish [you]93-anne had been there to see [her]123-henrietta behaviour . And as to [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's liking [Louisa]124-louisa as well as [Henrietta]123-henrietta , it is nonsense to say so ; for [he]95-charles certainly does like [Henrietta]123-henrietta a great deal the best . But [Charles]95-charles is so positive ! [I]94-mary wish [you]93-anne had been with [us]2624-us yesterday , for then [you]93-anne might have decided between [us]2624-us ; and [I]94-mary am sure [you]93-anne would have thought as [I]94-mary did , unless [you]93-anne had been determined to give it against [me]94-mary . "[94-mary]

A dinner at [[Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove 's]802-mr musgrove 's had been the occasion when all these things should have been seen by [Anne]93-anne ; but [she]93-anne had staid at [home]285-home , under the mixed plea of a headache of [her]93-anne own , and some return of indisposition in [little Charles]95-charles . [She]93-anne had thought only of avoiding [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth ; but an escape from being appealed to as umpire was now added to the advantages of a quiet evening .

As to [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's views , [she]93-anne deemed it of more consequence that [he]117-captain wentworth should know [his]117-captain wentworth own mind early enough not to be endangering the happiness of [either sister]921-either sister , or impeaching [his]117-captain wentworth own honour , than that [he]117-captain wentworth should prefer [Henrietta]123-henrietta to [Louisa]124-louisa , or [Louisa]124-louisa to [Henrietta]123-henrietta . Either of [them]922-them would , in all probability , make [him]117-captain wentworth [an affectionate , good - humoured wife]923-an affectionate , good - humoured wife . With regard to [Charles Hayter]95-charles , [she]93-anne had delicacy which must be pained by any lightness of conduct in [a well - meaning young woman]924-a well - meaning young woman , and a heart to sympathize in any of the sufferings it occasioned ; but if [Henrietta]123-henrietta found [herself]123-henrietta mistaken in the nature of [her]123-henrietta feelings , the alteration could not be understood too soon .

[Charles Hayter]95-charles had met with much to disquiet and mortify [him]95-charles in [[his]95-charles cousin]914-his cousin 's behaviour . [She]93-anne had too old a regard for [him]117-captain wentworth to be so wholly estranged as might in two meetings extinguish every past hope , and leave [him]117-captain wentworth nothing to do but to keep away from [Uppercross]144-uppercross : but there was such a change as became very alarming , when [such a man as [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth]926-such a man as captain wentworth was to be regarded as the probable cause . [He]117-captain wentworth had been absent only two Sundays , and when [they]927-they parted , had left [her]93-anne interested , even to the height of [his]117-captain wentworth wishes , in [his]117-captain wentworth prospect of soon quitting [his]117-captain wentworth present curacy , and obtaining that of [Uppercross]4-uppercross instead . It had then seemed the object nearest [her]93-anne heart , that [Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley , [the rector]928-the rector , who for more than forty years had been zealously discharging all the duties of [[his]152-dr shirley office]929-his office , but was now growing too infirm for many of them , should be quite fixed on engaging [a curate]930-a curate ; should make [his]152-dr shirley curacy quite as good as [he]152-dr shirley could afford , and should give [Charles Hayter]95-charles the promise of it . The advantage of [his]152-dr shirley having to come only to [Uppercross]4-uppercross , instead of going six miles another way ; of [his]152-dr shirley having , in every respect , a better curacy ; of [his]152-dr shirley belonging to [[their]931-their dear]932-their dear [Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley , and of dear , [good Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley 's being relieved from the duty which [he]152-dr shirley could no longer get through without most injurious fatigue , had been a great deal , even to [Louisa]124-louisa , but had been almost everything to [Henrietta]123-henrietta . When [he]152-dr shirley came back , alas ! the zeal of the business was gone by . [Louisa]124-louisa could not listen at all to [his]152-dr shirley account of a conversation which [he]152-dr shirley had just held with [Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley : [she]124-louisa was at a window , looking out for [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth ; and even [Henrietta]123-henrietta had at best only a divided attention to give , and seemed to have forgotten all the former doubt and solicitude of the negotiation .

" Well , [I]117-captain wentworth am very glad indeed : but [I]117-captain wentworth always thought [you]124-louisa would have it ; [I]117-captain wentworth always thought [you]124-louisa sure . It did not appear to [me]117-captain wentworth that -- in short , [you]124-louisa know , [Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley must have [a curate]930-a curate , and [you]124-louisa had secured [his]152-dr shirley promise . Is [he]152-dr shirley coming , [Louisa]124-louisa ? "[117-captain wentworth]

One morning , very soon after the dinner at [the Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , at which [Anne]93-anne had not been present , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth walked into [the drawing - room at [the Cottage]608-the cottage]933-the drawing - room at the cottage , where were only [herself]93-anne and [the little invalid [Charles]95-charles , who was lying on the sofa]935-the little invalid charles , who was lying on the sofa .

The surprise of finding [himself]117-captain wentworth almost alone with [Anne Elliot]93-anne , deprived [his]117-captain wentworth manners of [their]936-they usual composure : [he]117-captain wentworth started , and could only say , " [I]117-captain wentworth thought [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves had been [here]2340-here : [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove told [me]117-captain wentworth [I]117-captain wentworth should find [them]936-they [here]2340-here , "[117-captain wentworth] before [he]117-captain wentworth walked to the window to recollect [himself]117-captain wentworth , and feel how [he]117-captain wentworth ought to behave .

" [They]936-they are up [stairs]756-stairs with [[my]93-anne sister]2379-my sister : [they]936-they will be down in a few moments , [I]93-anne dare say , "[93-anne] had been [Anne]93-anne 's reply , in all the confusion that was natural ; and if [the child]711-the child had not called [her]93-anne to come and do something for [him]117-captain wentworth , [she]93-anne would have been out of [the room]406-the room the next moment , and released [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth as well as [herself]93-anne .

[He]117-captain wentworth continued at the window ; and after calmly and politely saying , " [I]117-captain wentworth hope [the little boy]738-the little boy is better , "[117-captain wentworth] was silent .

[She]93-anne was obliged to kneel down by the sofa , and remain there to satisfy [[her]93-anne patient]939-her patient ; and thus [they]940-they continued a few minutes , when , to [her]93-anne very great satisfaction , [she]93-anne heard [some other person]941-some other person crossing [the little vestibule]942-the little vestibule . [She]93-anne hoped , on turning [her]93-anne head , to see [the master of [the house]310-the house]662-the master of the house ; but it proved to be one much less calculated for making matters easy -- [Charles Hayter]95-charles , probably not at all better pleased by the sight of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth than [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth had been by the sight of [Anne]93-anne .

[She]93-anne only attempted to say , " How do [you]117-captain wentworth do ? Will [you]117-captain wentworth not sit down ? [The others]359-the others will be [here]2340-here presently . "[93-anne]

[Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , however , came from [his]117-captain wentworth window , apparently not ill - disposed for conversation ; but [Charles Hayter]95-charles soon put an end to [his]95-charles attempts by seating [himself]95-charles near the table , and taking up the newspaper ; and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth returned to [his]117-captain wentworth window .

Another minute brought another addition . [The younger boy]945-the younger boy , [a remarkable stout , forward child , of two years old]946-a remarkable stout , forward child , of two years old , having got the door opened for [him]945-the younger boy by [some one without]947-some one without , made [his]945-the younger boy determined appearance among [them]948-them , and went straight to the sofa to see what was going on , and put in [his]945-the younger boy claim to anything good that might be giving away .

There being nothing to eat , [he]945-the younger boy could only have some play ; and as [[his]945-the younger boy aunt]804-his aunt would not let [him]945-the younger boy tease [[his]945-the younger boy sick brother]950-his sick brother , [he]945-the younger boy began to fasten [himself]945-the younger boy upon [her]804-his aunt , as [she]804-his aunt knelt , in such a way that , busy as [she]804-his aunt was about [Charles]95-charles , [she]804-his aunt could not shake [him]945-the younger boy off . [She]804-his aunt spoke to [him]945-the younger boy , ordered , entreated , and insisted in vain . Once [she]804-his aunt did contrive to push [him]945-the younger boy away , but [the boy]951-the boy had the greater pleasure in getting upon [her]804-his aunt back again directly .

" [Walter]90-sir walter , "[804-his aunt] said [she]804-his aunt , " get down this moment . [You]90-sir walter are extremely troublesome . [I]804-his aunt am very angry with [you]90-sir walter . "[804-his aunt]

" [Walter]90-sir walter , "[95-charles] cried [Charles Hayter]95-charles , " why do [you]90-sir walter not do as [you]90-sir walter are bid ? Do not [you]90-sir walter hear [[your]90-sir walter aunt]2633-your aunt speak ? Come to [me]95-charles , [Walter]90-sir walter , come to [cousin Charles]95-charles . "[95-charles]

But not a bit did [Walter]90-sir walter stir .

In another moment , however , [she]804-his aunt found [herself]804-his aunt in the state of being released from [him]90-sir walter ; [some one]952-some one was taking [him]90-sir walter from [her]804-his aunt , though [he]90-sir walter had bent down [her]804-his aunt head so much , that [his]90-sir walter little sturdy hands were unfastened from around [her]804-his aunt neck , and [he]90-sir walter was resolutely borne away , before [she]804-his aunt knew that [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth had done it .

[Her]804-his aunt sensations on the discovery made [her]804-his aunt perfectly speechless . [She]804-his aunt could not even thank [him]90-sir walter . [She]804-his aunt could only hang over [little Charles]95-charles , with most disordered feelings . [His]90-sir walter kindness in stepping forward to [her]804-his aunt relief , the manner , the silence in which it had passed , the little particulars of the circumstance , with the conviction soon forced on [her]804-his aunt by the noise [he]90-sir walter was studiously making with [the child]711-the child , that [he]90-sir walter meant to avoid hearing [her]804-his aunt thanks , and rather sought to testify that [her]804-his aunt conversation was the last of [his]90-sir walter wants , produced such a confusion of varying , but very painful agitation , as [she]804-his aunt could not recover from , till enabled by the entrance of [Mary]94-mary and [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves to make over [[her]804-his aunt little patient]954-her little patient to [their]955-their cares , and leave [the room]406-the room . [She]804-his aunt could not stay . It might have been an opportunity of watching the loves and jealousies of [the four]957-the four -- [they]957-the four were now altogether ; but [she]804-his aunt could stay for none of it . It was evident that [Charles Hayter]95-charles was not well inclined towards [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . [She]804-his aunt had a strong impression of [his]95-charles having said , in a vext tone of voice , after [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's interference , " [You]117-captain wentworth ought to have minded [me]95-charles , [Walter]90-sir walter ; [I]95-charles told [you]117-captain wentworth not to teaze [[your]117-captain wentworth aunt]2633-your aunt ; "[95-charles] and could comprehend [his]95-charles regretting that [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth should do what [he]117-captain wentworth ought to have done [himself]117-captain wentworth . But neither [Charles Hayter]95-charles 's feelings , nor [anybody]2413-anybody 's feelings , could interest [her]804-his aunt , till [she]804-his aunt had a little better arranged [her]804-his aunt own . [She]804-his aunt was ashamed of [herself]804-his aunt , quite ashamed of being so nervous , so overcome by such a trifle ; but so it was , and it required a long application of solitude and reflection to recover [her]804-his aunt .

Chapter 10

Other opportunities of making [her]804-his aunt observations could not fail to occur . [Anne]93-anne had soon been in company with [all the four together]959-all the four together often enough to have an opinion , though too wise to acknowledge as much at [home]285-home , where [she]93-anne knew it would have satisfied neither [husband]961-husband nor [wife]962-wife ; for while [she]93-anne considered [Louisa]124-louisa to be rather the favourite , [she]93-anne could not but think , as far as [she]93-anne might dare to judge from memory and experience , that [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth was not in love with either . [They]963-they were more in love with [him]117-captain wentworth ; yet there it was not love . It was a little fever of admiration ; but it might , probably must , end in love with some . [Charles Hayter]95-charles seemed aware of being slighted , and yet [Henrietta]123-henrietta had sometimes the air of being divided between [them]963-they . [Anne]93-anne longed for the power of representing to [them]963-they all what [they]963-they were about , and of pointing out some of the evils [they]963-they were exposing [themselves]963-they to . [She]93-anne did not attribute guile to any . It was the highest satisfaction to [her]93-anne to believe [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth not in the least aware of the pain [he]117-captain wentworth was occasioning . There was no triumph , no pitiful triumph in [his]117-captain wentworth manner . [He]117-captain wentworth had , probably , never heard , and never thought of any claims of [Charles Hayter]95-charles . [He]117-captain wentworth was only wrong in accepting the attentions ( for accepting must be the word ) of [two young women]964-two young women at once .

After a short struggle , however , [Charles Hayter]95-charles seemed to quit [the field]965-the field . Three days had passed without [his]95-charles coming once to [Uppercross]4-uppercross ; a most decided change . [He]95-charles had even refused one regular invitation to dinner ; and having been found on the occasion by [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove with some large books before [him]95-charles , [Mr]966-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove were sure all could not be right , and talked , with grave faces , of [his]95-charles studying [himself]95-charles to death . It was [Mary]94-mary 's hope and belief that [he]95-charles had received a positive dismissal from [Henrietta]123-henrietta , and [[her]94-mary husband]2315-her husband lived under the constant dependence of seeing [him]95-charles to - morrow . [Anne]93-anne could only feel that [Charles Hayter]95-charles was wise .

One morning , about this time [Charles Musgrove]96-charles and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth being gone a - shooting together , as [the sisters in [the Cottage]608-the cottage]968-the sisters in the cottage were sitting quietly at work , [they]968-the sisters in the cottage were visited at the window by [the sisters]970-the sisters from [the Mansion - house]905-the mansion - house .

It was a very fine November day , and [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves came through [the little grounds]972-the little grounds , and stopped for no other purpose than to say , that [they]968-the sisters in the cottage were going to take a long walk , and therefore concluded [Mary]94-mary could not like to go with [them]968-the sisters in the cottage ; and when [Mary]94-mary immediately replied , with some jealousy at not being supposed [a good walker]973-a good walker , " Oh , yes , [I]93-anne should like to join [you]93-anne very much , [I]93-anne am very fond of a long walk ; "[93-anne] [Anne]93-anne felt persuaded , by the looks of [the two girls]735-the two girls , that it was precisely what [they]735-the two girls did not wish , and admired again the sort of necessity which the family habits seemed to produce , of everything being to be communicated , and everything being to be done together , however undesired and inconvenient . [She]93-anne tried to dissuade [Mary]94-mary from going , but in vain ; and that being the case , thought it best to accept [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves ' much more cordial invitation to [herself]94-mary to go likewise , as [she]94-mary might be useful in turning back with [[her]94-mary sister]476-her sister , and lessening the interference in any plan of [their]735-the two girls own .

" [I]94-mary can not imagine why [they]735-the two girls should suppose [I]94-mary should not like a long walk , "[94-mary] said [Mary]94-mary , as [she]94-mary went up [stairs]756-stairs . " [Everybody]651-everybody is always supposing that [I]94-mary am not [a good walker]973-a good walker ; and yet [they]651-everybody would not have been pleased , if [we]516-the gentlemen had refused to join [them]651-everybody . When [people]2377-people come in this manner on purpose to ask [us]516-the gentlemen , how can one say no ? "[94-mary]

Just as [they]735-the two girls were setting off , [the gentlemen]516-the gentlemen returned . [They]516-the gentlemen had taken out a young dog , who had spoilt [their]516-the gentlemen sport , and sent [them]516-the gentlemen back early . [Their]516-the gentlemen time and strength , and spirits , were , therefore , exactly ready for this walk , and [they]516-the gentlemen entered into it with pleasure . Could [Anne]93-anne have foreseen such a junction , [she]93-anne would have staid at [home]285-home ; but , from some feelings of interest and curiosity , [she]93-anne fancied now that it was too late to retract , and [the whole six]979-the whole six set forward together in the direction chosen by [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , who evidently considered the walk as under [their]516-the gentlemen guidance .

[Anne]93-anne 's object was , not to be in the way of [anybody]2413-anybody ; and where the narrow paths across [the fields]981-the fields made many separations necessary , to keep with [[her]93-anne brother]2431-her brother and [sister]268-sister . [Her]93-anne pleasure in the walk must arise from the exercise and the day , from the view of the last smiles of the year upon the tawny leaves , and withered hedges , and from repeating to [herself]93-anne some few of the thousand poetical descriptions extant of autumn , that season of peculiar and inexhaustible influence on the mind of taste and tenderness , that season which had drawn from [every poet]984-every poet , worthy of being read , some attempt at description , or some lines of feeling . [She]93-anne occupied [her]93-anne mind as much as possible in such like musings and quotations ; but it was not possible , that when within reach of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's conversation with either of [the Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves , [she]93-anne should not try to hear it ; yet [she]93-anne caught little very remarkable . It was mere lively chat , such as [any young persons , on an intimate footing]985-any young persons , on an intimate footing , might fall into . [He]117-captain wentworth was more engaged with [Louisa]124-louisa than with [Henrietta]123-henrietta . [Louisa]124-louisa certainly put more forward for [his]117-captain wentworth notice than [[her]124-louisa sister]476-her sister . This distinction appeared to increase , and there was one speech of [Louisa]124-louisa 's which struck [her]93-anne . After one of the many praises of the day , which were continually bursting forth , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth added:--

" What glorious weather for [the Admiral]411-the admiral and [[my]117-captain wentworth sister]2379-my sister ! [They]2640-they meant to take a long drive this morning ; perhaps [we]2641-we may hail [them]2640-they from [some of [these hills]2643-these hills]2642-some of these hills . [They]2640-they talked of coming into [this side of [the country]287-the country]2644-this side of the country . [I]117-captain wentworth wonder whereabouts [they]2640-they will upset to - day . Oh ! it does happen very often , [I]117-captain wentworth assure [you]2646-you ; but [[my]117-captain wentworth sister]2379-my sister makes nothing of it ; [she]2379-my sister would as lieve be tossed out as not . "[117-captain wentworth]

" Ah ! [You]2646-you make the most of it , [I]124-louisa know , "[124-louisa] cried [Louisa]124-louisa , " but if it were really so , [I]124-louisa should do just the same in [her]2379-my sister place . If [I]124-louisa loved [a man]2277-a man , as [she]2379-my sister loves [the Admiral]411-the admiral , [I]124-louisa would always be with [him]2277-a man , nothing should ever separate [us]988-them , and [I]124-louisa would rather be overturned by [him]2277-a man , than driven safely by [anybody else]342-anybody else . "[124-louisa]

It was spoken with enthusiasm .

" Had [you]93-anne ? "[987-he] cried [he]987-he , catching the same tone ; " [I]987-he honour [you]93-anne ! "[987-he] And there was silence between [them]988-them for a little while .

[Anne]93-anne could not immediately fall into a quotation again . The sweet scenes of autumn were for a while put by , unless some tender sonnet , fraught with the apt analogy of the declining year , with declining happiness , and the images of youth and hope , and spring , all gone together , blessed [her]93-anne memory . [She]93-anne roused [herself]93-anne to say , as [they]988-them struck by order into [another path]989-another path , " Is not this one of the ways to [Winthrop]44-winthrop ? "[93-anne] But [nobody]2242-nobody heard , or , at least , [nobody]2242-nobody answered [her]93-anne .

[Winthrop]44-winthrop , however , or [[its]44-winthrop environs]992-its environs -- for [young men]993-young men are , sometimes to be met with , strolling about near [home]285-home -- was [their]993-young men destination ; and after another half mile of gradual ascent through large enclosures , where the ploughs at work , and [the fresh made path]995-the fresh made path spoke [the farmer counteracting the sweets of poetical despondence , and meaning to have spring]996-the farmer counteracting the sweets of poetical despondence , and meaning to have spring again , [they]988-them gained the summit of [the most considerable hill]997-the most considerable hill , which parted [Uppercross]144-uppercross and [Winthrop]44-winthrop , and soon commanded a full view of the latter , at [the foot of [the hill on the other side]999-the hill on the other side]998-the foot of the hill on the other side .

[Winthrop]44-winthrop , without beauty and without dignity , was stretched before [them]988-them ; [an indifferent house]1000-an indifferent house , standing low , and hemmed in by [the barns and buildings of [a farm - yard]1002-a farm - yard]1001-the barns and buildings of a farm - yard .

[Mary]94-mary exclaimed , " Bless [me]94-mary ! here is [Winthrop]44-winthrop . [I]94-mary declare [I]94-mary had no idea ! Well now , [I]94-mary think [we]988-them had better turn back ; [I]94-mary am excessively tired . "[94-mary]

[Henrietta]123-henrietta , conscious and ashamed , and seeing [no cousin]1003-no cousin [Charles]95-charles walking along any path , or leaning against any gate , was ready to do as [Mary]94-mary wished ; but " No ! "[96-charles] said [Charles Musgrove]96-charles , and " No , no ! "[124-louisa] cried [Louisa]124-louisa more eagerly , and taking [[her]124-louisa sister]476-her sister aside , seemed to be arguing the matter warmly .

[Charles]95-charles , in the meanwhile , was very decidedly declaring [his]95-charles resolution of calling on [[his]95-charles aunt]804-his aunt , now that [he]95-charles was so near ; and very evidently , though more fearfully , trying to induce [[his]95-charles wife]222-his wife to go too . But this was one of the points on which [the lady]1007-the lady shewed [her]1007-the lady strength ; and when [he]95-charles recommended the advantage of resting [herself]1007-the lady a quarter of an hour at [Winthrop]44-winthrop , as [she]1007-the lady felt so tired , [she]1007-the lady resolutely answered , " Oh ! no , indeed ! walking up [that hill]2651-that hill again would do [her]1007-the lady more harm than any sitting down could do [her]1007-the lady good ; "[1007-the lady] and , in short , [her]1007-the lady look and manner declared , that go [she]1007-the lady would not .

After a little succession of these sort of debates and consultations , it was settled between [Charles]95-charles and [[his]95-charles two sisters]1008-his two sisters , that [he]95-charles and [Henrietta]123-henrietta should just run down for a few minutes , to see [[their]1008-his two sisters aunt]1009-their aunt and [cousins]1010-cousins , while [the rest of the party]1011-the rest of the party waited for [them]1008-his two sisters at [the top of [the hill]1013-the hill]1012-the top of the hill . [Louisa]124-louisa seemed [the principal arranger of the plan]1014-the principal arranger of the plan ; and , as [she]124-louisa went a little way with [them]1008-his two sisters , down [the hill]1013-the hill , still talking to [Henrietta]123-henrietta , [Mary]94-mary took the opportunity of looking scornfully around [her]124-louisa , and saying to [Captain Wentworth--]117-captain wentworth

" It is very unpleasant , having such connexions ! But , [I]94-mary assure [you]117-captain wentworth , [I]94-mary have never been in [the house above]2652-the house above twice in [my]94-mary life . "[94-mary]

[She]94-mary received no other answer , than an artificial , assenting smile , followed by a contemptuous glance , as [he]117-captain wentworth turned away , which [Anne]93-anne perfectly knew the meaning of .

[The brow of [the hill]1013-the hill]1016-the brow of the hill , where [they]1008-his two sisters remained , was [a cheerful spot]1018-a cheerful spot : [Louisa]124-louisa returned ; and [Mary]94-mary , finding a comfortable seat for [herself]94-mary on the step of a stile , was very well satisfied so long as the others all stood about [her]94-mary ; but when [Louisa]124-louisa drew [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth away , to try for a gleaning of nuts in [an adjoining hedge - row]1019-an adjoining hedge - row , and [they]1008-his two sisters were gone by degrees quite out of sight and sound , [Mary]94-mary was happy no longer ; [she]94-mary quarrelled with [her]94-mary own seat , was sure [Louisa]124-louisa had got a much better somewhere , and nothing could prevent [her]94-mary from going to look for [a better also]1020-a better also . [She]94-mary turned through the same gate , but could not see [them]1008-his two sisters . [Anne]93-anne found a nice seat for [her]93-anne , on [a dry sunny bank]1021-a dry sunny bank , under the hedge - row , in which [she]93-anne had no doubt of [their]1008-his two sisters still being , in some spot or other . [Mary]94-mary sat down for a moment , but it would not do ; [she]94-mary was sure [Louisa]124-louisa had found a better seat somewhere else , and [she]124-louisa would go on till [she]124-louisa overtook [her]94-mary .

[Anne]93-anne , really tired [herself]93-anne , was glad to sit down ; and [she]93-anne very soon heard [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth and [Louisa]124-louisa in the hedge - row , behind [her]93-anne , as if making [their]1008-his two sisters way back along [the rough , wild sort of channel]1022-the rough , wild sort of channel , down the centre . [They]1008-his two sisters were speaking as [they]1008-his two sisters drew near . [Louisa]124-louisa 's voice was the first distinguished . [She]124-louisa seemed to be in the middle of some eager speech . What [Anne]93-anne first heard was--

" And so , [I]124-louisa made [her]124-louisa go . [I]124-louisa could not bear that [she]124-louisa should be frightened from the visit by such nonsense . What ! would [I]124-louisa be turned back from doing a thing that [I]124-louisa had determined to do , and that [I]124-louisa knew to be right , by the airs and interference of [such a person]2653-such a person , or of any person [I]124-louisa may say ? No , [I]124-louisa have no idea of being so easily persuaded . When [I]124-louisa have made up [my]124-louisa mind , [I]124-louisa have made it ; and [Henrietta]123-henrietta seemed entirely to have made up [hers]123-henrietta to call at [Winthrop]44-winthrop to - day ; and yet , [she]123-henrietta was as near giving it up , out of nonsensical complaisance ! "[124-louisa]

" [She]123-henrietta would have turned back then , but for [you]124-louisa ? "[124-louisa]

" [She]123-henrietta would indeed . [I]124-louisa am almost ashamed to say it . "[124-louisa]

" Happy for [her]124-louisa , to have such a mind as [yours]2654-you at hand ! After the hints [you]2654-you gave just now , which did but confirm [my]1023-i own observations , the last time [I]1023-i was in company with [him]2653-such a person , [I]1023-i need not affect to have no comprehension of what is going on . [I]1023-i see that more than a mere dutiful morning visit to [[your]2654-you aunt]2633-your aunt was in question ; and woe betide [him]2653-such a person , and [her]124-louisa too , when it comes to things of consequence , when they are placed in circumstances requiring fortitude and strength of mind , if [she]124-louisa have not resolution enough to resist idle interference in such a trifle as this . [[Your]2654-you sister]2380-your sister is [an amiable creature]2657-an amiable creature ; but [yours]2654-you is the character of decision and firmness , [I]1023-i see . If [you]2654-you value [her]124-louisa conduct or happiness , infuse as much of [your]2654-you own spirit into [her]124-louisa as [you]2654-you can . But this , no doubt , [you]2654-you have been always doing . It is the worst evil of too yielding and indecisive a character , that no influence over it can be depended on .
