[You]2654-you are never sure of a good impression being durable ; [everybody]651-everybody may sway it . Let [those who would be happy]2659-those who would be happy be firm . Here is a nut , "[1023-i] said [he]1023-i , catching one down from an upper bough , " to exemplify : a beautiful glossy nut , which , blessed with original strength , has outlived all the storms of autumn . Not a puncture , not a weak spot anywhere . This nut , "[1023-i] [he]1023-i continued , with playful solemnity , " while so many of [[his]1023-i brethren]2660-his brethren have fallen and been trodden under foot , is still in possession of all the happiness that a hazel nut can be supposed capable of . "[1023-i] Then returning to [his]1023-i former earnest tone--"My first wish for [all whom [I]1023-i am interested in]2661-all whom i am interested in , is that [they]2661-all whom i am interested in should be firm . If [Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa would be beautiful and happy in [her]124-louisa November of life , [she]124-louisa will cherish all [her]124-louisa present powers of mind . "[1023-i]

[He]1023-i had done , and was unanswered . It would have surprised [Anne]93-anne if [Louisa]124-louisa could have readily answered such a speech : words of such interest , spoken with such serious warmth ! [She]124-louisa could imagine what [Louisa]124-louisa was feeling . For [herself]124-louisa , [she]124-louisa feared to move , lest [she]124-louisa should be seen . While [she]124-louisa remained , a bush of low rambling holly protected [her]124-louisa , and [they]1024-i were moving on . Before [they]1024-i were beyond [her]124-louisa hearing , however , [Louisa]124-louisa spoke again .

" [Mary]94-mary is good - natured enough in many respects , "[124-louisa] said [she]124-louisa ; " but [she]94-mary does sometimes provoke [me]124-louisa excessively , by [her]94-mary nonsense and pride -- the Elliot pride . [She]94-mary has a great deal too much of the Elliot pride . [We]1024-i do so wish that [Charles]95-charles had married [Anne]93-anne instead . [I]124-louisa suppose [you]117-captain wentworth know [he]95-charles wanted to marry [Anne]93-anne ? "[124-louisa]

After a moment 's pause , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth said--

" Do [you]117-captain wentworth mean that [she]94-mary refused [him]95-charles ? "[1024-i]

" Oh ! yes ; certainly . "[1024-i]

" When did that happen ? "[1024-i]

" [I]1024-i do not exactly know , for [Henrietta]123-henrietta and [I]1024-i were at [school]380-school at the time ; but [I]1024-i believe about a year before [he]95-charles married [Mary]94-mary . [I]1024-i wish [she]94-mary had accepted [him]95-charles . [We]2663-we should all have liked [her]94-mary a great deal better ; and [papa]2382-papa and [mamma]2665-mamma always think it was [her]94-mary great friend [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's doing , that [she]94-mary did not . [They]2663-we think [Charles]95-charles might not be learned and bookish enough to please [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , and that therefore , [she]94-mary persuaded [Anne]93-anne to refuse [him]95-charles . "[1024-i]

The sounds were retreating , and [Anne]93-anne distinguished no more . [Her]93-anne own emotions still kept [her]93-anne fixed . [She]93-anne had much to recover from , before [she]93-anne could move . [The listener]1025-the listener 's proverbial fate was not absolutely [hers]93-anne ; [she]93-anne had heard no evil of [herself]93-anne , but [she]93-anne had heard a great deal of very painful import . [She]93-anne saw how [her]93-anne own character was considered by [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , and there had been just that degree of feeling and curiosity about [her]93-anne in [his]117-captain wentworth manner which must give [her]93-anne extreme agitation .

As soon as [she]93-anne could , [she]93-anne went after [Mary]94-mary , and having found , and walked back with [her]94-mary to [[their]1026-they former station]1027-their former station , by the stile , felt some comfort in [[their]1026-they whole party]1028-their whole party being immediately afterwards collected , and once more in motion together . [Her]93-anne spirits wanted the solitude and silence which only numbers could give .

[Charles]95-charles and [Henrietta]123-henrietta returned , bringing , as may be conjectured , [Charles Hayter]95-charles with [them]1026-they . The minutiae of the business [Anne]93-anne could not attempt to understand ; even [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth did not seem admitted to perfect confidence here ; but that there had been a withdrawing on [the gentleman]2219-the gentleman 's side , and a relenting on [the lady]1007-the lady 's , and that [they]1026-they were now very glad to be together again , did not admit a doubt . [Henrietta]123-henrietta looked a little ashamed , but very well pleased;--Charles [Hayter]95-charles exceedingly happy : and [they]1026-they were devoted to [each other]489-each other almost from the first instant of [their]1026-they all setting forward for [Uppercross]4-uppercross .

Everything now marked out [Louisa]124-louisa for [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth ; nothing could be plainer ; and where many divisions were necessary , or even where [they]1026-they were not , [they]1026-they walked side by side nearly as much as the other two . In [a long strip of [meadow land]1033-meadow land]1032-a long strip of meadow land , where there was ample space for all , [they]1026-they were thus divided , forming [three distinct parties]1034-three distinct parties ; and to that party of the three which boasted least animation , and least complaisance , [Anne]93-anne necessarily belonged . [She]93-anne joined [Charles]95-charles and [Mary]94-mary , and was tired enough to be very glad of [Charles]95-charles 's other arm ; but [Charles]95-charles , though in very good humour with [her]93-anne , was out of temper with [[his]95-charles wife]222-his wife . [Mary]94-mary had shewn [herself]94-mary disobliging to [him]95-charles , and was now to reap the consequence , which consequence was [his]95-charles dropping [her]94-mary arm almost every moment to cut off the heads of some nettles in the hedge with [his]95-charles switch ; and when [Mary]94-mary began to complain of it , and lament [her]94-mary being ill - used , according to custom , in being on the hedge side , while [Anne]93-anne was never incommoded on the other , [he]95-charles dropped the arms of both to hunt after a weasel which [he]95-charles had a momentary glance of , and [they]1036-they could hardly get [him]95-charles along at all .

[This long meadow]1037-this long meadow bordered a lane , which [their]1036-they footpath , at the end of [it]1038-it was to cross , and when [the party]542-the party had all reached the gate of exit , the carriage advancing in the same direction , which had been some time heard , was just coming up , and proved to be [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft 's gig . [He]95-charles and [[his]95-charles wife]222-his wife had taken [their]1036-they intended drive , and were returning [home]285-home . Upon hearing how long a walk [the young people]585-the young people had engaged in , [they]1036-they kindly offered a seat to [any lady who might be particularly tired]1043-any lady who might be particularly tired ; it would save [her]1043-any lady who might be particularly tired a full mile , and [they]1036-they were going through [Uppercross]4-uppercross . The invitation was general , and generally declined . [The Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves were not at all tired , and [Mary]94-mary was either offended , by not being asked before any of [the others]359-the others , or what [Louisa]124-louisa called [the Elliot]93-anne pride could not endure to make a third in a one horse chaise .

[The walking party]1045-the walking party had crossed [the lane]1046-the lane , and were surmounting an opposite stile , and [the Admiral]411-the admiral was putting [his]95-charles horse in motion again , when [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth cleared the hedge in a moment to say something to [[his]95-charles sister]799-his sister . The something might be guessed by its effects .

" [Miss Elliot]93-anne , [I]112-mrs croft am sure [you]93-anne are tired , "[112-mrs croft] cried [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft . " Do let [us]1036-they have the pleasure of taking [you]93-anne [home]285-home . [Here]2340-here is excellent room for three , [I]112-mrs croft assure [you]93-anne . If [we]1036-they were all like [you]93-anne , [I]112-mrs croft believe [we]1036-they might sit four . [You]93-anne must , indeed , [you]93-anne must . "[112-mrs croft]

[Anne]93-anne was still in [the lane]1046-the lane ; and though instinctively beginning to decline , [she]93-anne was not allowed to proceed . [The Admiral]411-the admiral 's kind urgency came in support of [[his]411-the admiral wife]222-his wife 's ; [they]1052-they would not be refused ; [they]1052-they compressed [themselves]1052-they into the smallest possible space to leave [her]222-his wife a corner , and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , without saying a word , turned to [her]222-his wife , and quietly obliged [her]222-his wife to be assisted into [the carriage]683-the carriage .

Yes ; [he]117-captain wentworth had done it . [She]222-his wife was in [the carriage]683-the carriage , and felt that [he]117-captain wentworth had placed [her]222-his wife there , that [his]117-captain wentworth will and [his]117-captain wentworth hands had done it , that [she]222-his wife owed it to [his]117-captain wentworth perception of [her]222-his wife fatigue , and [his]117-captain wentworth resolution to give [her]222-his wife rest . [She]222-his wife was very much affected by the view of [his]117-captain wentworth disposition towards [her]222-his wife , which all these things made apparent . This little circumstance seemed the completion of all that had gone before . [She]222-his wife understood [him]117-captain wentworth . [He]117-captain wentworth could not forgive [her]222-his wife , but [he]117-captain wentworth could not be unfeeling . Though condemning [her]222-his wife for the past , and considering it with high and unjust resentment , though perfectly careless of [her]222-his wife , and though becoming attached to [another]1055-another , still [he]117-captain wentworth could not see [her]222-his wife suffer , without the desire of giving [her]222-his wife relief . It was a remainder of former sentiment ; it was an impulse of pure , though unacknowledged friendship ; it was a proof of [his]117-captain wentworth own warm and amiable heart , which [she]222-his wife could not contemplate without emotions so compounded of pleasure and pain , that [she]222-his wife knew not which prevailed .

[Her]222-his wife answers to the kindness and the remarks of [[her]222-his wife companions]1056-her companions were at first unconsciously given . [They]1057-we had travelled half [their]1057-we way along [the rough lane]1058-the rough lane , before [she]222-his wife was quite awake to what [they]1057-we said . [She]222-his wife then found [them]1057-we talking of " [Frederick]117-captain wentworth . "[222-his wife]

" [He]117-captain wentworth certainly means to have one or other of [those two girls]2668-those two girls , [Sophy]135-sophy , "[411-the admiral] said [the Admiral]411-the admiral ; " but there is no saying which . [He]117-captain wentworth has been running after [them]2668-those two girls , too , long enough , [one]252-one would think , to make up [his]117-captain wentworth mind . Ay , this comes of the peace . If it were war now , [he]117-captain wentworth would have settled it long ago . [[We]1057-we sailors]2670-we sailors , [Miss Elliot]93-anne , can not afford to make long courtships in time of war . How many days was it , [[my]411-the admiral dear]2319-my dear , between the first time of [my]411-the admiral seeing [you]2319-my dear and [our]1057-we sitting down together in [[our]1057-we lodgings at [North Yarmouth]47-north yarmouth]2672-our lodgings at north yarmouth ? "[411-the admiral]

" [We]1057-we had better not talk about it , [[my]112-mrs croft dear]2319-my dear , "[112-mrs croft] replied [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , pleasantly ; " for if [Miss Elliot]93-anne were to hear how soon [we]1057-we came to an understanding , [she]93-anne would never be persuaded that [we]1057-we could be happy together . [I]112-mrs croft had known [you]2319-my dear by character , however , long before . "[112-mrs croft]

" Well , and [I]1060-i had heard of [you]2319-my dear as [a very pretty girl]273-a very pretty girl , and what were [we]1057-we to wait for besides ? [I]1060-i do not like having such things so long in hand . [I]1060-i wish [Frederick]117-captain wentworth would spread a little more canvass , and bring [us]1057-we home one of [these young ladies]2675-these young ladies to [Kellynch]6-kellynch . Then there would always be company for [them]2675-these young ladies . And [very nice young ladies]2676-very nice young ladies [they]2675-these young ladies both are ; [I]1060-i hardly know one from [the other]254-the other . "[1060-i]

" Very good humoured , [unaffected girls]2678-unaffected girls , indeed , "[112-mrs croft] said [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , in a tone of calmer praise , such as made [Anne]93-anne suspect that [her]93-anne keener powers might not consider either of [them]1060-i as quite worthy of [[her]93-anne brother]2431-her brother ; " and [a very respectable family]2679-a very respectable family . [One]252-one could not be connected with [better people]2681-better people . [[My]112-mrs croft dear]2319-my dear Admiral , that post ! [we]1060-i shall certainly take that post . "[112-mrs croft]

But by coolly giving the reins a better direction [herself]93-anne [they]1060-i happily passed the danger ; and by once afterwards judiciously putting out [her]93-anne hand [they]1060-i neither fell into a rut , nor ran foul of [a dung - cart]1062-a dung - cart ; and [Anne]93-anne , with some amusement at [their]1060-i style of driving , which [she]93-anne imagined no bad representation of the general guidance of [their]1060-i affairs , found [herself]93-anne safely deposited by [them]1060-i at [the Cottage]608-the cottage .

Chapter 11

The time now approached for [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's return : the day was even fixed ; and [Anne]93-anne , being engaged to join [her]93-anne as soon as [she]93-anne was resettled , was looking forward to an early removal to [Kellynch]6-kellynch , and beginning to think how [her]93-anne own comfort was likely to be affected by it .

It would place [her]93-anne in [the same village]1064-the same village with [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , within half a mile of [him]117-captain wentworth ; [they]1060-i would have to frequent [the same church]1065-the same church , and there must be intercourse between [the two families]565-the two families . This was against [her]93-anne ; but on the other hand , [he]117-captain wentworth spent so much of [his]117-captain wentworth time at [Uppercross]4-uppercross , that in removing thence [she]93-anne might be considered rather as leaving [him]117-captain wentworth behind , than as going towards [him]117-captain wentworth ; and , upon the whole , [she]93-anne believed [she]93-anne must , on this interesting question , be [the gainer]1067-the gainer , almost as certainly as in [her]93-anne change of domestic society , in leaving poor [Mary]94-mary for [Lady Russell]101-lady russell .

[She]93-anne wished it might be possible for [her]93-anne to avoid ever seeing [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth at [the Hall]1068-the hall : [those rooms]1069-those rooms had witnessed former meetings which would be brought too painfully before [her]93-anne ; but [she]93-anne was yet more anxious for the possibility of [Lady Russell]101-lady russell and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth never meeting anywhere . [They]1070-them did not like [each other]489-each other , and no renewal of acquaintance now could do any good ; and were [Lady Russell]101-lady russell to see [them]1070-them together , [she]93-anne might think that [he]117-captain wentworth had too much self - possession , and [she]93-anne too little .

These points formed [her]93-anne chief solicitude in anticipating [her]93-anne removal from [Uppercross]4-uppercross , where [she]93-anne felt [she]93-anne had been stationed quite long enough . [Her]93-anne usefulness to [little Charles]95-charles would always give some sweetness to the memory of [her]93-anne two months ' visit [there]377-there , but [he]117-captain wentworth was gaining strength apace , and [she]93-anne had nothing else to stay for .

The conclusion of [her]93-anne visit , however , was diversified in a way which [she]93-anne had not at all imagined . [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , after being unseen and unheard of at [Uppercross]4-uppercross for two whole days , appeared again among [them]1070-them to justify [himself]117-captain wentworth by a relation of what had kept [him]117-captain wentworth away .

A letter from [[his]117-captain wentworth friend]1073-his friend , [Captain Harville]153-captain harville , having found [him]117-captain wentworth out at last , had brought intelligence of [Captain Harville]153-captain harville 's being settled with [[his]153-captain harville family]221-his family at [Lyme]48-lyme for the winter ; of [their]1075-their being therefore , quite unknowingly , within twenty miles of each other . [Captain Harville]153-captain harville had never been in good health since a severe wound which [he]153-captain harville received two years before , and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's anxiety to see [him]153-captain harville had determined [him]117-captain wentworth to go immediately to [Lyme]48-lyme . [He]117-captain wentworth had been [there]377-there for four - and - twenty hours . [His]117-captain wentworth acquittal was complete , [his]117-captain wentworth friendship warmly honoured , a lively interest excited for [[his]117-captain wentworth friend]1073-his friend , and [his]117-captain wentworth description of [the fine country about [Lyme]48-lyme]1078-the fine country about lyme so feelingly attended to by [the party]542-the party , that an earnest desire to see [Lyme]48-lyme [themselves]1075-their , and a project for going thither was the consequence .

[The young people]585-the young people were all wild to see [Lyme]48-lyme . [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth talked of going [there]377-there again [himself]117-captain wentworth , it was only seventeen miles from [Uppercross]4-uppercross ; though November , the weather was by no means bad ; and , in short , [Louisa]124-louisa , who was the most eager of the eager , having formed the resolution to go , and besides the pleasure of doing as [she]124-louisa liked , being now armed with the idea of merit in maintaining [her]124-louisa own way , bore down all the wishes of [[her]124-louisa father]274-her father and [mother]473-mother for putting it off till summer ; and to [Lyme]48-lyme [they]585-the young people were to go -- [Charles]95-charles , [Mary]94-mary , [Anne]93-anne , [Henrietta]123-henrietta , [Louisa]124-louisa , and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth .

The first heedless scheme had been to go in the morning and return at night ; but to this [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove , for the sake of [his]120-mrs musgrove horses , would not consent ; and when it came to be rationally considered , a day in the middle of November would not leave much time for seeing [a new place]1084-a new place , after deducting seven hours , as the nature of [the country]287-the country required , for going and returning . [They]585-the young people were , consequently , to stay the night there , and not to be expected back till the next day 's dinner . This was felt to be a considerable amendment ; and though [they]585-the young people all met at [the Great House]564-the great house at rather an early breakfast hour , and set off very punctually , it was so much past noon before [the two carriages]1087-the two carriages , [[Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove 's coach]1088-mr musgrove 's coach containing [the four ladies]1089-the four ladies , and [[Charles]95-charles 's curricle]1090-charles 's curricle , in which [he]120-mrs musgrove drove [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , were descending [the long hill]1091-the long hill into [Lyme]48-lyme , and entering upon [the still steeper street]1092-the still steeper street of [the town]1093-the town itself , that it was very evident [they]585-the young people would not have more than time for looking about [them]585-the young people , before the light and warmth of the day were gone .

After securing accommodations , and ordering a dinner at [one of [the inns]1095-the inns]1094-one of the inns , the next thing to be done was unquestionably to walk directly down to [the sea]2296-the sea . [They]585-the young people were come too late in the year for any amusement or variety which [Lyme]48-lyme , as [a public place]1097-a public place , might offer . [The rooms]1098-the rooms were shut up , [the lodgers]1099-the lodgers almost all gone , [scarcely any family]1100-scarcely any family but of [the residents]1101-the residents left ; and , as there is nothing to admire in [the buildings themselves]1102-the buildings themselves , the remarkable situation of [the town]1093-the town , [the principal street]1104-the principal street almost hurrying into [the water]1105-the water , the walk to [the Cobb]49-the cobb , skirting round [the pleasant little bay]1106-the pleasant little bay , which , in the season , is animated with bathing machines and company ; the Cobb itself , [its]49-the cobb old wonders and new improvements , with the very beautiful line of cliffs stretching out to [the east of [the town]1093-the town]1107-the east of the town , are what [the stranger]1109-the stranger 's eye will seek ; and [a very strange stranger]1110-a very strange stranger it must be , who does not see charms in [the immediate environs of [Lyme]48-lyme]1111-the immediate environs of lyme , to make [him]1110-a very strange stranger wish to know it better . The scenes in [[its]48-lyme neighbourhood]1112-its neighbourhood , [Charmouth]50-charmouth , with [[its]48-lyme high grounds and extensive sweeps of country]1113-its high grounds and extensive sweeps of country , and still more , [[its]48-lyme sweet , retired bay]1114-its sweet , retired bay , backed by [dark cliffs , where fragments of low rock among the sands]1115-dark cliffs , where fragments of low rock among the sands , make [it]48-lyme [the happiest spot]1116-the happiest spot for watching the flow of the tide , for sitting in unwearied contemplation ; the woody varieties of [the cheerful village of Up Lyme]1117-the cheerful village of up lyme ; and , above all , [Pinny]51-pinny , with [its]51-pinny green chasms between [romantic rocks]1118-romantic rocks , where the scattered forest trees and orchards of luxuriant growth , declare that [many a generation]1119-many a generation must have passed away since the first partial falling of the cliff prepared the ground for such a state , where a scene so wonderful and so lovely is exhibited , as may more than equal any of the resembling scenes of [the far - famed Isle of [Wight]52-wight]1120-the far - famed isle of wight : [these places]1121-these places must be visited , and visited again , to make the worth of [Lyme]48-lyme understood .

[The party from [Uppercross]4-uppercross]1122-the party from uppercross passing down by [the now deserted and melancholy looking rooms]1123-the now deserted and melancholy looking rooms , and still descending , soon found [themselves]1122-the party from uppercross on [the sea - shore]1124-the sea - shore ; and lingering only , as [all]1125-all must linger and gaze on a first return to [the sea]2296-the sea , who ever deserved to look on it at all , proceeded towards [the Cobb]1127-the cobb , equally [their]1122-the party from uppercross object in itself and on [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's account : for in [a small house , near the foot of [an old pier of unknown date]1129-an old pier of unknown date]1128-a small house , near the foot of an old pier of unknown date , were [the Harvilles]154-the harvilles settled . [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth turned in to call on [[his]117-captain wentworth friend]1073-his friend ; [the others]359-the others walked on , and [he]117-captain wentworth was to join [them]359-the others on [the Cobb]1127-the cobb .

[They]359-the others were by no means tired of wondering and admiring ; and not even [Louisa]124-louisa seemed to feel that [they]359-the others had parted with [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth long , when [they]359-the others saw [him]117-captain wentworth coming after [them]359-the others , with [three companions , all well known already , by description , to be [Captain]2535-captain and [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville]1133-three companions , all well known already , by description , to be captain and mrs harville , and [a Captain Benwick , who was staying with [them]359-the others]155-captain benwick .

[Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick had some time ago been [first lieutenant of [the Laconia]23-the laconia]1135-first lieutenant of the laconia ; and the account which [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth had given of [him]155-captain benwick , on [his]155-captain benwick return from [Lyme]48-lyme before , [his]117-captain wentworth warm praise of [him]155-captain benwick as [an excellent young man]1136-an excellent young man and [an officer]1137-an officer , whom [he]155-captain benwick had always valued highly , which must have stamped [him]155-captain benwick well in the esteem of [every listener]1138-every listener , had been followed by a little history of [his]155-captain benwick private life , which rendered [him]155-captain benwick perfectly interesting in the eyes of [all the ladies]1139-all the ladies . [He]155-captain benwick had been engaged to [[Captain Harville]153-captain harville 's sister]1140-captain harville 's sister , and was now mourning [her]1140-captain harville 's sister loss . [They]1141-they had been a year or two waiting for fortune and promotion . [Fortune]156-fortune came , [his]155-captain benwick prize - money as [lieutenant]1142-lieutenant being great ; promotion , too , came at last ; but [Fanny Harville]157-fanny harville did not live to know it . [She]1140-captain harville 's sister had died the preceding summer while [he]155-captain benwick was at [sea]668-sea . [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth believed it impossible for [man]1144-man to be more attached to [woman]1145-woman than poor [Benwick]155-captain benwick had been to [Fanny Harville]157-fanny harville , or to be more deeply afflicted under the dreadful change . [He]117-captain wentworth considered [his]155-captain benwick disposition as of the sort which must suffer heavily , uniting very strong feelings with quiet , serious , and retiring manners , and a decided taste for reading , and sedentary pursuits . To finish the interest of the story , the friendship between [him]155-captain benwick and [the Harvilles]154-the harvilles seemed , if possible , augmented by the event which closed all [their]1141-they views of alliance , and [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick was now living with [them]1141-they entirely . [Captain Harville]153-captain harville had taken [[his]153-captain harville present house]1146-his present house for half a year ; [his]153-captain harville taste , and [his]153-captain harville health , and [his]153-captain harville fortune , all directing [him]153-captain harville to [a residence inexpensive]1147-a residence inexpensive , and by [the sea]2296-the sea ; and the grandeur of [the country]287-the country , and the retirement of [Lyme]48-lyme in the winter , appeared exactly adapted to [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick 's state of mind . The sympathy and good - will excited towards [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick was very great .

" And yet , "[93-anne] said [Anne]93-anne to [herself]93-anne , as [they]1150-they now moved forward to meet [the party]542-the party , " [he]155-captain benwick has not , perhaps , a more sorrowing heart than [I]93-anne have . [I]93-anne can not believe [his]155-captain benwick prospects so blighted for ever . [He]155-captain benwick is younger than [I]93-anne am ; younger in feeling , if not in fact ; younger as [a man]2277-a man . [He]155-captain benwick will rally again , and be happy with another . "[93-anne]

[They]1150-they all met , and were introduced . [Captain Harville]153-captain harville was [a tall , dark man , with a sensible , benevolent countenance]1152-a tall , dark man , with a sensible , benevolent countenance ; [a little lame]1153-a little lame ; and from strong features and want of health , looking much older than [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick looked , and was , the youngest of the three , and , compared with either of [them]1150-they , [a little man]1154-a little man . [He]155-captain benwick had a pleasing face and a melancholy air , just as [he]155-captain benwick ought to have , and drew back from conversation .

[Captain Harville]153-captain harville , though not equalling [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth in manners , was [a perfect gentleman , unaffected , warm , and obliging]1155-a perfect gentleman , unaffected , warm , and obliging . [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville , a degree less polished than [[her]140-mrs harville husband]2315-her husband , seemed , however , to have the same good feelings ; and nothing could be more pleasant than [their]1150-they desire of considering the whole party as friends of [their]1150-they own , because [the friends of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth]1157-the friends of captain wentworth , or more kindly hospitable than [their]1150-they entreaties for [their]1150-they all promising to dine with [them]1150-they . The dinner , already ordered at [the inn]1158-the inn , was at last , though unwillingly , accepted as a excuse ; but [they]1150-they seemed almost hurt that [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth should have brought [any such party to [Lyme]48-lyme]1159-any such party to lyme , without considering it as a thing of course that [they]1150-they should dine with [them]1150-they .

There was so much attachment to [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth in all this , and such a bewitching charm in a degree of hospitality so uncommon , so unlike the usual style of give - and - take invitations , and dinners of formality and display , that [Anne]93-anne felt [her]93-anne spirits not likely to be benefited by an increasing acquaintance among [[his]117-captain wentworth brother - officers]1160-his brother - officers . " These would have been all [[my]93-anne friends]2684-my friends , "[93-anne] was [her]93-anne thought ; and [she]93-anne had to struggle against a great tendency to lowness .

On quitting [the Cobb]49-the cobb , [they]1150-they all went in - doors with [[their]1150-they new friends]1161-their new friends , and found rooms so small as none but [those who invite from the heart]1162-those who invite from the heart could think capable of accommodating [so many]1163-so many . [Anne]93-anne had a moment 's astonishment on the subject [herself]93-anne ; but it was soon lost in the pleasanter feelings which sprang from the sight of all the ingenious contrivances and nice arrangements of [Captain Harville]153-captain harville , to turn the actual space to the best account , to supply the deficiencies of [lodging - house]1164-lodging - house furniture , and defend the windows and doors against the winter storms to be expected . The varieties in the fitting - up of [the rooms]1098-the rooms , where the common necessaries provided by [the owner , in the common indifferent plight]1166-the owner , in the common indifferent plight , were contrasted with some few articles of a rare species of wood , excellently worked up , and with something curious and valuable from [all the distant countries [Captain Harville]153-captain harville had visited]1167-all the distant countries captain harville had visited , were more than amusing to [Anne]93-anne ; connected as it all was with [his]153-captain harville profession , the fruit of its labours , the effect of its influence on [his]153-captain harville habits , the picture of repose and domestic happiness it presented , made it to [her]93-anne a something more , or less , than gratification .

[Captain Harville]153-captain harville was [no reader]1168-no reader ; but [he]153-captain harville had contrived excellent accommodations , and fashioned very pretty shelves , for a tolerable collection of well - bound volumes , the property of [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick . [His]153-captain harville lameness prevented [him]153-captain harville from taking much exercise ; but a mind of usefulness and ingenuity seemed to furnish [him]153-captain harville with constant employment within . [He]153-captain harville drew , [he]153-captain harville varnished , [he]153-captain harville carpentered , [he]153-captain harville glued ; [he]153-captain harville made toys for [the children]610-the children ; [he]153-captain harville fashioned new netting - needles and pins with improvements ; and if everything else was done , sat down to [his]153-captain harville large fishing - net at one corner of [the room]406-the room .

[Anne]93-anne thought [she]93-anne left great happiness behind [her]93-anne when [they]1171-they quitted [the house]310-the house ; and [Louisa]124-louisa , by whom [she]93-anne found [herself]93-anne walking , burst forth into raptures of admiration and delight on the character of [the navy]2245-the navy ; [their]1171-they friendliness , [their]1171-they brotherliness , [their]1171-they openness , [their]1171-they uprightness ; protesting that [she]93-anne was convinced of [sailors]2271-sailors having more worth and warmth than [any other set of men in [England]17-england]1175-any other set of men in england ; that [they]1171-they only knew how to live , and [they]1171-they only deserved to be respected and loved .

[They]1171-they went back to dress and dine ; and so well had the scheme answered already , that nothing was found amiss ; though its being " so entirely out of season , "[1176-the heads of the inn] and the " no thoroughfare of [Lyme]48-lyme , "[1176-the heads of the inn] and the " no expectation of company , "[1176-the heads of the inn] had brought many apologies from [the heads of [the inn]1158-the inn]1176-the heads of the inn .

[Anne]93-anne found [herself]93-anne by this time growing so much more hardened to being in [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's company than [she]93-anne had at first imagined could ever be , that the sitting down to the same table with [him]117-captain wentworth now , and the interchange of [the common civilities attending on it]1178-the common civilities attending on it ( [they]1171-they never got beyond ) , was become a mere nothing .

The nights were too dark for [the ladies]1179-the ladies to meet again till the morrow , but [Captain Harville]153-captain harville had promised [them]1179-the ladies a visit in the evening ; and [he]153-captain harville came , bringing [[his]153-captain harville friend]1073-his friend also , which was more than had been expected , it having been agreed that [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick had all the appearance of being oppressed by the presence of so many [strangers]810-strangers . [He]155-captain benwick ventured among [them]1179-the ladies again , however , though [his]155-captain benwick spirits certainly did not seem fit for the mirth of [the party]542-the party in general .

While [Captains Wentworth]158-captains wentworth and [Harville]153-captain harville led the talk on one side of [the room]406-the room , and by recurring to former days , supplied anecdotes in abundance to occupy and entertain [the others]359-the others , it fell to [Anne]93-anne 's lot to be placed rather apart with [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick ; and a very good impulse of [her]93-anne nature obliged [her]93-anne to begin an acquaintance with [him]155-captain benwick . [He]155-captain benwick was shy , and disposed to abstraction ; but the engaging mildness of [her]93-anne countenance , and gentleness of [her]93-anne manners , soon had their effect ; and [Anne]93-anne was well repaid the first trouble of exertion . [He]155-captain benwick was evidently [a young man of considerable taste in reading , though principally in poetry]1185-a young man of considerable taste in reading , though principally in poetry ; and besides the persuasion of having given [him]155-captain benwick at least an evening 's indulgence in the discussion of subjects , which [[his]155-captain benwick usual companions]1186-his usual companions had probably no concern in , [she]93-anne had the hope of being of real use to [him]155-captain benwick in some suggestions as to the duty and benefit of struggling against affliction , which had naturally grown out of [their]1187-their conversation . For , though shy , [he]155-captain benwick did not seem reserved ; it had rather the appearance of feelings glad to burst their usual restraints ; and having talked of poetry , the richness of the present age , and gone through a brief comparison of opinion as to [the first - rate poets]1188-the first - rate poets , trying to ascertain whether [Marmion]159-marmion or [The Lady of the Lake]1189-the lady of the lake were to be preferred , and how ranked [the Giaour]160-the giaour and [The Bride of [Abydos]53-abydos]1190-the bride of abydos ; and moreover , how [the Giaour]160-the giaour was to be pronounced , [he]155-captain benwick showed [himself]155-captain benwick so intimately acquainted with all the tenderest songs of [the one poet]1191-the one poet , and all the impassioned descriptions of hopeless agony of the other ; [he]155-captain benwick repeated , with such tremulous feeling , the various lines which imaged a broken heart , or a mind destroyed by wretchedness , and looked so entirely as if [he]155-captain benwick meant to be understood , that [she]93-anne ventured to hope [he]155-captain benwick did not always read only poetry , and to say , that [she]93-anne thought it was the misfortune of poetry to be seldom safely enjoyed by [those who enjoyed it completely]1192-those who enjoyed it completely ; and that the strong feelings which alone could estimate it truly were the very feelings which ought to taste it but sparingly .

[His]155-captain benwick looks shewing [him]155-captain benwick not pained , but pleased with this allusion to [his]155-captain benwick situation , [she]93-anne was emboldened to go on ; and feeling in [herself]93-anne the right of seniority of mind , [she]93-anne ventured to recommend a larger allowance of prose in [his]155-captain benwick daily study ; and on being requested to particularize , mentioned such works of [[our]1193-our best moralists]1194-our best moralists , such collections of the finest letters , such memoirs of characters of worth and suffering , as occurred to [her]93-anne at the moment as calculated to rouse and fortify the mind by the highest precepts , and the strongest examples of moral and religious endurances .

[Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick listened attentively , and seemed grateful for the interest implied ; and though with a shake of the head , and sighs which declared [his]155-captain benwick little faith in the efficacy of any books on grief like [his]155-captain benwick , noted down the names of those [she]93-anne recommended , and promised to procure and read them .

When the evening was over , [Anne]93-anne could not but be amused at the idea of [her]93-anne coming to [Lyme]48-lyme to preach patience and resignation to [a young man whom [she]93-anne had never seen before]1195-a young man whom she had never seen before ; nor could [she]93-anne help fearing , on more serious reflection , that , like [many other great moralists and preachers]1196-many other great moralists and preachers , [she]93-anne had been eloquent on a point in which [her]93-anne own conduct would ill bear examination .

Chapter 12

[Anne]93-anne and [Henrietta]123-henrietta , finding [themselves]1197-they [the earliest of the party the next morning]1198-the earliest of the party the next morning , agreed to stroll down to [the sea]2296-the sea before breakfast . [They]1197-they went to [the sands]1200-the sands , to watch the flowing of the tide , which a fine south - easterly breeze was bringing in with all the grandeur which so flat [a shore]1201-a shore admitted . [They]1197-they praised the morning ; gloried in [the sea]2296-the sea ; sympathized in the delight of the fresh - feeling breeze -- and were silent ; till [Henrietta]123-henrietta suddenly began again with--

" Oh ! yes,--I am quite convinced that , with very few exceptions , [the sea]2296-the sea - air always does good . There can be no doubt of its having been of the greatest service to [Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley , after [his]152-dr shirley illness , last spring twelve - month . [He]152-dr shirley declares [himself]152-dr shirley , that coming to [Lyme]48-lyme for a month , did [him]152-dr shirley more good than all the medicine [he]152-dr shirley took ; and , that being by [the sea]2296-the sea , always makes [him]152-dr shirley feel young again . Now , [I]123-henrietta can not help thinking it a pity that [he]152-dr shirley does not live entirely by [the sea]2296-the sea . [I]123-henrietta do think [he]152-dr shirley had better leave [Uppercross]4-uppercross entirely , and fix at [Lyme]48-lyme . Do not [you]2688-you , [Anne]93-anne ? Do not [you]2688-you agree with [me]123-henrietta , that it is the best thing [he]152-dr shirley could do , both for [himself]152-dr shirley and [Mrs Shirley]161-mrs shirley ? [She]161-mrs shirley has [cousins]1010-cousins [here]2340-here , [you]2688-you know , and many acquaintance , which would make it cheerful for [her]161-mrs shirley , and [I]123-henrietta am sure [she]161-mrs shirley would be glad to get to a place where [she]161-mrs shirley could have medical attendance at hand , in case of [his]152-dr shirley having another seizure . Indeed [I]123-henrietta think it quite melancholy to have such excellent people as [Dr]152-dr shirley and [Mrs Shirley]161-mrs shirley , who have been doing good all [their]2691-their lives , wearing out [their]2691-their last days in [a place like [Uppercross]4-uppercross , where , excepting [[our]2693-our family]2694-our family , [they]2691-their seem shut out from all [the world]237-the world]2692-a place like uppercross , where , excepting our family , they seem shut out from all the world . [I]123-henrietta wish [[his]152-dr shirley friends]361-his friends would propose it to [him]152-dr shirley . [I]123-henrietta really think [they]361-his friends ought . And , as to procuring a dispensation , there could be no difficulty at [his]152-dr shirley time of life , and with [his]152-dr shirley character . [My]123-henrietta only doubt is , whether anything could persuade [him]152-dr shirley to leave [[his]152-dr shirley parish]2697-his parish . [He]152-dr shirley is so very strict and scrupulous in [his]152-dr shirley notions ; over - scrupulous [I]123-henrietta must say . Do not [you]93-anne think , [Anne]93-anne , it is being over - scrupulous ? Do not [you]93-anne think it is quite a mistaken point of conscience , when [a clergyman]2698-a clergyman sacrifices [his]152-dr shirley health for the sake of duties , which may be just as well performed by [another person]2699-another person ? And at [Lyme]48-lyme too , only seventeen miles off , [he]152-dr shirley would be near enough to hear , if [people]2377-people thought there was anything to complain of . "[123-henrietta]

[Anne]93-anne smiled more than once to [herself]93-anne during this speech , and entered into the subject , as ready to do good by entering into the feelings of [a young lady]1203-a young lady as of [a young man]468-a young man , though here it was good of a lower standard , for what could be offered but general acquiescence ? [She]93-anne said all that was reasonable and proper on the business ; felt the claims of [Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley to repose as [she]93-anne ought ; saw how very desirable it was that [he]152-dr shirley should have [some active , respectable young man]1205-some active , respectable young man , as [a resident curate]1206-a resident curate , and was even courteous enough to hint at the advantage of [such resident curate]1207-such resident curate 's being married .

" [I]123-henrietta wish , "[123-henrietta] said [Henrietta]123-henrietta , very well pleased with [[her]123-henrietta companion]1208-her companion , " [I]123-henrietta wish [Lady Russell]101-lady russell lived at [Uppercross]4-uppercross , and were intimate with [Dr Shirley]152-dr shirley . [I]123-henrietta have always heard of [Lady Russell]101-lady russell as [a woman of the greatest influence with everybody]2701-a woman of the greatest influence with everybody ! [I]123-henrietta always look upon [her]101-lady russell as able to persuade [a person]2702-a person to anything ! [I]123-henrietta am afraid of [her]101-lady russell , as [I]123-henrietta have told [you]93-anne before , quite afraid of [her]101-lady russell , because [she]101-lady russell is so very clever ; but [I]123-henrietta respect [her]101-lady russell amazingly , and wish [we]2703-we had [such a neighbour at [Uppercross]4-uppercross]2704-such a neighbour at uppercross . "[123-henrietta]

[Anne]93-anne was amused by [Henrietta]123-henrietta 's manner of being grateful , and amused also that the course of events and the new interests of [Henrietta]123-henrietta 's views should have placed [[her]93-anne friend]546-her friend at all in favour with [any of [the Musgrove family]1211-the musgrove family]1210-any of the musgrove family ; [she]93-anne had only time , however , for a general answer , and a wish that [such another woman]1212-such another woman were at [Uppercross]4-uppercross , before [all subjects]1213-all subjects suddenly ceased , on seeing [Louisa]124-louisa and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth coming towards [them]1214-they . [They]1214-they came also for a stroll till breakfast was likely to be ready ; but [Louisa]124-louisa recollecting , immediately afterwards that [she]124-louisa had something to procure at [a shop]1215-a shop , invited [them]1214-they all to go back with [her]124-louisa into [the town]1093-the town . [They]1214-they were all at [her]124-louisa disposal .

When [they]1214-they came to the steps , leading upwards from [the beach]1217-the beach , [a gentleman , at the same moment preparing to come down]1218-a gentleman , at the same moment preparing to come down , politely drew back , and stopped to give [them]1214-they way . [They]1214-they ascended and passed [him]1218-a gentleman , at the same moment preparing to come down ; and as [they]1214-they passed , [Anne]93-anne 's face caught [his]1218-a gentleman , at the same moment preparing to come down eye , and [he]1218-a gentleman , at the same moment preparing to come down looked at [her]93-anne with a degree of earnest admiration , which [she]93-anne could not be insensible of . [She]93-anne was looking remarkably well ; [her]93-anne very regular , very pretty features , having the bloom and freshness of youth restored by the fine wind which had been blowing on [her]93-anne complexion , and by the animation of eye which it had also produced . It was evident that [the gentleman]2219-the gentleman , ( completely [a gentleman in manner]1220-a gentleman in manner ) admired [her]93-anne exceedingly . [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth looked round at [her]93-anne instantly in a way which [shewed]1221-shewed [his]1218-a gentleman , at the same moment preparing to come down noticing of it . [He]117-captain wentworth gave [her]93-anne a momentary glance , a glance of brightness , which seemed to say , " [That man]2705-that man is struck with [you]93-anne , and even [I]117-captain wentworth , at this moment , see something like [Anne Elliot]93-anne again . "[117-captain wentworth]

After attending [Louisa]124-louisa through [her]124-louisa business , and loitering about a little longer , [they]1222-they returned to [the inn]1158-the inn ; and [Anne]93-anne , in passing afterwards quickly from [[her]93-anne own chamber]1224-her own chamber to [[their]1222-they dining - room]1225-their dining - room , had nearly run against [the very same gentleman]1226-the very same gentleman , as [he]1226-the very same gentleman came out of [an adjoining apartment]1227-an adjoining apartment . [She]93-anne had before conjectured [him]1226-the very same gentleman to be [a stranger like [themselves]1222-they]1228-a stranger like themselves , and determined that [a well - looking groom , who was strolling about near [the two inns]1230-the two inns as [they]1222-they came back]1229-a well - looking groom , who was strolling about near the two inns as they came back , should be [[his]1226-the very same gentleman servant]1231-his servant . [Both master]1232-both master and [man]1144-man being in mourning assisted the idea . It was now proved that [he]1226-the very same gentleman belonged to [the same inn]1234-the same inn as [themselves]1222-they ; and this second meeting , short as it was , also proved again by [the gentleman]2219-the gentleman 's looks , that [he]1226-the very same gentleman thought [hers]93-anne very lovely , and by the readiness and propriety of [his]1226-the very same gentleman apologies , that [he]1226-the very same gentleman was [a man of exceedingly good manners]1236-a man of exceedingly good manners . [He]1226-the very same gentleman seemed about thirty , and though not handsome , had [an agreeable person]1237-an agreeable person . [Anne]93-anne felt that [she]93-anne should like to know who [he]1226-the very same gentleman was .

[They]1222-they had nearly done breakfast , when the sound of [a carriage]2371-a carriage , ( almost the first [they]1222-they had heard since entering [Lyme]48-lyme ) drew half [the party]542-the party to the window . It was [[a gentleman]374-a gentleman 's carriage]1241-a gentleman 's carriage , a curricle , but only coming round from [the stable - yard]1242-the stable - yard to the front door ; [somebody]1243-somebody must be going away . It was driven by [a servant in mourning]1244-a servant in mourning .

The word curricle made [Charles Musgrove]96-charles jump up that [he]1226-the very same gentleman might compare it with [his]1226-the very same gentleman own ; [the servant in mourning]1245-the servant in mourning roused [Anne]93-anne 's curiosity , and [the whole six]979-the whole six were collected to look , by the time [the owner of the curricle]1247-the owner of the curricle was to be seen issuing from the door amidst the bows and civilities of [the household]1248-the household , and taking [his]1247-the owner of the curricle seat , to drive off .

" Ah ! "[117-captain wentworth] cried [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , instantly , and with half a glance at [Anne]93-anne , " it is [the very man [we]979-the whole six passed]2706-the very man we passed . "[117-captain wentworth]

[The Miss Musgroves]121-the miss musgroves agreed to it ; and having all kindly watched [him]1247-the owner of the curricle as far up [the hill]1013-the hill as [they]979-the whole six could , [they]979-the whole six returned to the breakfast table . [The waiter]1250-the waiter came into [the room]406-the room soon afterwards .

" Pray , "[117-captain wentworth] said [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , immediately , " can [you]117-captain wentworth tell [us]979-the whole six the name of [the gentleman who is just gone away]2707-the gentleman who is just gone away ? "[117-captain wentworth]

" Yes , [Sir]2533-sir , [a Mr Elliot]2709-a mr elliot , [a gentleman of large fortune]2710-a gentleman of large fortune , came in last night from [Sidmouth]54-sidmouth . Dare say [you]2533-sir heard [the carriage]683-the carriage , [sir]2533-sir , while [you]2533-sir were at dinner ; and going on now for [Crewkherne]162-crewkherne , in [his]162-crewkherne way to [Bath]10-bath and [London]7-london . "[1250-the waiter]

" [Elliot]93-anne ! "[117-captain wentworth] [Many]1252-many had looked on [each other]489-each other , and [many]1252-many had repeated the name , before all this had been got through , even by the smart rapidity of [a waiter]1255-a waiter .

" Bless [me]94-mary ! "[94-mary] cried [Mary]94-mary ; " it must be [[our]2713-our cousin]2714-our cousin ; it must be [[our]2713-our [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot]2715-our mr elliot , it must , indeed ! [Charles]96-charles , [Anne]93-anne , must not it ? In mourning , [you]2533-sir see , just as [[our]2713-our Mr [Elliot]102-mr elliot]2715-our mr elliot must be . How very extraordinary ! [[my]1250-the waiter father 's next heir]2719-my father 's next heir ? "[1250-the waiter]

" No , [ma'am]2584-ma'am , [he]102-mr elliot did not mention [no particular family]2723-no particular family ; but [he]102-mr elliot said [[his]102-mr elliot master]2724-his master was [a very rich gentleman]2725-a very rich gentleman , and would be [a baronight some day]2726-a baronight some day . "[1255-a waiter]

" There ! [you]2533-sir see ! "[94-mary] cried [Mary]94-mary in an ecstasy , " just as [I]94-mary said ! Heir to [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter ! [I]94-mary was sure that would come out , if it was so . Depend upon it , that is a circumstance which [[his]102-mr elliot servants]2727-his servants take care to publish , wherever [he]102-mr elliot goes . But , [Anne]93-anne , only conceive how extraordinary ! [I]94-mary wish [I]94-mary had looked at [him]102-mr elliot more . [I]94-mary wish [we]2728-we had been aware in time , who it was , that [he]102-mr elliot might have been introduced to [us]2728-we . What a pity that [we]2728-we should not have been introduced to [each other]489-each other ! Do [you]2533-sir think [he]102-mr elliot had the [Elliot]102-mr elliot countenance ? Oh ! the great - coat was hanging over the panel , and hid the arms , so it did ; otherwise , [I]94-mary am sure , [I]94-mary should have observed them , and the livery too ; if [the servant]2730-the servant had not been in mourning , [one]252-one should have known [him]102-mr elliot by the livery . "[94-mary]

" Putting all these very extraordinary circumstances together , "[117-captain wentworth] said [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , " [we]1258-their must consider it to be the arrangement of [Providence]118-providence , that [you]93-anne should not be introduced to [[your]93-anne cousin]2732-your cousin . "[117-captain wentworth]

When [she]1257-she could command [Mary]94-mary 's attention , [Anne]93-anne quietly tried to convince [her]94-mary that [[their]1258-their father]729-their father and [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot had not , for many years , been on such terms as to make the power of attempting an introduction at all desirable .

At the same time , however , it was a secret gratification to [herself]1257-she to have seen [[her]1257-she cousin]2558-her cousin , and to know that [the future owner of [Kellynch]6-kellynch]1261-the future owner of kellynch was undoubtedly [a gentleman]374-a gentleman , and had an air of good sense . [She]1257-she would not , upon any account , mention [her]1257-she having met with [him]102-mr elliot the second time ; luckily [Mary]94-mary did not much attend to [their]1258-their having passed close by [him]102-mr elliot in [their]1258-their earlier walk , but [she]94-mary would have felt quite ill - used by [Anne]93-anne 's having actually run against [him]102-mr elliot in [the passage]1263-the passage , and received [his]102-mr elliot very polite excuses , while [she]1257-she had never been near [him]102-mr elliot at all ; no , that cousinly little interview must remain a perfect secret .

" Of course , "[94-mary] said [Mary]94-mary , " [you]93-anne will mention [our]1258-their seeing [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot , the next time [you]93-anne write to [Bath]10-bath . [I]94-mary think [[my]94-mary father]2247-my father certainly ought to hear of it ; do mention all about [him]102-mr elliot . "[94-mary]

[Anne]93-anne avoided a direct reply , but it was just the circumstance which [she]93-anne considered as not merely unnecessary to be communicated , but as what ought to be suppressed . The offence which had been given [[her]93-anne father]274-her father , many years back , [she]93-anne knew ; [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth 's particular share in it [she]93-anne suspected ; and that [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot 's idea always produced irritation in both was beyond a doubt . [Mary]94-mary never wrote to [Bath]372-bath [herself]94-mary ; all the toil of keeping up a slow and unsatisfactory correspondence with [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth fell on [Anne]93-anne .

Breakfast had not been long over , when [they]1266-they were joined by [Captain]2535-captain and [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville and [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick ; with whom [they]1266-they had appointed to take [their]1266-they last walk about [Lyme]48-lyme . [They]1266-they ought to be setting off for [Uppercross]4-uppercross by one , and in the meanwhile were to be all together , and out of doors as long as [they]1266-they could .

[Anne]93-anne found [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick getting near [her]93-anne , as soon as [they]1266-they were all fairly in [the street]1268-the street . [Their]1266-they conversation the preceding evening did not disincline [him]155-captain benwick to seek [her]93-anne again ; and [they]1266-they walked together some time , talking as before of [Mr Scott]163-mr scott and [Lord Byron]164-lord byron , and still as unable as before , and as unable as [any other two readers]1269-any other two readers , to think exactly alike of the merits of either , till something occasioned an almost general change amongst [[their]1266-they party]1270-their party , and instead of [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick , [she]93-anne had [Captain Harville]153-captain harville by [her]93-anne side .

" [Miss Elliot]93-anne , "[155-captain benwick] said [he]155-captain benwick , speaking rather low , " [you]93-anne have done a good deed in making [that poor fellow]2734-that poor fellow talk so much . [I]155-captain benwick wish [he]2734-that poor fellow could have such company oftener . It is bad for [him]2734-that poor fellow , [I]155-captain benwick know , to be shut up as [he]2734-that poor fellow is ; but what can [we]1266-they do ? [We]1266-they can not part . "[155-captain benwick]

" No , "[93-anne] said [Anne]93-anne , " that [I]93-anne can easily believe to be impossible ; but in time , perhaps -- [we]1266-they know what time does in every case of affliction , and [you]93-anne must remember , [Captain Harville]153-captain harville , that [[your]93-anne friend]2735-your friend may yet be called [a young mourner]2736-a young mourner -- only last summer , [I]93-anne understand . "[93-anne]

" Ay , true enough , "[93-anne] ( with a deep sigh ) " only [June]165-june . "[93-anne]

" And not known to [him]2734-that poor fellow , perhaps , so soon . "[155-captain benwick]

" Not till the first week of August , when [he]2734-that poor fellow came [home]285-home from [the Cape]55-the cape , just made into [the Grappler]2738-the grappler . [I]93-anne was at [Plymouth]28-plymouth dreading to hear of [him]2734-that poor fellow ; [he]2734-that poor fellow sent in letters , but [the Grappler]2738-the grappler was under orders for [Portsmouth]35-portsmouth . There the news must follow [him]2734-that poor fellow , but who was to tell it ? not [I.]93-anne [I]93-anne would as soon have been run up to [the yard - arm]2740-the yard - arm . [Nobody]2242-nobody could do it , but [that good fellow]2742-that good fellow "[93-anne] ( pointing to [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . ) " [The Laconia]23-the laconia had come into [Plymouth]28-plymouth the week before ; no danger of [her]2742-that good fellow being sent to [sea]668-sea again . [He]2734-that poor fellow stood [his]2734-that poor fellow chance for the rest ; wrote up for leave of absence , but without waiting the return , travelled night and day till [he]2734-that poor fellow got to [Portsmouth]35-portsmouth , rowed off to [the Grappler]167-the grappler that instant , and never left [the poor fellow]2744-the poor fellow for a week . That 's what [he]2734-that poor fellow did , and [nobody else]358-nobody else could have saved [poor James]92-james stevenson . [You]93-anne may think , [Miss Elliot]93-anne , whether [he]2734-that poor fellow is dear to [us]2746-us ! "[93-anne]

[Anne]93-anne did think on the question with perfect decision , and said as much in reply as [her]93-anne own feeling could accomplish , or as [his]1271-he seemed able to bear , for [he]1271-he was too much affected to renew the subject , and when [he]1271-he spoke again , it was of something totally different .

[Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville 's giving it as [her]93-anne opinion that [[her]93-anne husband]2315-her husband would have quite walking enough by the time [he]1271-he reached [home]285-home , determined the direction of all the party in what was to be [their]1274-their last walk ; [they]1274-their would accompany [them]1274-their to [their]1274-their door , and then return and set off [themselves]1274-their . By all [their]1274-their calculations there was just time for this ; but as [they]1274-their drew near [the Cobb]49-the cobb , there was such a general wish to walk along [it]49-the cobb once more , [all]1125-all were so inclined , and [Louisa]124-louisa soon grew so determined , that the difference of a quarter of an hour , it was found , would be no difference at all ; so with all the kind leave - taking , and all the kind interchange of invitations and promises which may be imagined , [they]1274-their parted from [Captain]2535-captain and [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville at [their]1274-their own door , and still accompanied by [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick , who seemed to cling to [them]1274-their to the last , proceeded to make the proper adieus to [the Cobb]49-the cobb .

[Anne]93-anne found [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick again drawing near [her]93-anne . [Lord Byron]164-lord byron 's " dark blue seas "[164-lord byron] could not fail of being brought forward by [their]1274-their present view , and [she]93-anne gladly gave [him]164-lord byron all [her]93-anne attention as long as attention was possible . It was soon drawn , perforce another way .

There was too much wind to make the high part of [the new Cobb]1277-the new cobb pleasant for [the ladies]1179-the ladies , and [they]1274-their agreed to get down the steps to the lower , and [all]1125-all were contented to pass quietly and carefully down the steep flight , excepting [Louisa]124-louisa ; [she]124-louisa must be jumped down [them]1280-them by [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . In all [their]1274-their walks , [he]117-captain wentworth had had to jump [her]124-louisa from the stiles ; the sensation was delightful to [her]124-louisa . The hardness of the pavement for [her]124-louisa feet , made [him]117-captain wentworth less willing upon the present occasion ; [he]117-captain wentworth did it , however . [She]124-louisa was safely down , and instantly , to show [her]124-louisa enjoyment , ran up the steps to be jumped down again . [He]117-captain wentworth advised [her]124-louisa against it , thought the jar too great ; but no , [he]117-captain wentworth reasoned and talked in vain , [she]124-louisa smiled and said , " [I]124-louisa am determined [I]124-louisa will : "[124-louisa] [he]117-captain wentworth put out [his]117-captain wentworth hands ; [she]124-louisa was too precipitate by half a second , [she]124-louisa fell on the pavement on [the Lower Cobb]56-the lower cobb , and was taken up lifeless ! There was no wound , no blood , no visible bruise ; but [her]124-louisa eyes were closed , [she]124-louisa breathed not , [her]124-louisa face was like death . The horror of the moment to [all who stood around]1281-all who stood around !

[Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , who had caught [her]124-louisa up , knelt with [her]124-louisa in [his]117-captain wentworth arms , looking on [her]124-louisa with a face as pallid as [her]124-louisa own , in an agony of silence . " [She]124-louisa is dead ! [she]124-louisa is dead ! "[94-mary] screamed [Mary]94-mary , catching hold of [[her]94-mary husband]2315-her husband , and contributing with [his]117-captain wentworth own horror to make [him]2315-her husband immoveable ; and in another moment , [Henrietta]123-henrietta , sinking under the conviction , lost [her]123-henrietta senses too , and would have fallen on the steps , but for [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick and [Anne]93-anne , who caught and supported [her]123-henrietta between [them]1283-them .

" Is there [no one]479-no one to help [me]117-captain wentworth ? "[117-captain wentworth] were the first words which burst from [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , in a tone of despair , and as if all [his]117-captain wentworth own strength were gone .

" Go to [him]2315-her husband , go to [him]2315-her husband , "[93-anne] cried [Anne]93-anne , " for heaven 's sake go to [him]2315-her husband . [I]93-anne can support [her]123-henrietta [myself]93-anne . Leave [me]93-anne , and go to [him]2315-her husband . Rub [her]123-henrietta hands , rub [her]123-henrietta temples ; here are salts ; take them , take them . "[93-anne]

[Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick obeyed , and [Charles]96-charles at the same moment , disengaging [himself]96-charles from [[his]155-captain benwick wife]222-his wife , [they]1285-they were both with [him]155-captain benwick ; and [Louisa]124-louisa was raised up and supported more firmly between [them]1285-they , and everything was done that [Anne]93-anne had prompted , but in vain ; while [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , staggering against the wall for [his]117-captain wentworth support , exclaimed in the bitterest agony--

" Oh [God]141-god ! [[her]123-henrietta father]274-her father and [mother]473-mother ! "[117-captain wentworth]

" [A surgeon]2750-a surgeon ! "[93-anne] said [Anne]93-anne .

[He]117-captain wentworth caught the word ; it seemed to rouse [him]117-captain wentworth at once , and saying only-- " True , true , [a surgeon]2750-a surgeon this instant , "[117-captain wentworth] was darting away , when [Anne]93-anne eagerly suggested--

" [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick , would not it be better for [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick ? [He]155-captain benwick knows where [a surgeon]2750-a surgeon is to be found . "[117-captain wentworth]

[Every one capable of thinking]1286-every one capable of thinking felt the advantage of the idea , and in a moment ( it was all done in rapid moments ) [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick had resigned the poor corpse - like figure entirely to [the brother]865-the brother 's care , and was off for [the town]1093-the town with the utmost rapidity .

As to [the wretched party left behind]1289-the wretched party left behind , it could scarcely be said which of [the three , who were completely rational]1290-the three , who were completely rational , was suffering most : [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , [Anne]93-anne , or [Charles]96-charles , who , really [a very affectionate brother]1291-a very affectionate brother , hung over [Louisa]124-louisa with sobs of grief , and could only turn [his]117-captain wentworth eyes from [one sister]1292-one sister , to see the other in a state as insensible , or to witness the hysterical agitations of [[his]117-captain wentworth wife]222-his wife , calling on [him]117-captain wentworth for help which [he]117-captain wentworth could not give .

[Anne]93-anne , attending with all the strength and zeal , and thought , which instinct supplied , to [Henrietta]123-henrietta , still tried , at intervals , to suggest comfort to [the others]359-the others , tried to quiet [Mary]94-mary , to animate [Charles]96-charles , to assuage the feelings of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth . [Both]1295-both seemed to look to [her]93-anne for directions .

" [Anne]93-anne , [Anne]93-anne , "[96-charles] cried [Charles]96-charles , " What is to be done next ? What , in heaven 's name , is to be done next ? "[96-charles]

[Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's eyes were also turned towards [her]93-anne .

" Had not [she]123-henrietta better be carried to [the inn]1158-the inn ? Yes , [I]1296-the workmen am sure : carry [her]123-henrietta gently to [the inn]1158-the inn . "[1296-the workmen]

" Yes , yes , to [the inn]1158-the inn , "[117-captain wentworth] repeated [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , comparatively collected , and eager to be doing something . " [I]117-captain wentworth will carry [her]123-henrietta [myself]117-captain wentworth . [Musgrove]96-charles , take care of [the others]359-the others . "[117-captain wentworth]

By this time the report of the accident had spread among [the workmen]1296-the workmen and [boatmen]1297-boatmen about [the Cobb]49-the cobb , and [many]1252-many were collected near [them]49-the cobb , to be useful if wanted , at any rate , to enjoy the sight of [a dead young lady]1299-a dead young lady , nay , [two dead young ladies]1300-two dead young ladies , for it proved twice as fine as the first report . To [some of the best - looking of [these good people]1302-these good people]1301-some of the best - looking of these good people [Henrietta]123-henrietta was consigned , for , though partially revived , [she]123-henrietta was quite helpless ; and in this manner , [Anne]93-anne walking by [her]123-henrietta side , and [Charles]96-charles attending to [[his]1303-his wife]222-his wife , [they]1305-they set forward , treading back with feelings unutterable , the ground , which so lately , so very lately , and so light of heart , [they]1305-they had passed along .

[They]1305-they were not off [the Cobb]49-the cobb , before [the Harvilles]154-the harvilles met [them]1305-they . [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick had been seen flying by [[their]1305-they house]1306-their house , with a countenance which showed something to be wrong ; and [they]1305-they had set off immediately , informed and directed as [they]1305-they passed , towards the spot . Shocked as [Captain Harville]153-captain harville was , [he]153-captain harville brought senses and nerves that could be instantly useful ; and a look between [him]153-captain harville and [[his]153-captain harville wife]222-his wife decided what was to be done . [She]222-his wife must be taken to [[their]1305-they house]1306-their house ; [all]1125-all must go to [[their]1305-they house]1306-their house ; and await [the surgeon]1311-the surgeon 's arrival there . [They]1305-they would not listen to scruples : [he]153-captain harville was obeyed ; [they]1305-they were all beneath [his]153-captain harville roof ; and while [Louisa]124-louisa , under [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville 's direction , was conveyed up [stairs]756-stairs , and given possession of [her]124-louisa own bed , assistance , cordials , restoratives were supplied by [[her]124-louisa husband]2315-her husband to all who needed [them]1305-they .

[Louisa]124-louisa had once opened [her]124-louisa eyes , but soon closed them again , without apparent consciousness . This had been a proof of life , however , of service to [[her]124-louisa sister]476-her sister ; and [Henrietta]123-henrietta , though perfectly incapable of being in [the same room]789-the same room with [Louisa]124-louisa , was kept , by the agitation of hope and fear , from a return of [her]123-henrietta own insensibility . [Mary]94-mary , too , was growing calmer .

[The surgeon]1311-the surgeon was with [them]1305-they almost before it had seemed possible . [They]1305-they were sick with horror , while [he]1311-the surgeon examined ; but [he]1311-the surgeon was not hopeless . The head had received a severe contusion , but [he]1311-the surgeon had seen greater injuries recovered from : [he]1311-the surgeon was by no means hopeless ; [he]1311-the surgeon spoke cheerfully .

That [he]1311-the surgeon did not regard it as a desperate case , that [he]1311-the surgeon did not say a few hours must end it , was at first felt , beyond the hope of most ; and the ecstasy of such a reprieve , the rejoicing , deep and silent , after a few fervent ejaculations of gratitude to Heaven had been offered , may be conceived .

The tone , the look , with which " Thank [God]141-god ! "[117-captain wentworth] was uttered by [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , [Anne]93-anne was sure could never be forgotten by [her]93-anne ; nor the sight of [him]117-captain wentworth afterwards , as [he]117-captain wentworth sat near a table , leaning over it with folded arms and face concealed , as if overpowered by the various feelings of [his]117-captain wentworth soul , and trying by prayer and reflection to calm [them]1305-they .

[Louisa]124-louisa 's limbs had escaped . There was no injury but to the head .

It now became necessary for [the party]542-the party to consider what was best to be done , as to [their]1305-they general situation . [They]1305-they were now able to speak to [each other]489-each other and consult . That [Louisa]124-louisa must remain where [she]124-louisa was , however distressing to [[her]124-louisa friends]238-her friends to be involving [the Harvilles]154-the harvilles in such trouble , did not admit a doubt . [Her]124-louisa removal was impossible . [The Harvilles]154-the harvilles silenced all scruples ; and , as much as [they]1305-they could , all gratitude . [They]1305-they had looked forward and arranged everything before [the others]359-the others began to reflect . [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick must give up [[his]155-captain benwick room]1321-his room to [them]1305-they , and get another bed elsewhere ; and the whole was settled . [They]1305-they were only concerned that [the house]310-the house could accommodate no more ; and yet perhaps , by " putting [the children]610-the children away in [[the maid]2758-the maid 's room]2759-the maid 's room , or swinging a cot somewhere , "[1305-they] [they]1305-they could hardly bear to think of not finding room for [two or three besides]1323-two or three besides , supposing [they]1305-they might wish to stay ; though , with regard to any attendance on [Miss Musgrove]124-louisa , there need not be the least uneasiness in leaving [her]124-louisa to [[Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville 's care]1324-mrs harville 's care entirely . [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville was [a very experienced nurse]1325-a very experienced nurse , and [[her]140-mrs harville nursery - maid , who had lived with [her]140-mrs harville long , and gone about with [her]140-mrs harville everywhere]1326-her nursery - maid , who had lived with her long , and gone about with her everywhere , was just such another . Between these two , [she]124-louisa could want no possible attendance by day or night . And all this was said with a truth and sincerity of feeling irresistible .

[Charles]96-charles , [Henrietta]123-henrietta , and [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth were [the three]1327-the three in consultation , and for a little while it was only an interchange of perplexity and terror . " [Uppercross]4-uppercross , the necessity of [some one]952-some one 's going to [Uppercross]4-uppercross ; the news to be conveyed ; how it could be broken to [Mr and Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove ; the lateness of the morning ; an hour already gone since [they]1328-they ought to have been off ; the impossibility of being in tolerable time . "[1328-they] At first , [they]1328-they were capable of nothing more to the purpose than such exclamations ; but , after a while , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , exerting [himself]117-captain wentworth , said--

" [We]1328-they must be decided , and without the loss of another minute . Every minute is valuable . [Some one]952-some one must resolve on being off for [Uppercross]4-uppercross instantly . [Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove , either [you]120-mrs musgrove or [I]117-captain wentworth must go . "[117-captain wentworth]

[Charles]96-charles agreed , but declared [his]117-captain wentworth resolution of not going away . [He]117-captain wentworth would be as little incumbrance as possible to [Captain]2535-captain and [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville ; but as to leaving [[his]117-captain wentworth sister]799-his sister in such a state , [he]117-captain wentworth neither ought , nor would . So far it was decided ; and [Henrietta]123-henrietta at first declared the same . [She]123-henrietta , however , was soon persuaded to think differently . The usefulness of [her]123-henrietta staying ! [She]123-henrietta who had not been able to remain in [[Louisa]124-louisa 's room]1331-louisa 's room , or to look at [her]124-louisa , without sufferings which made [her]123-henrietta worse than helpless ! [She]123-henrietta was forced to acknowledge that [she]123-henrietta could do no good , yet was still unwilling to be away , till , touched by the thought of [[her]123-henrietta father]274-her father and [mother]473-mother , [she]123-henrietta gave it up ; [she]123-henrietta consented , [she]123-henrietta was anxious to be at [home]285-home .

The plan had reached this point , when [Anne]93-anne , coming quietly down from [[Louisa]124-louisa 's room]1331-louisa 's room , could not but hear what followed , for the parlour door was open .

" Then it is settled , [Musgrove]124-louisa , "[117-captain wentworth] cried [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , " that [you]124-louisa stay , and that [I]117-captain wentworth take care of [[your]124-louisa sister]2380-your sister [home]285-home . But as to the rest , as to the others , if [one]252-one stays to assist [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville , [I]117-captain wentworth think it need be only one . [Mrs Charles Musgrove]96-charles will , of course , wish to get back to [[her]140-mrs harville children]239-her children ; but if [Anne]93-anne will stay , [no one]479-no one so proper , so capable as [Anne]93-anne . "[117-captain wentworth]

[She]1336-she paused a moment to recover from the emotion of hearing [herself]1336-she so spoken of . [The other two]1337-the other two warmly agreed with what [he]117-captain wentworth said , and [she]1336-she then appeared .

" [You]1336-she will stay , [I]117-captain wentworth am sure ; [you]1336-she will stay and nurse [her]1336-she ; "[117-captain wentworth] cried [he]117-captain wentworth , turning to [her]1336-she and speaking with a glow , and yet a gentleness , which seemed almost restoring the past . [She]1336-she coloured deeply , and [he]117-captain wentworth recollected [himself]117-captain wentworth and moved away . [She]1336-she expressed [herself]1336-she most willing , ready , happy to remain . " It was what [she]1336-she had been thinking of , and wishing to be allowed to do . [A bed on the floor in [[Louisa]124-louisa 's room]1331-louisa 's room]2767-a bed on the floor in louisa 's room would be sufficient for [her]124-louisa , if [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville would but think so . "[1336-she]

One thing more , and all seemed arranged .
