[She]93-anne could imagine [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay to have said , that " now [Miss Anne]93-anne was come , [she]93-anne could not suppose [herself]93-anne at all wanted ; "[105-mrs clay] for [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth was replying in a sort of whisper , " That must not be any reason , indeed . [I]91-elizabeth assure [you]93-anne [I]91-elizabeth feel it none . [She]1007-the lady is nothing to [me]91-elizabeth , compared with [you]93-anne ; "[91-elizabeth] and [she]93-anne was in full time to hear [[her]93-anne father]274-her father say , " [[My]93-anne dear madam]2868-my dear madam , this must not be . As yet , [you]93-anne have seen nothing of [Bath]10-bath . [You]93-anne have been here only to be useful . [You]93-anne must not run away from [us]2869-us now . [You]93-anne must stay to be acquainted with [Mrs Wallis]173-mrs wallis , [the beautiful Mrs Wallis]173-mrs wallis . To [your]93-anne fine mind , [I]93-anne well know the sight of beauty is a real gratification . "[93-anne]

[He]274-her father spoke and looked so much in earnest , that [Anne]93-anne was not surprised to see [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay stealing a glance at [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth and [herself]105-mrs clay . [Her]105-mrs clay countenance , perhaps , might express some watchfulness ; but the praise of the fine mind did not appear to excite a thought in [[her]93-anne sister]476-her sister . [The lady]1007-the lady could not but yield to such joint entreaties , and promise to stay .

In the course of the same morning , [Anne]93-anne and [[her]93-anne father]274-her father chancing to be alone together , [he]274-her father began to compliment [her]105-mrs clay on [her]105-mrs clay improved looks ; [he]274-her father thought [her]105-mrs clay " less thin in [her]105-mrs clay person , in [her]105-mrs clay cheeks ; [her]105-mrs clay skin , [her]105-mrs clay complexion , greatly improved ; clearer , fresher . Had [she]105-mrs clay been using any thing in particular ? "[274-her father] " No , nothing . "[274-her father] " [Merely Gowland]66-gowland , "[274-her father] [he]274-her father supposed . " No , nothing at all . "[274-her father] " Ha ! [he]274-her father was surprised at that ; "[274-her father] and added , " certainly [you]93-anne can not do better than to continue as [you]93-anne are ; [you]93-anne can not be better than well ; or [I]274-her father should recommend [Gowland]66-gowland , the constant use of [Gowland]66-gowland , during the spring months . [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay has been using it at [my]274-her father recommendation , and [you]93-anne see what it has done for [her]105-mrs clay . [You]93-anne see how it has carried away [her]105-mrs clay freckles . "[274-her father]

If [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth could but have heard this ! Such personal praise might have struck [her]91-elizabeth , especially as it did not appear to [Anne]93-anne that the freckles were at all lessened . But everything must take its chance . The evil of a marriage would be much diminished , if [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth were also to marry . As for [herself]91-elizabeth , [she]91-elizabeth might always command a home with [Lady Russell]101-lady russell .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's composed mind and polite manners were put to some trial on this point , in [her]101-lady russell intercourse in [Camden Place]60-camden place . The sight of [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay in such favour , and of [Anne]93-anne so overlooked , was a perpetual provocation to [her]105-mrs clay there ; and vexed [her]105-mrs clay as much when [she]105-mrs clay was away , as [a person in Bath who drinks the water]1603-a person in bath who drinks the water , gets all the new publications , and has [a very large acquaintance]1604-a very large acquaintance , has time to be vexed .

As [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot became known to [her]105-mrs clay , [she]105-mrs clay grew more charitable , or more indifferent , towards [the others]359-the others . [His]102-mr elliot manners were an immediate recommendation ; and on conversing with [him]102-mr elliot [she]105-mrs clay found the solid so fully supporting the superficial , that [she]105-mrs clay was at first , as [she]105-mrs clay told [Anne]93-anne , almost ready to exclaim , " Can this be [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot ? "[105-mrs clay] and could not seriously picture to [herself]105-mrs clay [a more agreeable or estimable man]1606-a more agreeable or estimable man . Everything united in [him]102-mr elliot ; good understanding , correct opinions , knowledge of [the world]237-the world , and a warm heart . [He]102-mr elliot had strong feelings of family attachment and family honour , without pride or weakness ; [he]102-mr elliot lived with the liberality of [a man of fortune , without display]1608-a man of fortune , without display ; [he]102-mr elliot judged for [himself]102-mr elliot in everything essential , without defying public opinion in any point of worldly decorum . [He]102-mr elliot was steady , observant , moderate , candid ; never run away with by spirits or by selfishness , which fancied itself strong feeling ; and yet , with a sensibility to what was amiable and lovely , and a value for all the felicities of domestic life , which [characters of fancied enthusiasm and violent agitation]1609-characters of fancied enthusiasm and violent agitation seldom really possess . [She]105-mrs clay was sure that [he]102-mr elliot had not been happy in marriage . [Colonel Wallis]172-colonel wallis said it , and [Lady Russell]101-lady russell saw it ; but it had been no unhappiness to sour [his]102-mr elliot mind , nor ( [she]105-mrs clay began pretty soon to suspect ) to prevent [his]102-mr elliot thinking of a second choice . [Her]105-mrs clay satisfaction in [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot outweighed all the plague of [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay .

It was now some years since [Anne]93-anne had begun to learn that [she]93-anne and [[her]93-anne excellent friend]1610-her excellent friend could sometimes think differently ; and it did not surprise [her]93-anne , therefore , that [Lady Russell]101-lady russell should see nothing suspicious or inconsistent , nothing to require more motives than appeared , in [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot 's great desire of a reconciliation . In [Lady Russell]101-lady russell 's view , it was perfectly natural that [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot , at a mature time of life , should feel it a most desirable object , and what would very generally recommend [him]102-mr elliot among [all sensible people]1611-all sensible people , to be on good terms with [the head of [[his]102-mr elliot family]221-his family]2834-the head of his family ; the simplest process in [the world]237-the world of time upon a head naturally clear , and only erring in the heyday of youth . [Anne]93-anne presumed , however , still to smile about it , and at last to mention " [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth . "[101-lady russell] [Lady Russell]101-lady russell listened , and looked , and made only this cautious reply:--"Elizabeth ! very well ; time will explain . "[101-lady russell]

It was a reference to the future , which [Anne]93-anne , after a little observation , felt [she]93-anne must submit to . [She]93-anne could determine nothing at present . In [that house]445-that house [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth must be first ; and [she]91-elizabeth was in the habit of such general observance as " [Miss Elliot]93-anne , "[91-elizabeth] that any particularity of attention seemed almost impossible . [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot , too , it must be remembered , had not been [a widower]253-a widower seven months . A little delay on [his]102-mr elliot side might be very excusable . In fact , [Anne]93-anne could never see the crape round [his]102-mr elliot hat , without fearing that [she]93-anne was [the inexcusable one]1617-the inexcusable one , in attributing to [him]102-mr elliot such imaginations ; for though [his]102-mr elliot marriage had not been very happy , still it had existed so many years that [she]93-anne could not comprehend a very rapid recovery from the awful impression of its being dissolved .

However it might end , [he]102-mr elliot was without any question [their]1618-their pleasantest acquaintance in [Bath]10-bath : [she]93-anne saw [[nobody]2242-nobody equal to [him]102-mr elliot]1620-nobody equal to him ; and it was a great indulgence now and then to talk to [him]102-mr elliot about [Lyme]48-lyme , which [he]102-mr elliot seemed to have as lively a wish to see again , and to see more of , as [herself]93-anne . [They]1618-their went through the particulars of [their]1618-their first meeting a great many times . [He]102-mr elliot gave [her]93-anne to understand that [he]102-mr elliot had looked at [her]93-anne with some earnestness . [She]93-anne knew it well ; and [she]93-anne remembered [another person]2699-another person 's look also .

[They]1618-their did not always think alike . [His]102-mr elliot value for rank and connexion [she]93-anne perceived was greater than [hers]93-anne . It was not merely complaisance , it must be a liking to the cause , which made [him]102-mr elliot enter warmly into [[her]93-anne father]274-her father and [sister]268-sister 's solicitudes on a subject which [she]93-anne thought unworthy to excite [them]1624-their . The [Bath]10-bath paper one morning announced the arrival of [the Dowager Viscountess Dalrymple]176-the dowager viscountess dalrymple , and [[her]176-the dowager viscountess dalrymple daughter]1625-her daughter , [the Honourable Miss Carteret]177-miss carteret ; and all the comfort of No . -- , [Camden Place]60-camden place , was swept away for many days ; for [the Dalrymples]178-the dalrymples ( in [Anne]93-anne 's opinion , most unfortunately ) were [cousins of [the Elliots]179-the elliots]1626-cousins of the elliots ; and the agony was how to introduce [themselves]178-the dalrymples properly .

[Anne]93-anne had never seen [[her]93-anne father]274-her father and [sister]268-sister before in contact with [nobility]1629-nobility , and [she]93-anne must acknowledge [herself]93-anne disappointed . [She]93-anne had hoped better things from [their]1624-their high ideas of [their]1624-their own situation in life , and was reduced to form a wish which [she]93-anne had never foreseen ; a wish that [they]1624-their had more pride ; for " [[our]1624-their cousins]2870-our cousins [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple and [Miss Carteret]177-miss carteret ; "[1631-the rest of the family] " [[our]1624-their cousins]2870-our cousins , [the Dalrymples]178-the dalrymples , "[1631-the rest of the family] sounded in [her]93-anne ears all day long .

[Sir Walter]174-sir walter had once been in company with [the late viscount]1630-the late viscount , but had never seen any of [the rest of [the family]312-the family]1631-the rest of the family ; and the difficulties of the case arose from there having been a suspension of all intercourse by letters of ceremony , ever since the death of [that said late viscount]1633-that said late viscount , when , in consequence of a dangerous illness of [Sir Walter]174-sir walter 's at the same time , there had been an unlucky omission at [Kellynch]6-kellynch . No letter of condolence had been sent to [Ireland]68-ireland . The neglect had been visited on the head of [the sinner]1634-the sinner ; for when poor [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot died [herself]100-lady elliot , no letter of condolence was received at [Kellynch]6-kellynch , and , consequently , there was but too much reason to apprehend that [the Dalrymples]178-the dalrymples considered the relationship as closed . How to have this anxious business set to rights , and be admitted as [cousins]1010-cousins again , was the question : and it was a question which , in a more rational manner , neither [Lady Russell]101-lady russell nor [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot thought unimportant . " [Family connexions]2872-family connexions were always worth preserving , good company always worth seeking ; [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple had taken [a house]2221-a house , for three months , in [Laura Place]69-laura place , and would be living in style . [She]180-lady dalrymple had been at [Bath]10-bath the year before , and [Lady Russell]101-lady russell had heard [her]180-lady dalrymple spoken of as [a charming woman]2874-a charming woman . It was very desirable that the connexion should be renewed , if it could be done , without any compromise of propriety on the side of [the Elliots]179-the elliots . "[174-sir walter]

[Sir Walter]174-sir walter , however , would choose [his]174-sir walter own means , and at last wrote a very fine letter of ample explanation , regret , and entreaty , to [[his]174-sir walter right honourable cousin]1636-his right honourable cousin . Neither [Lady Russell]101-lady russell nor [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot could admire the letter ; but it did all that was wanted , in bringing three lines of scrawl from [the Dowager Viscountess]1637-the dowager viscountess . " [She]180-lady dalrymple was very much honoured , and should be happy in [their]1638-they acquaintance . "[1636-his right honourable cousin] The toils of the business were over , the sweets began . [They]1638-they visited in [Laura Place]69-laura place , [they]1638-they had the cards of [Dowager Viscountess Dalrymple]176-the dowager viscountess dalrymple , and [the Honourable Miss Carteret]177-miss carteret , to be arranged wherever [they]1638-they might be most visible : and " [[Our]1638-they cousins]2870-our cousins in [Laura]70-laura Place,"--"Our[180-lady dalrymple] cousin , [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple and [Miss Carteret]177-miss carteret , " were talked of to [everybody]651-everybody .[180-lady dalrymple]

[Anne]93-anne was ashamed . Had [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple and [[her]180-lady dalrymple daughter]1625-her daughter even been very agreeable , [she]93-anne would still have been ashamed of the agitation [they]1638-they created , but [they]1638-they were nothing . There was no superiority of manner , accomplishment , or understanding . [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple had acquired the name of " [a charming woman]2874-a charming woman , "[180-lady dalrymple] because [she]180-lady dalrymple had a smile and a civil answer for [everybody]651-everybody . [Miss Carteret]177-miss carteret , with still less to say , was so plain and so awkward , that [she]177-miss carteret would never have been tolerated in [Camden Place]60-camden place but for [her]177-miss carteret birth .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell confessed [she]101-lady russell had expected something better ; but yet " it was an acquaintance worth having ; "[101-lady russell] and when [Anne]93-anne ventured to speak [her]93-anne opinion of [them]1638-they to [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot , [he]102-mr elliot agreed to [their]1638-they being nothing in [themselves]1638-they , but still maintained that , as [a family]439-a family connexion , as good company , as [those who would collect good company around [them]1638-they]1642-those who would collect good company around them , [they]1638-they had [their]1638-they value . [Anne]93-anne smiled and said ,

" [My]93-anne idea of good company , [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot , is the company of [clever , well - informed people , who have a great deal of conversation]2878-clever , well - informed people , who have a great deal of conversation ; that is what [I]93-anne call good company . "[93-anne]

" [You]93-anne are mistaken , "[102-mr elliot] said [he]102-mr elliot gently , " that is not good company ; that is the best . [Good company]2879-good company requires only birth , education , and manners , and with regard to education is not very nice . Birth and good manners are essential ; but a little learning is by no means a dangerous thing in good company ; on the contrary , it will do very well . [[My]102-mr elliot cousin]2880-my cousin [Anne]93-anne shakes [her]93-anne head . [She]93-anne is not satisfied . [She]93-anne is fastidious . [[My]102-mr elliot dear cousin]2881-my dear cousin "[102-mr elliot] ( sitting down by [her]93-anne ) , " [you]93-anne have a better right to be fastidious than almost [any other woman [I]93-anne know]2882-any other woman i know ; but will it answer ? Will it make [you]93-anne happy ? Will it not be wiser to accept [the society of [those good ladies in [Laura Place]69-laura place]2884-those good ladies in laura place]2883-the society of those good ladies in laura place , and enjoy all the advantages of the connexion as far as possible ? [You]93-anne may depend upon it , that [they]2884-those good ladies in laura place will move in the first set in [Bath]10-bath this winter , and as rank is rank , [your]93-anne being known to be related to [them]2884-those good ladies in laura place will have its use in fixing [[your]93-anne family]2885-your family ( [[our]2886-we family]2694-our family let [me]93-anne say ) in that degree of consideration which [we]2886-we must all wish for . "[93-anne]

" Yes , "[93-anne] sighed [Anne]93-anne , " [we]2886-we shall , indeed , be known to be related to [them]2884-those good ladies in laura place ! "[93-anne] then recollecting [herself]93-anne , and not wishing to be answered , [she]93-anne added , " [I]93-anne certainly do think there has been by far too much trouble taken to procure the acquaintance . [I]93-anne suppose "[93-anne] ( smiling ) " [I]93-anne have more pride than any of [you]93-anne ; but [I]93-anne confess it does vex [me]93-anne , that [we]2886-we should be so solicitous to have the relationship acknowledged , which [we]2886-we may be very sure is a matter of perfect indifference to [them]2884-those good ladies in laura place . "[93-anne]

" Pardon [me]93-anne , [dear cousin]2888-dear cousin , [you]2888-dear cousin are unjust in [your]2888-dear cousin own claims . "[93-anne]

" Well , "[93-anne] said [Anne]93-anne , " [I]93-anne certainly am proud , too proud to enjoy a welcome which depends so entirely upon place . "[93-anne]

" [I]1643-i love [your]93-anne indignation , "[1643-i] said [he]1643-i ; " it is very natural . But here [you]93-anne are in [Bath]10-bath , and the object is to be established [here]2340-here with all the credit and dignity which ought to belong to [Sir Walter Elliot]90-sir walter . [You]93-anne talk of being proud ; [I]1643-i am called proud , [I]1643-i know , and [I]1643-i shall not wish to believe [myself]1643-i otherwise ; for [our]2891-we pride , if investigated , would have the same object , [I]1643-i have no doubt , though the kind may seem a little different . In one point , [I]1643-i am sure , [[my]1643-i dear cousin]2881-my dear cousin , "[1643-i] ( [he]1643-i continued , speaking lower , though there was [no one else]2859-no one else in [the room]406-the room ) " in one point , [I]1643-i am sure , [we]2891-we must feel alike . [We]2891-we must feel that [every addition to [[your]93-anne father]2212-your father 's society , among [[his]2212-your father equals or [superiors]2896-superiors]2895-his equals or superiors]2893-every addition to your father 's society , among his equals or superiors , may be of use in diverting [his]2212-your father thoughts from [those who are beneath [him]2212-your father]2897-those who are beneath him . "[1643-i]

[He]1643-i looked , as [he]1643-i spoke , to the seat which [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay had been lately occupying : a sufficient explanation of what [he]1643-i particularly meant ; and though [Anne]93-anne could not believe in [their]1646-their having the same sort of pride , [she]93-anne was pleased with [him]1643-i for not liking [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay ; and [her]93-anne conscience admitted that [his]1643-i wishing to promote [[her]93-anne father]274-her father 's getting great acquaintance was more than excusable in the view of defeating [her]93-anne .

Chapter 17

While [Sir Walter]90-sir walter and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth were assiduously pushing [their]1646-their good fortune in [Laura Place]69-laura place , [Anne]93-anne was renewing an acquaintance of a very different description .

[She]93-anne had called on [[her]93-anne former governess]1648-her former governess , and had heard from [her]1648-her former governess of there being [an old school - fellow in [Bath]10-bath , who had the two strong claims on [her]1648-her former governess attention of past kindness and present suffering]1649-an old school - fellow in bath , who had the two strong claims on her attention of past kindness and present suffering . [Miss Hamilton]181-miss hamilton , now [Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith , had shewn [her]181-miss hamilton kindness in one of those periods of [her]181-miss hamilton life when it had been most valuable . [Anne]93-anne had gone unhappy to [school]380-school , grieving for the loss of [a mother whom [she]93-anne had dearly loved , feeling [her]93-anne separation from [home]285-home]1651-a mother whom she had dearly loved , feeling her separation from home , and suffering as [a girl of fourteen , of strong sensibility and not high spirits]1653-a girl of fourteen , of strong sensibility and not high spirits , must suffer at such a time ; and [Miss Hamilton]181-miss hamilton , three years older than [herself]181-miss hamilton , but still from the want of near relations and a settled home , remaining another year at [school]380-school , had been useful and good to [her]181-miss hamilton in a way which had considerably lessened [her]181-miss hamilton misery , and could never be remembered with indifference .

[Miss Hamilton]181-miss hamilton had left [school]380-school , had married not long afterwards , was said to have married [a man of fortune]1656-a man of fortune , and this was all that [Anne]93-anne had known of [her]181-miss hamilton , till now that [[their]1657-their governess]1658-their governess 's account brought [her]181-miss hamilton situation forward in a more decided but very different form .

[She]181-miss hamilton was [a widow and poor]1659-a widow and poor . [[Her]181-miss hamilton husband]2315-her husband had been extravagant ; and at [his]2315-her husband death , about two years before , had left [his]2315-her husband affairs dreadfully involved . [She]181-miss hamilton had had difficulties of every sort to contend with , and in addition to these distresses had been afflicted with a severe rheumatic fever , which , finally settling in [her]181-miss hamilton legs , had made [her]181-miss hamilton for the present a cripple . [She]181-miss hamilton had come to [Bath]10-bath on that account , and was now in lodgings near [the hot baths]1661-the hot baths , living in a very humble way , unable even to afford [herself]181-miss hamilton the comfort of [a servant]1662-a servant , and of course almost excluded from [society]233-society .

[[Their]1657-their mutual friend]1664-their mutual friend answered for the satisfaction which a visit from [Miss Elliot]93-anne would give [Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith , and [Anne]93-anne therefore lost no time in going . [She]93-anne mentioned nothing of what [she]93-anne had heard , or what [she]93-anne intended , at [home]285-home . It would excite no proper interest there . [She]93-anne only consulted [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , who entered thoroughly into [her]181-miss hamilton sentiments , and was most happy to convey [her]181-miss hamilton as near to [[Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith 's lodgings in [Westgate Buildings]72-westgate buildings]1666-mrs smith 's lodgings in westgate buildings , as [Anne]93-anne chose to be taken .

The visit was paid , [their]1657-their acquaintance re - established , [their]1657-their interest in [each other]489-each other more than re - kindled . The first ten minutes had its awkwardness and its emotion . Twelve years were gone since [they]1657-their had parted , and each presented [a somewhat different person]1668-a somewhat different person from what [the other]254-the other had imagined . Twelve years had changed [Anne]93-anne from [the blooming , silent , unformed girl of fifteen]1670-the blooming , silent , unformed girl of fifteen , to [the elegant little woman of seven - and - twenty , with every beauty except bloom]1671-the elegant little woman of seven - and - twenty , with every beauty except bloom , and with manners as consciously right as [they]1672-they were invariably gentle ; and twelve years had transformed [the fine - looking , well - grown [Miss Hamilton]181-miss hamilton]1673-the fine - looking , well - grown miss hamilton , in all the glow of health and confidence of superiority , into [a poor , infirm , helpless widow]1674-a poor , infirm , helpless widow , receiving the visit of [[her]181-miss hamilton former protegee]1675-her former protegee as a favour ; but all that was uncomfortable in the meeting had soon passed away , and left only the interesting charm of remembering former partialities and talking over old times .

[Anne]93-anne found in [Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith the good sense and agreeable manners which [she]93-anne had almost ventured to depend on , and a disposition to converse and be cheerful beyond [her]93-anne expectation . Neither the dissipations of the past -- and [she]93-anne had lived very much in [the world]237-the world -- nor the restrictions of the present , neither sickness nor sorrow seemed to have closed [her]93-anne heart or ruined [her]93-anne spirits .

In the course of a second visit [she]93-anne talked with great openness , and [Anne]93-anne 's astonishment increased . [She]93-anne could scarcely imagine a more cheerless situation in itself than [Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith 's . [She]93-anne had been very fond of [[her]93-anne husband]2315-her husband : [she]93-anne had buried [him]2315-her husband . [She]93-anne had been used to affluence : it was gone . [She]93-anne had [no child]1678-no child to connect [her]93-anne with life and happiness again , no relations to assist in the arrangement of perplexed affairs , no health to make all the rest supportable . [[Her]93-anne accommodations]1679-her accommodations were limited to [a noisy parlour]1680-a noisy parlour , and [a dark bedroom]1681-a dark bedroom behind , with no possibility of moving from one to the other without assistance , which there was only [one servant in [the house]310-the house]1682-one servant in the house to afford , and [she]93-anne never quitted [the house]310-the house but to be conveyed into the warm bath . Yet , in spite of all this , [Anne]93-anne had reason to believe that [she]93-anne had moments only of languor and depression , to hours of occupation and enjoyment . How could it be ? [She]93-anne watched , observed , reflected , and finally determined that this was not a case of fortitude or of resignation only . [A submissive spirit]1685-a submissive spirit might be patient , a strong understanding would supply resolution , but here was something more ; here was that elasticity of mind , that disposition to be comforted , that power of turning readily from evil to good , and of finding employment which carried [her]93-anne out of [herself]93-anne , which was from nature alone . It was the choicest gift of Heaven ; and [Anne]93-anne viewed [[her]93-anne friend]546-her friend as one of those instances in which , by a merciful appointment , it seems designed to counterbalance almost every other want .

There had been a time , [Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith told [her]93-anne , when [her]93-anne spirits had nearly failed . [She]93-anne could not call [herself]93-anne [an invalid]1687-an invalid now , compared with [her]93-anne state on first reaching Bath . Then [she]93-anne had , indeed , been [a pitiable object]1688-a pitiable object ; for [she]93-anne had caught cold on the journey , and had hardly taken possession of [[her]93-anne lodgings]1689-her lodgings before [she]93-anne was again confined to [her]93-anne bed and suffering under severe and constant pain ; and all this among [strangers]810-strangers , with the absolute necessity of having [a regular nurse]1691-a regular nurse , and finances at that moment particularly unfit to meet any extraordinary expense . [She]93-anne had weathered it , however , and could truly say that it had done [her]93-anne good . It had increased [her]93-anne comforts by making [her]93-anne feel [herself]93-anne to be in good hands . [She]93-anne had seen too much of [the world]237-the world , to expect sudden or disinterested attachment anywhere , but [her]93-anne illness had proved to [her]93-anne that [[her]93-anne landlady]1693-her landlady had a character to preserve , and would not use [her]93-anne ill ; and [she]93-anne had been particularly fortunate in [[her]93-anne nurse]1694-her nurse , as [a sister of [[her]93-anne landlady]1693-her landlady , [a nurse]1380-a nurse by profession , and who had always [a home in [that house]445-that house when unemployed]1698-a home in that house when unemployed , chanced to be at liberty just in time to attend [her]93-anne]1695-a sister of her landlady , a nurse by profession , and who had always a home in that house when unemployed , chanced to be at liberty just in time to attend her . " And [she]93-anne , "[182-mrs smith] said [Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith , " besides nursing [me]182-mrs smith most admirably , has really proved an invaluable acquaintance . As soon as [I]182-mrs smith could use [my]182-mrs smith hands [she]93-anne taught [me]182-mrs smith to knit , which has been a great amusement ; and [she]93-anne put [me]182-mrs smith in the way of making these little thread - cases , pin - cushions and card - racks , which [you]2898-you always find [me]182-mrs smith so busy about , and which supply [me]182-mrs smith with the means of doing a little good to one or [two very poor families in [this neighbourhood]2900-this neighbourhood]2899-two very poor families in this neighbourhood . [She]93-anne had a large acquaintance , of course professionally , among [those who can afford to buy]2901-those who can afford to buy , and [she]93-anne disposes of [my]182-mrs smith merchandise . [She]93-anne always takes the right time for applying . [Everybody]651-everybody 's heart is open , [you]2898-you know , when [they]651-everybody have recently escaped from severe pain , or are recovering the blessing of health , and [Nurse Rooke]183-nurse rooke thoroughly understands when to speak . [She]183-nurse rooke is [a shrewd , intelligent , sensible woman]2903-a shrewd , intelligent , sensible woman . [Hers]183-nurse rooke is a line for seeing human nature ; and [she]183-nurse rooke has a fund of good sense and observation , which , as a companion , make [her]183-nurse rooke infinitely superior to [thousands of those who having only received ' the best education in [the world]237-the world]2904-thousands of those who having only received ' the best education in the world , ' know nothing worth attending to . Call it gossip , if [you]2898-you will , but when [Nurse Rooke]183-nurse rooke has half an hour 's leisure to bestow on [me]182-mrs smith , [she]183-nurse rooke is sure to have something to relate that is entertaining and profitable : something that makes [one]252-one know [one]252-one 's species better . [One]252-one likes to hear what is going on , to be au fait as to the newest modes of being trifling and silly . To [me]182-mrs smith , who live so much alone , [her]183-nurse rooke conversation , [I]182-mrs smith assure [you]2898-you , is a treat . "[182-mrs smith]

[Anne]93-anne , far from wishing to cavil at the pleasure , replied , " [I]93-anne can easily believe it . [Women of that class]2909-women of that class have great opportunities , and if [they]2909-women of that class are intelligent may be well worth listening to . Such varieties of human nature as they are in the habit of witnessing ! And it is not merely in its follies , that they are well read ; for [they]2909-women of that class see it occasionally under every circumstance that can be most interesting or affecting . What instances must pass before [them]2909-women of that class of ardent , disinterested , self - denying attachment , of heroism , fortitude , patience , resignation : of all the conflicts and all the sacrifices that ennoble [us]2910-us most . [A sick chamber]2911-a sick chamber may often furnish the worth of volumes . "[93-anne]

" Yes , "[182-mrs smith] said [Mrs Smith]182-mrs smith more doubtingly , " sometimes it may , though [I]182-mrs smith fear its lessons are not often in the elevated style [you]2898-you describe . There is so little real friendship in [the world]237-the world ! and unfortunately "[182-mrs smith] ( speaking low and tremulously ) " there are so many who forget to think seriously till it is almost too late . [Anne]93-anne saw the misery of such feelings . [Anne]93-anne had called several times on [[her]93-anne friend]546-her friend , before the existence of [such a person]2653-such a person was known in [Camden Place]60-camden place . [Anne]93-anne kept [her]93-anne appointment ; [the others]359-the others kept [theirs]359-the others , and of course [she]93-anne heard the next morning that [they]1711-theirs had had a delightful evening . [She]182-mrs smith had been [the only one of [the set absent]1716-the set absent]1715-the only one of the set absent , for [Sir Walter]90-sir walter and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth had not only been quite at [[her]182-mrs smith ladyship]1717-her ladyship 's service [themselves]1711-theirs , but had actually been happy to be employed by [her]182-mrs smith in collecting [others]391-others , and had been at the trouble of inviting both [Lady Russell]101-lady russell and [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot ; and [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot had made a point of leaving [Colonel Wallis]172-colonel wallis early , and [Lady Russell]101-lady russell had fresh arranged all [her]101-lady russell evening engagements in order to wait on [her]101-lady russell . [Anne]93-anne had the whole history of all that such an evening could supply from [Lady Russell]101-lady russell . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell was now perfectly decided in [her]101-lady russell opinion of [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot . [She]101-lady russell was as much convinced of [his]102-mr elliot meaning to gain [Anne]93-anne in time as of [his]102-mr elliot deserving [her]93-anne , and was beginning to calculate the number of weeks which would free [him]102-mr elliot from all the remaining restraints of widowhood , and leave [him]102-mr elliot at liberty to exert [his]102-mr elliot most open powers of pleasing . [She]101-lady russell would not speak to [Anne]93-anne with half the certainty [she]101-lady russell felt on the subject , [she]101-lady russell would venture on little more than hints of what might be hereafter , of a possible attachment on [his]102-mr elliot side , of the desirableness of the alliance , supposing such attachment to be real and returned . [Anne]93-anne heard [her]101-lady russell , and made no violent exclamations ; [she]93-anne only smiled , blushed , and gently shook [her]93-anne head .

" [I]101-lady russell am [no match - maker]2937-no match - maker , as [you]93-anne well know , "[101-lady russell] said [Lady Russell]101-lady russell , " being much too well aware of the uncertainty of all human events and calculations . " [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot is [an exceedingly agreeable man]2939-an exceedingly agreeable man , and in many respects [I]93-anne think highly of [him]102-mr elliot , "[93-anne] said [Anne]93-anne ; " but [we]2940-we should not suit . "[93-anne]

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell let this pass , and only said in rejoinder , " [I]101-lady russell own that to be able to regard [you]93-anne as [the future mistress of [Kellynch]6-kellynch]2941-the future mistress of kellynch , [the future Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot , to look forward and see [you]93-anne occupying [[your]93-anne dear mother]2942-your dear mother 's place , succeeding to all [her]2942-your dear mother rights , and all [her]2942-your dear mother popularity , as well as to all [her]2942-your dear mother virtues , would be the highest possible gratification to [me]101-lady russell . [[My]101-lady russell dearest]2945-my dearest [Anne]93-anne , it would give [me]101-lady russell more delight than is often felt at [my]101-lady russell time of life ! "[101-lady russell]

[Anne]93-anne was obliged to turn away , to rise , to walk to a distant table , and , leaning there in pretended employment , try to subdue the feelings this picture excited . For a few moments [her]93-anne imagination and [her]93-anne heart were bewitched . The idea of becoming what [[her]93-anne mother]263-her mother had been ; of having the precious name of " [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot "[263-her mother] first revived in [herself]93-anne ; of being restored to [Kellynch]6-kellynch , calling it [[her]93-anne home]373-her home again , [[her]93-anne home]373-her home for ever , was a charm which [she]93-anne could not immediately resist . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell said not another word , willing to leave the matter to [its]1729-its own operation ; and believing that , could [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot at that moment with propriety have spoken for [himself!--she]102-mr elliot believed , in short , what [Anne]93-anne did not believe . The same image of [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot speaking for [himself]102-mr elliot brought [Anne]93-anne to composure again . The charm of [Kellynch]6-kellynch and of " [Lady Elliot]100-lady elliot "[93-anne] all faded away . [She]93-anne never could accept [him]102-mr elliot . And it was not only that [her]93-anne feelings were still adverse to [any man]1730-any man save [one]252-one ; [her]93-anne judgement , on a serious consideration of the possibilities of such a case was against [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot .

Though [they]1732-they had now been acquainted a month , [she]93-anne could not be satisfied that [she]93-anne really knew [his]102-mr elliot character . That [he]102-mr elliot was [a sensible man]503-a sensible man , [an agreeable man]1734-an agreeable man , that [he]102-mr elliot talked well , professed good opinions , seemed to judge properly and as [a man of principle]2214-a man of principle , this was all clear enough . [He]102-mr elliot certainly knew what was right , nor could [she]93-anne fix on any one article of moral duty evidently transgressed ; but yet [she]93-anne would have been afraid to answer for [his]102-mr elliot conduct . [She]93-anne distrusted the past , if not the present . The names which occasionally dropt of [former associates]1736-former associates , the allusions to former practices and pursuits , suggested suspicions not favourable of what [he]102-mr elliot had been . [She]93-anne saw that there had been bad habits ; that [Sunday]186-sunday travelling had been a common thing ; that there had been a period of [his]102-mr elliot life ( and probably not a short one ) when [he]102-mr elliot had been , at least , careless in all serious matters ; and , though [he]102-mr elliot might now think very differently , who could answer for the true sentiments of [a clever , cautious man , grown old enough to appreciate a fair character]1737-a clever , cautious man , grown old enough to appreciate a fair character ? How could it ever be ascertained that [his]102-mr elliot mind was truly cleansed ?

[Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot was rational , discreet , polished , but [he]102-mr elliot was not open . There was never any burst of feeling , any warmth of indignation or delight , at the evil or good of [others]391-others . This , to [Anne]93-anne , was a decided imperfection . [Her]93-anne early impressions were incurable . [She]93-anne prized the frank , the open - hearted , the eager character beyond all others . Warmth and enthusiasm did captivate [her]93-anne still . [She]93-anne felt that [she]93-anne could so much more depend upon the sincerity of [those who sometimes looked or said a careless or a hasty thing]1739-those who sometimes looked or said a careless or a hasty thing , than of [those whose presence of mind never varied , whose tongue never slipped]1740-those whose presence of mind never varied , whose tongue never slipped .

[Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot was too generally agreeable . Various as were the tempers in [[[her]93-anne father]274-her father 's house]398-her father 's house , [he]102-mr elliot pleased [them]1743-them all . [He]102-mr elliot endured too well , stood too well with every body . [He]102-mr elliot had spoken to [her]93-anne with some degree of openness of [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay ; had appeared completely to see what [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay was about , and to hold [her]93-anne in contempt ; and yet [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay found [him]102-mr elliot as agreeable as any body .

[Lady Russell]101-lady russell saw either less or more than [[her]101-lady russell young friend]385-her young friend , for [she]101-lady russell saw nothing to excite distrust . [She]101-lady russell could not imagine [a man]2277-a man more exactly what [he]2277-a man ought to be than [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot ; nor did [she]101-lady russell ever enjoy a sweeter feeling than the hope of seeing [him]102-mr elliot receive the hand of [[her]101-lady russell beloved]1746-her beloved [Anne]93-anne in [Kellynch church]6-kellynch , in the course of the following autumn .

Chapter 18

It was the beginning of February ; and [Anne]93-anne , having been a month in [Bath]10-bath , was growing very eager for news from [Uppercross]4-uppercross and [Lyme]48-lyme . [She]93-anne wanted to hear much more than [Mary]94-mary had communicated . It was three weeks since [she]93-anne had heard at all . [She]93-anne only knew that [Henrietta]123-henrietta was at [home]285-home again ; and that [Louisa]124-louisa , though considered to be recovering fast , was still in [Lyme]48-lyme ; and [she]93-anne was thinking of [them]1748-them all very intently one evening , when a thicker letter than usual from [Mary]94-mary was delivered to [her]93-anne ; and , to quicken the pleasure and surprise , with [Admiral]111-admiral croft and [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft 's compliments .

[The Crofts]116-the crofts must be in [Bath]10-bath ! A circumstance to interest [her]93-anne . [They]116-the crofts were people whom [her]93-anne heart turned to very naturally .

" What is this ? "[90-sir walter] cried [Sir Walter]90-sir walter . " [The Crofts]116-the crofts have arrived in [Bath]10-bath ? [The Crofts who rent [Kellynch]6-kellynch]2946-the crofts who rent kellynch ? What have [they]2946-the crofts who rent kellynch brought [you]93-anne ? "[90-sir walter]

" A letter from [Uppercross Cottage]20-uppercross cottage , [Sir]2533-sir . "[1749-the poor admiral]

" Oh ! those letters are convenient passports . [They]116-the crofts secure an introduction . [I]90-sir walter should have visited [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft , however , at any rate . [I]90-sir walter know what is due to [[my]90-sir walter tenant]2948-my tenant . "[90-sir walter]

[Anne]93-anne could listen no longer ; [she]93-anne could not even have told how [the poor Admiral]1749-the poor admiral 's complexion escaped ; [her]93-anne letter engrossed [her]93-anne . It had been begun several days back .

" February 1st . "[1749-the poor admiral]

" [[My]1749-the poor admiral dear]2319-my dear [Anne,--I]187-anne,--i make no apology for [my]1749-the poor admiral silence , because [I]1749-the poor admiral know how [little people]2950-little people think of letters in such a place as [Bath]10-bath . [You]2319-my dear must be a great deal too happy to care for [Uppercross]4-uppercross , which , as [you]2319-my dear well know , affords little to write about . [We]2951-we have had a very dull Christmas ; [Mr and Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove have not had one dinner party all the holidays . [I]1749-the poor admiral do not reckon [the Hayters]143-the hayters as [anybody]2413-anybody . The holidays , however , are over at last : [I]1749-the poor admiral believe [no children]2953-no children ever had such long ones . [I]1749-the poor admiral am sure [I]1749-the poor admiral had not . [The house]310-the house was cleared yesterday , except of [the little Harvilles]154-the harvilles ; but [you]2319-my dear will be surprised to hear [they]154-the harvilles have never gone [home]285-home . [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville must be [an odd mother]2956-an odd mother to part with [them]154-the harvilles so long . [I]1749-the poor admiral do not understand it . [They]154-the harvilles are not at all [nice children]2957-nice children , in [my]1749-the poor admiral opinion ; but [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove seems to like [them]154-the harvilles quite as well , if not better , than [[her]140-mrs harville grandchildren]2958-her grandchildren . What dreadful weather [we]2959-we have had ! It may not be felt in [Bath]10-bath , with [[your]2319-my dear nice pavements]2960-your nice pavements ; but in [the country]287-the country it is of some consequence . [I]1749-the poor admiral have not had a creature call on [me]1749-the poor admiral since the second week in January , except [Charles Hayter]95-charles , who had been calling much oftener than was welcome . Between [ourselves]2959-we , [I]1749-the poor admiral think it a great pity [Henrietta]123-henrietta did not remain at [Lyme]48-lyme as long as [Louisa]124-louisa ; it would have kept [her]123-henrietta a little out of [his]95-charles way . [The carriage]683-the carriage is gone to - day , to bring [Louisa]124-louisa and [the Harvilles]154-the harvilles to - morrow . [We]2959-we are not asked to dine with [them]154-the harvilles , however , till the day after , [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove is so afraid of [her]123-henrietta being fatigued by the journey , which is not very likely , considering the care that will be taken of [her]123-henrietta ; and it would be much more convenient to [me]1749-the poor admiral to dine there to - morrow . [I]1749-the poor admiral am glad [you]2963-you find [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot so agreeable , and wish [I]1749-the poor admiral could be acquainted with [him]102-mr elliot too ; but [I]1749-the poor admiral have [my]1749-the poor admiral usual luck : [I]1749-the poor admiral am always out of the way when any thing desirable is going on ; always the last of [[my]1749-the poor admiral family]2964-my family to be noticed . What an immense time [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay has been staying with [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth ! Does [she]105-mrs clay never mean to go away ? But perhaps if [she]105-mrs clay were to leave [the room]406-the room vacant , [we]2966-we might not be invited . Let [me]1749-the poor admiral know what [you]2963-you think of this . [I]1749-the poor admiral do not expect [[my]1749-the poor admiral children]2967-my children to be asked , [you]2963-you know . [I]1749-the poor admiral can leave [them]2967-my children at [the Great House]564-the great house very well , for a month or six weeks . [I]1749-the poor admiral have this moment heard that [the Crofts]116-the crofts are going to [Bath]10-bath almost immediately ; [they]116-the crofts think [the Admiral]111-admiral croft gouty . [Charles]95-charles heard it quite by chance ; [they]116-the crofts have not had the civility to give [me]1749-the poor admiral any notice , or of offering to take anything . [I]1749-the poor admiral do not think [they]116-the crofts improve at all as [neighbours]250-neighbours . [We]2970-we see nothing of [them]116-the crofts , and this is really an instance of gross inattention . [Charles]95-charles joins [me]1749-the poor admiral in love , and everything proper . [Yours]2963-you affectionately , "[1749-the poor admiral]

" [Mary M---]188-mary . "[1749-the poor admiral]

" [I]1749-the poor admiral am sorry to say that [I]1749-the poor admiral am very far from well ; and [Jemima]126-jemima has just told [me]1749-the poor admiral that [the butcher]2971-the butcher says there is a bad sore - throat very much about . [I]1749-the poor admiral dare say [I]1749-the poor admiral shall catch it ; and [my]1749-the poor admiral sore - throats , [you]2963-you know , are always worse than [anybody]2413-anybody 's . "[1749-the poor admiral]

So ended the first part , which had been afterwards put into an envelope , containing nearly as much more .

" [I]188-mary kept [my]188-mary letter open , that [I]188-mary might send [you]2963-you word how [Louisa]124-louisa bore [her]124-louisa journey , and now [I]188-mary am extremely glad [I]188-mary did , having a great deal to add . In the first place , [I]188-mary had a note from [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft yesterday , offering to convey anything to [you]2963-you ; a very kind , friendly note indeed , addressed to [me]188-mary , just as it ought ; [I]188-mary shall therefore be able to make [my]188-mary letter as long as [I]188-mary like . [The Admiral]411-the admiral does not seem very ill , and [I]188-mary sincerely hope [Bath]10-bath will do [him]411-the admiral all the good [he]411-the admiral wants . [I]188-mary shall be truly glad to have [them]2974-them back again . [[Our]2975-we neighbourhood]2976-our neighbourhood can not spare such [a pleasant family]2977-a pleasant family . But now for [Louisa]124-louisa . [I]188-mary have something to communicate that will astonish [you]2963-you not a little . [She]124-louisa and [the Harvilles]154-the harvilles came on Tuesday very safely , and in the evening [we]2975-we went to ask [her]124-louisa how [she]124-louisa did , when [we]2975-we were rather surprised not to find [Captain Benwick of the party]2978-captain benwick of the party , for [he]2978-captain benwick of the party had been invited as well as [the Harvilles]154-the harvilles ; and what do [you]2963-you think was the reason ? Neither more nor less than [his]2978-captain benwick of the party being in love with [Louisa]124-louisa , and not choosing to venture to [Uppercross]4-uppercross till [he]2978-captain benwick of the party had had an answer from [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove ; for it was all settled between [him]2978-captain benwick of the party and [her]124-louisa before [she]124-louisa came away , and [he]2978-captain benwick of the party had written to [[her]124-louisa father]274-her father by [Captain Harville]153-captain harville . True , upon [my]188-mary honour ! Are not [you]2963-you astonished ? [I]188-mary shall be surprised at least if [you]2963-you ever received a hint of it , for [I]188-mary never did . [Mrs Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove protests solemnly that [she]124-louisa knew nothing of the matter . [We]2980-we are all very well pleased , however , for though it is not equal to [her]124-louisa marrying [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth , it is infinitely better than [Charles Hayter]95-charles ; and [Mr Musgrove]120-mrs musgrove has written [his]120-mrs musgrove consent , and [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick is expected to - day . [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville says [[her]140-mrs harville husband]2315-her husband feels a good deal on [[his]2315-her husband poor sister]2982-his poor sister 's account ; but , however , [Louisa]124-louisa is a great favourite with both . Indeed , [Mrs Harville]140-mrs harville and [I]188-mary quite agree that [we]2980-we love [her]124-louisa the better for having nursed [her]124-louisa . [Charles]95-charles wonders what [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth will say ; but if [you]2983-you remember , [I]188-mary never thought [him]117-captain wentworth attached to [Louisa]124-louisa ; [I]188-mary never could see anything of it . And this is the end , [you]2983-you see , of [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick 's being supposed to be [an admirer of [yours]2983-you]2984-an admirer of yours . How [Charles]95-charles could take such a thing into [his]95-charles head was always incomprehensible to [me]188-mary . [I]188-mary hope [he]117-captain wentworth will be more agreeable now . Certainly not a great match for [Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa , but a million times better than marrying among [the Hayters]143-the hayters . "[188-mary]

[Mary]188-mary need not have feared [[her]188-mary sister]476-her sister 's being in any degree prepared for the news . [She]188-mary had never in [her]188-mary life been more astonished . [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick and [Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa ! It was almost too wonderful for belief , and it was with the greatest effort that [she]188-mary could remain in [the room]406-the room , preserve an air of calmness , and answer the common questions of the moment . Happily for [her]188-mary , [they]1752-they were not many . [Sir Walter]90-sir walter wanted to know whether [the Crofts]2421-the crofts travelled with four horses , and whether [they]2421-the crofts were likely to be situated in [such a part of [Bath]10-bath]1754-such a part of bath as it might suit [Miss Elliot]93-anne and [himself]90-sir walter to visit in ; but had little curiosity beyond .

" How is [Mary]188-mary ? "[91-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth ; and without waiting for an answer , " And pray what brings [the Crofts]116-the crofts to [Bath]10-bath ? "[91-elizabeth]

" [They]2421-the crofts come on [the Admiral]411-the admiral 's account . [He]411-the admiral is thought to be gouty . "[2421-the crofts]

" Gout and decrepitude ! "[90-sir walter] said [Sir Walter]90-sir walter . " [Poor old gentleman]2986-poor old gentleman . "[90-sir walter]

" Have [they]2421-the crofts any acquaintance [here]2340-here ? "[91-elizabeth] asked [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth .

" [I]2421-the crofts do not know ; but [I]2421-the crofts can hardly suppose that , at [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft 's time of life , and in [his]111-admiral croft profession , [he]111-admiral croft should not have many acquaintance in such a place as this . "[2421-the crofts]

" [I]90-sir walter suspect , "[90-sir walter] said [Sir Walter]90-sir walter coolly , " that [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft will be best known in [Bath]10-bath as [the renter of [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall]2988-the renter of kellynch hall . [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth , may [we]2989-we venture to present [him]111-admiral croft and [[his]111-admiral croft wife]222-his wife in [Laura Place]69-laura place ? "[90-sir walter]

" Oh , no ! [I]1755-her fine little boys think not . Situated as [we]2989-we are with [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple , [cousins]1010-cousins , [we]2989-we ought to be very careful not to embarrass [her]180-lady dalrymple with acquaintance [she]180-lady dalrymple might not approve . If [we]2989-we were not related , it would not signify ; but as [cousins]1010-cousins , [she]180-lady dalrymple would feel scrupulous as to any proposal of [ours]2989-we . [We]2989-we had better leave [the Crofts]116-the crofts to find [their]116-the crofts own level . There are [several odd - looking men walking about here , who , [I]1755-her fine little boys am told , are [sailors]2271-sailors]2993-several odd - looking men walking about here , who , i am told , are sailors . [The Crofts]116-the crofts will associate with [them]2993-several odd - looking men walking about here , who , i am told , are sailors . "[1755-her fine little boys]

This was [Sir Walter]90-sir walter and [Elizabeth]91-elizabeth 's share of interest in the letter ; when [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay had paid [her]105-mrs clay tribute of more decent attention , in an enquiry after [Mrs Charles Musgrove]96-charles , and [[her]105-mrs clay fine little boys]1755-her fine little boys , [Anne]93-anne was at liberty .

In [[her]93-anne own room]1756-her own room , [she]93-anne tried to comprehend it . Well might [Charles]96-charles wonder how [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth would feel ! Perhaps [he]117-captain wentworth had quitted [the field]965-the field , had given [Louisa]124-louisa up , had ceased to love , had found [he]117-captain wentworth did not love [her]124-louisa . [She]124-louisa could not endure the idea of treachery or levity , or anything akin to ill usage between [him]117-captain wentworth and [[his]117-captain wentworth friend]1073-his friend . [She]124-louisa could not endure that such a friendship as [theirs]1759-they should be severed unfairly .

[Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick and [Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa ! [The high - spirited , joyous - talking Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa , and [the dejected , thinking , feeling , reading]1760-the dejected , thinking , feeling , reading , [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick , seemed each of [them]1759-they everything that would not suit [the other]254-the other . [Their]1759-they minds most dissimilar ! Where could have been the attraction ? The answer soon presented itself . It had been in situation . [They]1759-they had been thrown together several weeks ; [they]1759-they had been living in [the same small family party]1762-the same small family party : since [Henrietta]123-henrietta 's coming away , [they]1759-they must have been depending almost entirely on [each other]489-each other , and [Louisa]124-louisa , just recovering from illness , had been in an interesting state , and [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick was not inconsolable . That was a point which [Anne]93-anne had not been able to avoid suspecting before ; and instead of drawing the same conclusion as [Mary]188-mary , from the present course of events , [they]1759-they served only to confirm the idea of [his]155-captain benwick having felt some dawning of tenderness toward [herself]93-anne . [She]93-anne did not mean , however , to derive much more from it to gratify [her]93-anne vanity , than [Mary]188-mary might have allowed . [She]93-anne was persuaded that [any tolerably pleasing young woman who had listened and seemed to feel]1764-any tolerably pleasing young woman who had listened and seemed to feel for [him]155-captain benwick would have received the same compliment . [He]155-captain benwick had an affectionate heart . [He]155-captain benwick must love [somebody]1243-somebody .

[She]93-anne saw no reason against [their]1759-they being happy . [Louisa]124-louisa had fine naval fervour to begin with , and [they]1759-they would soon grow more alike . [He]155-captain benwick would gain cheerfulness , and [she]124-louisa would learn to be an enthusiast for [Scott]163-mr scott and [Lord Byron]164-lord byron ; nay , that was probably learnt already ; of course [they]1759-they had fallen in love over poetry . The idea of [Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa turned into [a person of literary taste]1766-a person of literary taste , and sentimental reflection was amusing , but [she]124-louisa had no doubt of its being so . The day at [Lyme]48-lyme , the fall from [the Cobb]49-the cobb , might influence [her]124-louisa health , [her]124-louisa nerves , [her]124-louisa courage , [her]124-louisa character to the end of [her]124-louisa life , as thoroughly as it appeared to have influenced [her]124-louisa fate .

The conclusion of the whole was , that if [the woman who had been sensible of]1767-the woman who had been sensible of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's merits could be allowed to prefer [another man]1768-another man , there was nothing in the engagement to excite lasting wonder ; and if [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth lost [no friend]1769-no friend by it , certainly nothing to be regretted . No , it was not regret which made [Anne]93-anne 's heart beat in spite of [herself]93-anne , and brought the colour into [her]93-anne cheeks when [she]93-anne thought of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth unshackled and free . [She]93-anne had some feelings which [she]93-anne was ashamed to investigate . They were too much like joy , senseless joy !

[She]93-anne longed to see [the Crofts]116-the crofts ; but when the meeting took place , it was evident that no rumour of the news had yet reached [them]116-the crofts . The visit of ceremony was paid and returned ; and [Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa was mentioned , and [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick , too , without even half a smile .

[The Crofts]116-the crofts had placed [themselves]116-the crofts in [lodgings in [Gay Street]74-gay street]1770-lodgings in gay street , perfectly to [Sir Walter]90-sir walter 's satisfaction . [He]90-sir walter was not at all ashamed of the acquaintance , and did , in fact , think and talk a great deal more about [the Admiral]411-the admiral , than [the Admiral]411-the admiral ever thought or talked about [him]411-the admiral .

[The Crofts]116-the crofts knew quite as many people in [Bath]10-bath as [they]116-the crofts wished for , and considered [their]116-the crofts intercourse with [the Elliots]179-the elliots as a mere matter of form , and not in the least likely to afford [them]116-the crofts any pleasure . [They]116-the crofts brought with [them]116-the crofts [their]116-the crofts country habit of being almost always together . [He]411-the admiral was ordered to walk to keep off the gout , and [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft seemed to go shares with [him]411-the admiral in everything , and to walk for [her]112-mrs croft life to do [him]411-the admiral good . [Anne]93-anne saw [them]116-the crofts wherever [she]93-anne went . [Lady Russell]101-lady russell took [her]93-anne out in [[her]101-lady russell carriage]1773-her carriage almost every morning , and [she]93-anne never failed to think of [them]116-the crofts , and never failed to see [them]116-the crofts . Knowing [their]116-the crofts feelings as [she]93-anne did , it was a most attractive picture of happiness to [her]93-anne . [She]93-anne always watched [them]116-the crofts as long as [she]93-anne could , delighted to fancy [she]93-anne understood what [they]116-the crofts might be talking of , as [they]116-the crofts walked along in happy independence , or equally delighted to see [the Admiral]411-the admiral 's hearty shake of the hand when [he]411-the admiral encountered [an old friend]676-an old friend , and observe [their]116-the crofts eagerness of conversation when occasionally forming into a little knot of [the navy]2245-the navy , [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft looking as intelligent and keen as any of [the officers around [her]93-anne]1777-the officers around her .

[Anne]93-anne was too much engaged with [Lady Russell]101-lady russell to be often walking [herself]93-anne ; but it so happened that one morning , about a week or ten days after [the Croft]112-mrs croft 's arrival , it suited [her]93-anne best to leave [[her]93-anne friend]546-her friend , or [[her]93-anne friend]546-her friend 's carriage , in [the lower part of [the town]1093-the town]1780-the lower part of the town , and return alone to [Camden Place]60-camden place , and in walking up [Milsom Street]76-milsom street [she]93-anne had the good fortune to meet with [the Admiral]411-the admiral . [He]411-the admiral was standing by [himself]411-the admiral at a printshop window , with [his]411-the admiral hands behind [him]411-the admiral , in earnest contemplation of some print , and [she]101-lady russell not only might have passed [him]411-the admiral unseen , but was obliged to touch as well as address [him]411-the admiral before [she]101-lady russell could catch [his]411-the admiral notice . When [he]411-the admiral did perceive and acknowledge [her]101-lady russell , however , it was done with all [his]411-the admiral usual frankness and good humour . " Ha ! is it [you]101-lady russell ? Thank [you]101-lady russell , thank [you]101-lady russell . This is treating [me]411-the admiral like [a friend]1363-a friend . Here [I]411-the admiral am , [you]101-lady russell see , staring at a picture . [I]411-the admiral can never get by [this shop]2996-this shop without stopping . But what a thing [here]2340-here is , by way of [a boat]2998-a boat ! Do look at it . Did [you]101-lady russell ever see the like ? What [queer fellows [your]101-lady russell fine painters]2999-queer fellows your fine painters must be , to think that [anybody]2413-anybody would venture [their]2999-queer fellows your fine painters lives in such a shapeless old cockleshell as that ? And yet here are [two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at [their]3001-two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at their ease ease]3001-two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at their ease , and looking about [them]3001-two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at their ease at [the rocks]3002-the rocks and [mountains]3003-mountains , as if [they]3001-two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at their ease were not to be upset the next moment , which [they]3001-two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at their ease certainly must be . [I]411-the admiral wonder where [that boat]3004-that boat was built ! "[411-the admiral] ( laughing heartily ) ; " [I]411-the admiral would not venture over a horsepond in [it]3004-that boat . Well , "[411-the admiral] ( turning away ) , " now , where are [you]101-lady russell bound ? Can [I]411-the admiral go anywhere for [you]101-lady russell , or with [you]101-lady russell ? Can [I]411-the admiral be of any use ? "[411-the admiral]

" None , [I]411-the admiral thank [you]101-lady russell , unless [you]101-lady russell will give [me]411-the admiral the pleasure of [your]101-lady russell company the little way [[our]3005-we road]3006-our road lies together . [I]411-the admiral am going [home]285-home . "[411-the admiral]

" That [I]411-the admiral will , with all [my]411-the admiral heart , and farther , too . Yes , yes [we]3005-we will have a snug walk together , and [I]411-the admiral have something to tell [you]101-lady russell as [we]3005-we go along . There , take [my]411-the admiral arm ; that 's right ; [I]411-the admiral do not feel comfortable if [I]411-the admiral have not [a woman there]3008-a woman there . [Lord]3009-lord ! what a boat it is ! "[411-the admiral] taking a last look at the picture , as [they]1783-they began to be in motion .

" Did [you]101-lady russell say that [you]101-lady russell had something to tell [me]411-the admiral , [sir]2533-sir ? "[411-the admiral]

" Yes , [I]411-the admiral have , presently . But here comes [a friend]1363-a friend , [Captain Brigden]189-captain brigden ; [I]411-the admiral shall only say , ' How [d'ye]3012-d'ye do ? ' as [we]3005-we pass , however . [I]411-the admiral shall not stop . ' How [d'ye]3012-d'ye do ? ' [Brigden]189-captain brigden stares to see anybody with [me]411-the admiral but [[my]411-the admiral wife]2794-my wife . [She]2794-my wife , [poor soul]3014-poor soul , is tied by the leg . [She]2794-my wife has a blister on one of [her]2794-my wife heels , as large as a three - shilling piece . If [you]2533-sir look across [the street]1268-the street , [you]2533-sir will see [Admiral Brand]190-admiral brand coming down and [[his]1363-a friend brother]1496-his brother . [Shabby fellows]3017-shabby fellows , [both of [them]3017-shabby fellows]3018-both of them ! [I]411-the admiral am glad [they]3017-shabby fellows are not on this side of the way . [Sophy]135-sophy can not bear [them]3017-shabby fellows . [They]3017-shabby fellows played [me]411-the admiral a pitiful trick once : got away with [some of [[my]411-the admiral best men]3020-my best men]3019-some of my best men . [I]411-the admiral will tell [you]2533-sir the whole story another time . There comes [old Sir Archibald Drew]191-old sir archibald drew and [[his]191-old sir archibald drew grandson]3021-his grandson . Look , [he]191-old sir archibald drew sees [us]3022-we ; [he]191-old sir archibald drew kisses [his]191-old sir archibald drew hand to [you]2533-sir ; [he]191-old sir archibald drew takes [you]2533-sir for [[my]411-the admiral wife]2794-my wife . Ah ! the peace has come too soon for that [younker]2533-sir . [Poor old Sir Archibald]191-old sir archibald drew ! How do [you]2533-sir like [Bath]10-bath , [Miss Elliot]93-anne ? It suits [us]3022-we very well . [We]3022-we are always meeting with [some old friend]3024-some old friend or other ; [the streets]1507-the streets full of [them]3024-some old friend every morning ; sure to have plenty of chat ; and then [we]3022-we get away from [them]3024-some old friend all , and shut [ourselves]3022-we in [[our]3022-we lodgings]3026-our lodgings , and draw in [our]3022-we chairs , and are as snug as if [we]3022-we were at [Kellynch]6-kellynch , ay , or as [we]3022-we used to be even at [North Yarmouth]47-north yarmouth and [Deal]41-deal . [We]3022-we do not like [[our]3022-we lodgings]3026-our lodgings here the worse , [I]411-the admiral can tell [you]3028-you , for putting [us]3022-we in mind of those [we]3022-we first had at [North Yarmouth]47-north yarmouth . The wind blows through one of the cupboards just in the same way . "[411-the admiral]

When [they]1784-we were got a little farther , [Anne]93-anne ventured to press again for what [he]1785-i had to communicate . [She]93-anne hoped when clear of [Milsom Street]76-milsom street to have [her]93-anne curiosity gratified ; but [she]93-anne was still obliged to wait , for [the Admiral]411-the admiral had made up [his]411-the admiral mind not to begin till [they]1784-we had gained the greater space and quiet of [Belmont]77-belmont ; and as [she]93-anne was not really [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft , [she]93-anne must let [him]1785-i have [his]1785-i own way . As soon as [they]1784-we were fairly ascending [Belmont]77-belmont , [he]1785-i began--

" Well , now [you]93-anne shall hear something that will surprise [you]93-anne . But first of all , [you]93-anne must tell [me]1785-i the name of [the young lady]3029-the young lady [I]1785-i am going to talk about . [That young lady]3030-that young lady , [you]93-anne know , that [we]1784-we have all been so concerned for . [The Miss Musgrove]124-louisa , that all this has been happening to . [Her]3030-that young lady Christian name : [I]1785-i always forget [her]3030-that young lady Christian name . "[1785-i]

[Anne]93-anne had been ashamed to appear to comprehend so soon as [she]93-anne really did ; but now [she]93-anne could safely suggest the name of " [Louisa]124-louisa . "[93-anne]

" Ay , ay , [Miss Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa , that is the name . [I]1785-i wish [young ladies]3031-young ladies had not such a number of fine Christian names . [I]1785-i should never be out if [they]3031-young ladies were [all Sophys]3032-all sophys , or something of that sort . Well , this [Miss Louisa]124-louisa , [we]1784-we all thought , [you]93-anne know , was to marry [Frederick]117-captain wentworth . [He]117-captain wentworth was courting [her]124-louisa week after week . The only wonder was , what [they]3031-young ladies could be waiting for , till the business at [Lyme]48-lyme came ; then , indeed , it was clear enough that [they]3031-young ladies must wait till [her]124-louisa brain was set to right . But even then there was something odd in [their]3031-young ladies way of going on . Instead of staying at [Lyme]48-lyme , [he]117-captain wentworth went off to [Plymouth]28-plymouth , and then [he]117-captain wentworth went off to see [Edward]128-edward . When [we]1784-we came back from [Minehead]78-minehead [he]117-captain wentworth was gone down to [Edward]128-edward 's , and there [he]117-captain wentworth has been ever since . [We]1784-we have seen nothing of [him]117-captain wentworth since November . Even [Sophy]135-sophy could not understand it . But now , the matter has taken the strangest turn of all ; for [this young lady]3033-this young lady , the same [Miss Musgrove]124-louisa , instead of being to marry [Frederick]117-captain wentworth , is to marry [James Benwick]192-james benwick . [You]3034-you know [James Benwick]192-james benwick . "[1785-i]

" A little . [I]93-anne am a little acquainted with [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick . "[93-anne]

" Well , [she]3033-this young lady is to marry [him]155-captain benwick . Nay , most likely [they]3035-they are married already , for [I]1785-i do not know what [they]3035-they should wait for . "[1785-i]

" [I]93-anne thought [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick [a very pleasing young man]3036-a very pleasing young man , "[93-anne] said [Anne]93-anne , " and [I]93-anne understand that [he]155-captain benwick bears an excellent character . "[93-anne]

" Oh ! yes , yes , there is not a word to be said against [James Benwick]192-james benwick . [He]155-captain benwick is only [a commander]3037-a commander , it is true , made last summer , and these are bad times for getting on , but [he]155-captain benwick has not another fault that [I]1785-i know of . [An excellent , good - hearted fellow]3038-an excellent , good - hearted fellow , [I]1785-i assure [you]3039-you ; [a very active , zealous officer]3040-a very active , zealous officer too , which is more than [you]3039-you would think for , perhaps , for that soft sort of manner does not do [him]155-captain benwick justice . "[1785-i]

" Indeed [you]3039-you are mistaken there , [sir]2533-sir ; [I]93-anne should never augur want of spirit from [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick 's manners . [I]93-anne thought [them]3042-them particularly pleasing , and [I]93-anne will answer for it , [they]3042-them would generally please . "[93-anne]

" Well , well , [ladies]3043-ladies are [the best judges]3044-the best judges ; but [James Benwick]192-james benwick is rather too piano for [me]1785-i ; and though very likely it is all [our]3045-our partiality , [Sophy]135-sophy and [I]1785-i can not help thinking [Frederick]117-captain wentworth 's manners better than [his]155-captain benwick . There is something about [Frederick]117-captain wentworth more to [our]3045-our taste . "[1785-i]

[Anne]93-anne was caught . [She]93-anne had only meant to oppose the too common idea of spirit and gentleness being incompatible with each other , not at all to represent [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick 's manners as the very best that could possibly be ; and , after a little hesitation , [she]93-anne was beginning to say , " [I]93-anne was not entering into any comparison of [the two friends]3046-the two friends , "[93-anne] but [the Admiral]411-the admiral interrupted [her]93-anne with--

" And the thing is certainly true . It is not a mere bit of gossip . [We]3045-our have it from [Frederick]117-captain wentworth [himself]117-captain wentworth . [[His]117-captain wentworth sister]799-his sister had a letter from [him]117-captain wentworth yesterday , in which [he]117-captain wentworth tells [us]3045-our of it , and [he]117-captain wentworth had just had it in a letter from [Harville]140-mrs harville , written upon the spot , from [Uppercross]4-uppercross . [I]411-the admiral fancy [they]3046-the two friends are all at [Uppercross]4-uppercross . "[411-the admiral]

This was an opportunity which [Anne]93-anne could not resist ; [she]93-anne said , therefore , " [I]93-anne hope , [Admiral]2508-admiral , [I]93-anne hope there is nothing in the style of [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's letter to make [you]2508-admiral and [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft particularly uneasy . It did seem , last autumn , as if there were an attachment between [him]117-captain wentworth and [Louisa Musgrove]124-louisa ; but [I]93-anne hope it may be understood to have worn out on each side equally , and without violence . [I]93-anne hope [his]117-captain wentworth letter does not breathe the spirit of [an ill - used man]3049-an ill - used man . "[93-anne]

" Not at all , not at all ; there is not an oath or a murmur from beginning to end . "[93-anne]

[Anne]93-anne looked down to hide [her]93-anne smile .

" No , no ; [Frederick]117-captain wentworth is not [a man to whine and complain]3050-a man to whine and complain ; [he]117-captain wentworth has too much spirit for that . If [the girl]3051-the girl likes [another man]1768-another man better , it is very fit [she]3051-the girl should have [him]117-captain wentworth . "[93-anne]

" Certainly . But what [I]93-anne mean is , that [I]93-anne hope there is nothing in [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth 's manner of writing to make [you]2508-admiral suppose [he]117-captain wentworth thinks [himself]117-captain wentworth ill - used by [[his]117-captain wentworth friend]1073-his friend , which might appear , [you]2508-admiral know , without its being absolutely said . [I]93-anne should be very sorry that such a friendship as has subsisted between [him]117-captain wentworth and [Captain Benwick]155-captain benwick should be destroyed , or even wounded , by a circumstance of this sort . "[93-anne]

" Yes , yes , [I]93-anne understand [you]2508-admiral . But there is nothing at all of that nature in the letter . [He]117-captain wentworth does not give the least fling at [Benwick]155-captain benwick ; does not so much as say , ' [I]93-anne wonder at it , [I]93-anne have a reason of [my]93-anne own for wondering at it . ' No , [you]2508-admiral would not guess , from [his]117-captain wentworth way of writing , that [he]117-captain wentworth had ever thought of [this Miss]3054-this miss ( what 's [her]3054-this miss name ? ) for [himself]117-captain wentworth . [He]117-captain wentworth very handsomely hopes [they]3055-they will be happy together ; and there is nothing very unforgiving in that , [I]93-anne think . "[93-anne]

[Anne]93-anne did not receive the perfect conviction which [the Admiral]411-the admiral meant to convey , but it would have been useless to press the enquiry farther . [She]93-anne therefore satisfied [herself]93-anne with common - place remarks or quiet attention , and [the Admiral]411-the admiral had it all [his]411-the admiral own way .

" [Poor Frederick]193-poor frederick ! "[411-the admiral] said [he]411-the admiral at last . " Now [he]193-poor frederick must begin all over again with [somebody else]3056-somebody else . [I]411-the admiral think [we]3055-they must get [him]193-poor frederick to [Bath]10-bath . [Sophy]135-sophy must write , and beg [him]193-poor frederick to come to [Bath]10-bath . Here are [pretty girls]3057-pretty girls enough , [I]411-the admiral am sure . It would be of no use to go to [Uppercross]4-uppercross again , for that other [Miss Musgrove]124-louisa , [I]411-the admiral find , is bespoke by [[her]124-louisa cousin]2558-her cousin , [the young parson]3059-the young parson . Do not [you]93-anne think , [Miss Elliot]93-anne , [we]3060-we had better try to get [him]117-captain wentworth to [Bath]10-bath ? "[411-the admiral]

Chapter 19

While [Admiral Croft]111-admiral croft was taking this walk with [Anne]93-anne , and expressing [his]111-admiral croft wish of getting [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth to [Bath]10-bath , [Captain Wentworth]117-captain wentworth was already on [his]117-captain wentworth way thither . Before [Mrs Croft]112-mrs croft had written , [he]117-captain wentworth was arrived , and the very next time [Anne]93-anne walked out , [she]93-anne saw [him]117-captain wentworth .

[Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot was attending [[his]102-mr elliot two cousins]1790-his two cousins and [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay . [They]1791-them were in [Milsom Street]76-milsom street . It began to rain , not much , but enough to make shelter desirable for [women]2486-women , and quite enough to make it very desirable for [Miss Elliot]93-anne to have the advantage of being conveyed [home]285-home in [[Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple 's carriage , which was seen waiting at a little distance]1794-lady dalrymple 's carriage , which was seen waiting at a little distance ; [she]180-lady dalrymple , [Anne]93-anne , and [Mrs Clay]105-mrs clay , therefore , turned into [Molland]194-molland 's , while [Mr Elliot]102-mr elliot stepped to [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple , to request [her]180-lady dalrymple assistance . [He]102-mr elliot soon joined [them]1791-them again , successful , of course ; [Lady Dalrymple]180-lady dalrymple would be most happy to take [them]1791-them [home]285-home , and would call for [them]1791-them in a few minutes .

[[Her]180-lady dalrymple ladyship]1717-her ladyship 's carriage was a barouche , and did not hold more than four with any comfort .
